genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
review_text: i played 7 days to die and enjoyed it immensely, especially the mix of survival, crafting, and exploration. the game kept me hooked with its intense nights and rewarding progression. i’ve spent countless hours playing with friends, and every session felt exciting and unpredictable. building and defending our bases together was one of the highlights. overall, it’s one of the most fun and engaging co-op survival games i’ve experience

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
review_text: this game has been though quite a bit over the course of it life. is it still fun, yes, is it different from what it was many years ago, very much so. once the devs get their vision built, this can become a great game, but for now, its just a fun, physics based, survival, zombie fps.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
review_text: bought this game a few years back and i always seem to return to it. developers never gave up even if the cash flow has probably dwindled considerably since there's no cash shop / dlc until recently and it's been out for years. there's also great mods out there for it. imho not only was it worth the money i spent on it, but i'd gladly pay for cash shops / dlc items (as long as it's cosmetic and not p2w) to help the developers out.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
review_text: ok, so review time. i have played this game for over 700 hours now and i must say it is one of the best zombie survival ames out there in my oppinion there is nothing out there that has the same feel as this game, the progressio is great and the building aspect is wonderfull. it has a steep learning curve when you start the game fresh and don't know what you are doing, but give it time and it will grow on you. it's a voxel game so everything is a block that can be destroyed but can also be exploited. this game is so much fun, but the devs have been going into a strange direction with the game ever since 1.0 but i still have faith they will make the game even better. i highly reccomend this game it is a must play.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
review_text: 7 days to die is the lovechild of minecraft and a zombie apocalypse… if that child also came with a serious performance problem. gathering, crafting, and building feels great, especially when you’re fortifying your base for the dreaded horde night. the sandbox survival is deep and addictive, and there’s nothing like blasting zombies with a diy shotgun you just crafted. but optimization is rough — even mid-range pcs can struggle, and the ui feels like it was designed by someone who hates clarity. horde nights are thrilling, but sometimes you spend more time fighting the game than the zombies. 6/10 — fun moments, but your pc might file a complaint.

review_text: i have a lot of hours in this game, but when i say that it has gotten worse with every update i mean it, the music is worse, the visuals, the game play, everything is much worse. for one, you used to be able to wear up to ten or so items on your character, now you get four four! the game is not a survival game, it plays like an adventure game built on top of a survival game with a lot of features very commonly being removed to the point where i'm longing to play older versions of the game for the game play instead of wanting to remove the bulk. it's bad, but maybe still the best considering the quality of other games but it used to be great not the best of x type. furthermore your saves will be deleted every update. very nice.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
review_text: 2025/11 there's still no content in the game, a sandbox where you have to entertain yourself with something, after leveling up once new game's progression feels slow, the missions are boring, and the game mechanics are designed to slow down the process. it would be better to focus on end-game development. it's an empty game with interesting mechanics, crafting, and buildings.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
review_text: i played this first on xbox back when telltale was involved and then i got on here till my old pc couldn't run it, then i got a new one and played it again and i can say after every update the game felt worse and worse and worse. i came back hearing somethings that were pretty much all bad. i had some hope. that was crushed very fast. tutorial sets you up for failure. rewards for quests aren't balanced. xp grind is not adjusted properly. don't get me wrong it's called a grind for a reason but when almost full week passes and i'm still level 3 on default settings after killing a new yorks city worth of zombies that's just bull. quest locations if they are a zombie filled building all the zombies just sit there till i hit a trigger and if i get a new quest in the same building they all respawn even if it was only 3 minutes since i was there. the only thing that is still around that i like (and doesn't feel pointless now) is zombies are still somewhat tanky early game but aren't going to rip your face off if your careful while also still being easy to kill. i know you can mod this game but if you have to mod a game to make it fun the game is screwed up.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
review_text: i have been playing this game for about 10 or so years now on and off. what they have done to progression is just awful. remember when crafting an item made you better at crafting it? remember when doing an action like running, jumping, looting , ect. made your skill for that level up? i sure do. now most of your progression is pretty much 100% rng dependent. they keep making changes that force you into a certain playstyle instead of you know... the sandbox survival game that it used to be. making farming harder, zombies don't drop loot like they used to, constantly changing zombie ai to nerf base designs they don't like people using, removing clothing for some reason, removing getting jars back after drinking water, making leveling traders harder, and just so many more obnoxious and useless changes that horrible. its like they hate their players i really do not get it. it is honestly just so sad to see what the game has become. i really cannot recommend this game anymore especially for $45.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
review_text: i have honestly yet to play a game as unstable as this. even on the latest build, native linux or proton with a half-million different settings tweaked, it remains horribly unstable. at any random time, atleast once per hour, the game will either freeze my system, or spike the memory usage 30gb, and then crash after ooming my system. its a... slow game when its not crashing, with progression made difficult by the instability since at any moment it could crash forcing you to remain in places that are as safe as possible.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
review_text: i had this game for some time, played it back in alpha 15 i think, was very fun and then some more around 18, 19, 20 i think. the game was only improving but now i don't really like that much this version of the game. i've put some 40 hours-ish into this version and maybe i will try some more but at this state in the game, and at this price(44euro) i can't recommand it. wait for a sale to make it even a bit worth. if u have some friends to try with it might raise it's worth but alone not so much

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
review_text: used to love this game, a decade ago. every update however just seems to make the game worse, and the progression more tedious/grindy. and $45 for this? it was worth the $20-25 back in 2017, but its fallen too far/gotten too few updates in the last few years to justify the price anymore.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
review_text: if the fun pimps would have just finished the game they had instead of trying to rework every aspect over and over again it would have been a gem. but hey, you can buy dlc cosmetic items now, thanks fun pimps.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
review_text: i've put over 300 hours into this game because it was one me and my sisters would play together, but since its official 1.0 release, the game has not improved in any considerable way, and the price hike to $45 is wildly stupid because it's not worth more than $30 for the content that's available. not to mention, there's no actual purpose to the game other than 24/7 survival. there's no story, and the "quests" that are in the game do nothing but help you level up to unlock perks. the base building aspect is lacking and extremely mediocre, the combat mechanics are still crap and the graphics are still ugly to look at. if you are still interested in it, buy it when it goes on a steep sale. otherwise, avoid it.

review_text: been playing since this thing was a twinkle in its fathers eye. was good for a long time, got better too. for some reason they stopped making new zombie skins and decided they should update the armor system and starting quest. the new quest system is bad... way worse than before. one of the first quests is to dig with a stone shovel... they made it shorter now, but still... no one wants to dig with a stone shovel. the new quest ui is terrible. they updated the armor system... wasn't sure why until today. 11 bucks for a single armor set... how the mighty have fallen.

review_text: game is playable. and in a group setting could be fun. but its over promised and under delivered and on top of that after an over decade long dev cycle they cant help but use generative art in the game and then not disclose it. can't recommend paying for a near full price game with all of that.

fun game! the buildings are gorgeous. i loved setting up industries and production chains and planning out crop rotations.

farthest frontier is a fantastic city builder. the visuals are beautiful, the atmosphere feels alive, and it’s genuinely rewarding to see your small settlement grow into a thriving town. the survival mechanics add just the right amount of challenge, keeping things engaging without being frustrating. every run feels different, and i keep coming back for more. easily one of the best games in the genre.
in-depth medieval city sim. combat is trash, but can be disabled

great game. ui is a bit peculiar and the game has performance issues, when you reach higher population numbers, but overall you can sink many hours into this, do micromanaging, fight against animals and raiders and so on. it's a mix of anno, frostpunk and cities skylines with it's own touch.

one of the best examples of early access done right. been there from the beginning and the developer communcated their goals well, took enough time to implement everything and there weren't even too many bugs involved! great chill but also demanding survival city building with an emphasis on forward planning, resource production, population management and trade. also big thumps up for no use of ai!
this is a great game. realistic and challenging. love getting as far as i can and then rerolling and trying out something else.
chilling and relaxing game with a lovely characteristic
one of your villagers died. ☠️
way better than manor lords

mix of city builder and rts. there's some depth to the production chains and tech tree but the military gameplay loop is pretty basic. early game food production is a bottleneck. late game the raiders are overpowered. overall it's a decent game with both easy and challenging map biomes and gameplay modes. there's some flexibility to city layout but there's certain production chains that work better when placed in a more formulaic structure, so the city building part is kind of repetitive after a couple of play throughs. the strategic combat portion of the game is very basic and repetitive after the first five raids. the devs have hinted at future updates and possibly dlcs if the game sells well so hopefully they continue to expand on the core gameplay loops like they did during early access. it's like a more polished version of banished with basic rts combat added. there's at least 30-50 hours of play here minimum. more if you enjoy city building with some environmental interruptions and the occasional raider incursion. definitely a good city builder sandbox game with some shallow military and rts components.

exceptional before release, exceptional at release. this game will suck you in for hours, even when you've finished it repeatedly. there's something really satisfying about it. can't wait to see how it develops.

finally into v1.0 and great to see the game become what most of us thought it would be. highly recommended and now its in v1.0 its time tog et right into the gameplay and enjoy the completed features.
its a really well made game. the first learning curve is a bit step due to having to set limits in your storages inventory. but otherwise all good and fun.
solid city builder and very addicting
one of the best city manegment/builder game on steam. looks both beautiful and feels easy too learn/understand.
rich and cool game mechanics.

surprisingly deep, especially on the economic side. its city-building system is stable and well-designed, and the realistic crop-rotation mechanics make it an excellent survival city-builder — even if the combat elements are not the most exciting part of the experience. i can only recommend it to every city-builder fan.
i enjoy this one. easy to start and fun to deep dive into. late game gets slow and a little grindy but is still fun. its only a month old and i'm at 220+ hrs already. that speaks for itself.
simple but a crafty gameplay design.
this is my favorite of the colony city builders. great farming, lots of depth
a certified cozy banger for the years to come. it's both challenging and merciful for a very satisfying result that's going to make you crave for "one more year" over and over.

a worthy successor to the classic banished. very pretty art style that is mostly grounded with a slight fantasy flair to it. the changing seasons are beautiful to look at, and the survival mechanics are a solid challenge and very tweakable. combat is a welcome addition as well!
really fun time sink that i often play while listening to podcasts. continues to see regular improvements.

after 97 hours, i think i can confidently say that it feels incomplete. the tech tree doesn't seem to flow well, there aren't clear explanations as to what things mean, i don't have a hotkey (or at least one that i could find easily) to select all of my laborers at once and have them do a task (like excavation). i enjoyed the game, but there are so many issues and missing quality of life mechanics. it feels like its still early access.

promising at the start, but very slow and little in the way of goals/progression/difficulty as you get further. can't be bothered to complete the first play through and it's just more bleh. badly thought out tech tree, raids do not work well and are not particularly challenging. i could go on.

8 hours of game play, gunna recommend the game but it needs polish. the production chains are difficult to navigate (ie viewing recources, how much iron do i have? do i have enough workers, great i have way to much now, feeling) plus the production chains arnt all that fleshed out, as well. no logisitcs ect (remote work camps but no low priority depot) combat sucks, trade hub no auto trade or search. basically the menus need work. as a gamer, im not going to lean into trade, until im self seficient, and if you wanna support the town, you need to do this, till like tier 3. farming sucks, interesting idea, but too much micro management, still aint figured out what sand and clay do.. speaking of, no tutorial. no clear idea what does what. its a over production mindset with this game. could use a que from captain of industry in this regard... graphs are cool, but whats the demand for an item? (am i producing to much of this? oh it spoiled.. oh there is rats now, well gotta pay the rat catcher, is that worth doing?) so problems aside, kill the hostile stuff, and forget the military, this a laid back city builder.. otherwise, similar to banished. fun, time killer, but def def needs some 1.0 polish.........thats why recommend no, even though it is actually pretty good.

i had been watching this game for a long while waiting for the release. and well. it's not done. town defense is garbage. you can't place archers on walls, so they just try to fire through gates until they get over run, or worse try to fight close quarters. the towers do less damage than a hunter, they're really just more of a distraction until other troops get there. a lot of the industry and resource gathering needs pretty severe reworking. getting industry to the point that you can either turn a profit or even maintain demand is nearly impossible. you are constantly out of food. the amount of people needed to make food grows to the point that it's the only thing you can do. i really would like this game if it got ironed out but it's just moderately frustrating at the moment.

it's very slow progress and if playing with raiders they are op'd in the early game and just slow down progress even more. hours of playing leads to not much advancement. feels like a bit of a waste of time.

i like the city building in this game, but they have had more than a year i think in early access and do nothing about the unit controls. worst unit controls i have ever played. you have to manually select every citizen that isn´t a soldier if you want to use them and then there is nothing more to control them. just put them in a place and then repeatedly keep them in place while trying to make them attack. i hate to give this a thumbs down because this is the only problem with the game, but this is unplayable for me.
great game, but it keeps crashing when i'm through year 4. i will recommend this game if that gets fixed.

game is okay. probably worth the money on sale, but to be honest lacks a bit of depth towards the latter part of the game. the pacing could be a bit faster, lacks a bit of qol (it's tedious to re-arrange a base), doesn't really discuss mechanics (not even in their website), there are some strange quirks (farmers from far away keep travelling between crop lots), lacks options in logistics management and clarity of which goes where and how does inventory flow across the town, doesn't discuss the production rate of buildings, bugs (flag doesn't re-appear when a barracks is destroyed). trading becomes stagnant after awhile, you just wait for the rng and check what the merchant buys or sells. economy mechanics where there is no true way to make a sustainable economy with large surpluses passively. no passive trading functionality (you have to micromanage every sale and re-stock?) the list goes on.. simply put, the game has a decent base but lacks polish for a full release game. happy to revisit the review maybe a year from now after improvements.

i love banished, so i'd love to love this game. actually, i'd love to be able to play this game. i can't though, because despite the ui scaling the fonts remain ridiculously small and unreadable on a 4k monitor and a 4k tv.

well this game do has a nice style to it but it is not particularly fun. there really is no motivation going forward, no mini quests or challenges, citizens don't come with new needs, you just build for the sake of it. the scaling is also off in the tech tree on my 4k monitor and the font is horrible. foundation for example is much more fun.

trash. villager ai is fundamentally broken, not just in response to hostiles which is well documented but even farmers and so on will mill around the field uselessly for entire seasons without doing anything. you can manually select villagers and move them around but there's no option to tell them to go back onto the ai, so they mill around for weeks before they're polled again. scaled ui actively gets in the way.

the game is actually pretty dang good. the interface, controls/hotkeys (or lack thereof), and quality of life: abysmal. after quite a few hours of enjoyment, i'm frustrated and feel insulted by the developer's lack of interest in implementing more/better hotkeys (it's not much work) or the ability to even select all villagers or control them as a group, etc. they built in these controls for military but expect you to slowly drag-select the many groups of villagers across your very large town and manually click them into place. then, they'll roam back off into raiders to die. nonsense.
total shit of a game, gets stuck when it matters and the dynamics does not work as told, dont waste your money or time
bad lag and game crashes. couldn't count how many error i had.

awesome game for the most part. but i still can't give it a positive purely because of how crappy the raiding system works , when this is fixed i will switch it to positive. the issue is: villages are suicidal, needs to micromangement them and in big cities this is extremely frustrating. easy fix is to have your townhall be able to have all villagers, garrison or make a seperation building where they can take shelter from the raiders.or let them run away quiker when raiders are nearby. plenty of ways to fix the issue.not sure why this is still not fixed considering this was also an issue in early access.
game is completely unplayable in 2560x1440, the ui scaling is abysmal and dragging the slider high enough to make text legible makes ui elements so large they feel like a mobile game.

game takes forever to load and sometimes wont load. if it loads, crashes constantly and you go through the whole process again. i love the style of the game and if it played, it would be my favorite game. steam said no refund because i played more than 2 hours (14 hrs) but over 90% of that was either waiting to load or trying to recuperate after crashing. 2 hrs is steams policy. my policy is when i pay for a game and it wont play and you wont refund, i dont buy any more games from you and i give you a lousy review. sorry, thats my policy.
optimized like shit for higher population settlements

i reached 1000 population and the game felt... done. i guess the replayability felt bit low for me, but maybe it's just my gaming style. the threat is always external (invading barbarians, barbarian camps, wild animals) - there are no other kingdoms to worry about or to do some diplomacy with. it felt like some medieval life elements were missing in order to give this game a bit more... flair. such as the ability to have a monarch, a castle, guards with the house colors, maybe some crime as the population is unhappy or hungry... you know, mechanics to enhance the medieval-inspired gameplay. but this is just my opinion, it may not be this game's ultimate goal to do any of that, and that's okay. not recommending it, however, due to the limited replayability vs current price.

this game was in early access for over 3 years and whilst they made significant improvements to the game, one of the biggest complaints was the terrain tool. they ignored all feedback and criticism regarding this for over 3 years and released the game to 1.0 with the tool in the same state as it was when they released to early access. why is the terrain tool such a big issue you may wonder resulting in my negative review and inability to enjoy the game? buildings and paths follow the terrain so if you place a building on uneven terrain, it is wonky. this is especially noticeable for the larger buildings. the last time i played the game on a mountain map, my mind broke as i realised my entire town was completely wonky made worse and more noticeable with the larger buildings and upgrades to housing. the other issue is that any ranged buildings and units get a bonus to their damage depending on the terrain height relative to their target. this means that to create proper defences, you have this incredibly tedious, unintuitive and somewhat broken tool to try and adjust the terrain heights. it's abysmal and ruins the entire game to the point that most people don't even bother playing on maps that have hills or mountains because they do not want to have to deal with this issue. i thought these devs would be good because they made grim dawn, but i was so wrong. how can you ignore so many complaints about the terrain tool and not do anything to rectify it? it's the worst implementation of a terrain tool i've ever seen in a game in my 3 decades of gaming.

i want to like this game but i find it so slow and the tech tree to be a disappointment. want your villagers to be better at defending? click a button. no experience based skill system. raiders don't make sense. raiders: let's attack that village of 50 people and hope they don't attack us back! 5 vs 50.. smart. resources don't matter, they're abundant and now matter how many trees you chop down, you'll always run out of logs but forestry is a tier 2 technology.. cause planting trees like planting crops is just a no no. i'll give this game a pass for another year i think.

farthest frontier began early access with a strong core and beautiful aesthetic, but the 1.0 release disappointingly failed to evolve beyond its "basic foundation status." the game quickly becomes dull and repetitive due to a fundamental lack of meaningful progression. the core mechanics are sound, but they do not deepen over time. maps feel monotonous, and the raiding mechanic is less of a strategic challenge and more of an annoying disruption. ultimately, the game offers a competent but shallow city-builder experience that gets boring quickly for veterans of the genre.

i genuinely like this game. i can easily invest many hours into it. i absolutely love all the graphs and stats, and how your decisions actually affect the people. you choose to distribute food, water, and other resources. the are random events too, like i had a lightning strike happen that damaged buildings, affected people, and lowered morale, which i thought was really cool. the game takes time, but the slow progression makes everything feel rewarding. overall, i thought it was enjoyable and i can't wait to progress further.

old review: "the game has been abandoned. no official updates for over a year. they took the cash and ran. yet another "early access" scam. if the developers and/or publisher provide an update that gives a reasonable degree of hope that this game isn't abandoned, i will change this review." edit - the devs have finally released an update and apology to the community. i, for one, am glad the game isn't abandoned. as promised, i've changed the review to positive. i hope they keep working on the game and make it over the finish line.

so i've been a supporter of this game since march of 2024, and i won't deny that right now the game appears to be abandoned. but at the same time what we do have for the game does roughly get to about where the "campaign" is supposed to end iirc. from what i have gathered is the devs have been working on trying to overhaul everything on the back end to run smoother, whether or not this was just a fanciful rumor i can't say, how long it should take for them to do this i also wouldn't be able to say considering i have little to no knowledge in game design, much less how big their team is. what i do know is that i the game is overall enjoyable to play, albeit rough around the edges and if that's what you like then give it a shot. as for the publisher, i wouldn't fault them for any issues arrising due to the devs, we have seen some absolute slop come out like gollum, but we've also seen games such as barotrauma. all i can say at the end of the day is if you are interested give the game a shot, it hasn't been officially declared dead by devs or publisher yet.

this game is very fun i would highly recommend this game to any one who liked frost punk and factoro so far i have had a blast even know its early on in its devemint and i cant wait for more updates to come

after just putting four hours into this game i thoroughly enjoyed it. after reading some of the reviews if the developer would have probably communicated maybe would not have such negative reviews. i complain about early access as well but to me it's like a full release. i have a 4k system it had zero problems no issues none ran smoothly no hesitation. i really had nothing bad to say about the game. it's a city builder. i like the way everything intertwines. the research tree is very large and very dependent upon what you are doing. you can't progress without it most definitely. some city builders require buildings to be next to each other or in the area close together to process items but not this game you don't have to have buildings right next to each other they really don't depend on each other that way which was different. i love that i can send out scouts and reveal the map. in order for some of that to even function properly i had to do research to a certain point which i was very far away from some of it and had a long ways to go to even get to that point, which i found to be fascinating. i had more work to do just to accomplish things that were being revealed on the map. i got the game on sale, definitely not for everyone but i think the one thing i would have liked to have seen is a variety of maps to choose from at the start. if you like city builders definitely a fun game and i do recommend.

normally i wait until i finish a game before posting a review but in this case it seemed necessary to counter some of the negative reviews spreading misinformation that have been posted lately. firstly, this game is obviously not a cash-grab. no developer puts this many years into creating a new ip of this scope and quality with all the accompanying social media channels if they are just trying to make a quick buck. also, if the negative reviewers bothered to check the discord discussions, they would learn that the game has not been abandoned. having said that, the only way any developer stays in business is by generating enough revenue to keep the lights on so i genuinely hope this game succeeds because even as the negative reviewers admit, the developers have created a solid foundation for a great game. to give some context, i purchased this game last year on the same day that i purchased manor lords. after testing both games, i refunded manor lords and kept new cycle, not because manor lords was a bad game, but because new cycle was the more polished game - it looked better, sounded better, and had far fewer bugs and mechanical problems. i plan to get manor lords once it is in better shape but people need to show patience for early access games like manor lords and new cycle that have small development teams. new cycle is already a good game with lots of potential. as such, it is certainly worth trying out and supporting if you like this genre.

about three hours in, and i’m having a good time. there are some rough edges to this game, but juggling resources, assigning workers, and laying out roads while bracing for storms is genuinely kinda fun. i’ve already had a few “oh no” moments when water or power dipped and people were at risk, and it felt great to claw things back by changing how my resources are allocated. the vibe is on point, and the loop—scramble, stabilize, expand—keeps pulling me along. with a bit more polish, this could be a great game.
fantastic gameplay. best game i have played in a while!

there was potential but developers abandoned the game, its unfinished with bugs, buyer beware. as of today 11-20-25, the developers have breathed life back into this game with an overdue but outstanding update, so with that, i have updated my recommendation for the game.

this game is not for the faint of heart. it is a punishing, deeply challenging survival builder that will test your patience and resolve. if you're looking for a gentle, hand-holding experience, this isn't it. but if you're a fan of games like frostpunk or rimworld and crave a truly brutal, unforgiving challenge, then you've found your next obsession. the core gameplay loop is incredibly tough. you are thrown into an apocalyptic world with very little guidance, and the early game is a constant struggle. the first few cycles are a desperate scramble for resources, and you will fail. a lot. but every failure is a lesson. and when you finally manage to survive and thrive, the sense of accomplishment is unlike anything else. the game's music and art style are fantastic and perfectly capture the bleak atmosphere. however, the background music can become repetitive, and the menu audio cues are sometimes inconsistent, which can break the immersion. final verdict: this game is a raw, compelling, and incredibly rewarding survival experience. it's harsh, but that's the point. it's a game about enduring against all odds, and if you're willing to embrace the challenge, you'll find a truly special game here.
if you like games that require microdecisions... this'll provide hours of decision-overload

just spent 6 hours in new cycle and i’ve officially gone from 'just one more building' to 'how did it get 3am again?' 😩🔥 game’s got that classic city builder addiction loop, but with survival stress sprinkled in. imagine banished had a love child with frostpunk, and then it watched mad max for parenting tips. yeah, it’s kinda like that. the good: ✅ building from sticks and stones to smokestacks and steel feels chef’s kiss ✅ the post-apocalyptic vibe actually makes sense and adds pressure ✅ managing resources and trying not to starve your entire population = true strategy gamer moment™ the mid: ⚖️ ui’s doing its job but not winning any awards ⚖️ tutorial? nah, figure it out like the rest of us, champ 💀 ⚖️ sometimes you stare at your screen for 10 minutes thinking “what now?” but in a good existential way the not-so-good: ❌ game stutters a bit once your city turns into a spaghetti mess ❌ some features feel half-baked (early access vibes, y’know) ❌ still no mod support so we can't replace citizens with anime characters yet smh final thoughts? it’s not perfect, but it’s got that “one more hour” energy. if you're into city builders with a side of chaos and a sprinkle of solar apocalypse, give it a shot. i’m definitely keeping my eye on future updates. 8.2/10 – would accidentally starve half my colony again."

✅ unique setting – a fresh take on the city builder genre with a post-apocalyptic sci-fi backdrop. ✅ engaging progression – satisfying development from a small settlement to an industrial metropolis. ✅ survival mechanics – adds tension and challenge beyond traditional city building. ✅ strategic gameplay – requires careful resource management and planning. ✅ visually appealing – solid visual design that fits the theme. ✅ still in development – some systems could use more polish and balance. ✅ promising future – has strong potential as updates continue. ✅ good for fans of: city builders, survival strategy, and sci-fi settings.

✅ good: unique post-apocalyptic sci-fi setting engaging city progression from small camp to industrial hub survival mechanics add meaningful tension and depth strong atmosphere and visual presentation resource management is satisfying and challenging promising updates and active development team ⚖️ neutral: pacing can feel slow in early stages but there is pacing control even pause the game! ui is functional but could be more intuitive learning curve may be steep for new players building placement sometimes feels a bit restrictive limited tutorials – trial and error is common not all features fully implemented yet ❌ bad: occasional performance issues on larger cities some mechanics feel underdeveloped or unbalanced lack of content variety in late game (so far) needs more optimization and qol features still missing some standard city-builder features no mod support (as of now)

worthy newcomer in the building/colony sim genre! this game reminds me of two classics in said genre - frostpunk and anno, and i think this game doing a good work combining mechanics from both of them. the start is smooth and surprisingly, not overwhelming, considering amount of resources available, but they introduced and used gradually, without creating a situations when bunch of them being dropped into your attention zone in the same time. the game is also not without challenge, the further you develop - the more interconected resources and buildings become, and don`t forget that you need not to forget to manage constantly growing needs of your setlers (if you want said buildings to work of course :)) i`m sure devs can make this game even more exciting in the future updates, and with that in mind, maybe in 10 years we will treat this game as one of those classics in genre, and rightfully so

i found new cycle to be a deep and engaging city builder with survival mechanics and a polished visual style, the buildings look great, and the seasons and natural disasters are very well done and not only adds to the visuals but also impacts on the gameplay mechanics. it has a lot of layers and interesting things to do, blending city builder with survival mechanics, however there are some areas that need improvement at first, i found the ui overwhelming and the controls a bit confusing, but the tutorial helps a lot and makes it easier to understand the core systems. once you get into it, the game becomes really enjoyable. my main issue is the pacing,it moves too fast between cycles, and there's often too much happening at once. also, the population system feels unbalanced, with low birth rates and limited ways to recover when workers die. that said, the game has great potential. it’s already fun for fans of complex city builders and i’m looking forward to seeing how it evolves with future updates.

recommended by a friends, it is a fun experience and i have fun playing it (it was easy mode). i feel like it would be hard to get more people at the start and in the middle i start to get overflowing people in my community. same thing with energy. it's very hard to gather energy at the start since you only have windmill for energy gathering and after you get coal generator, it's basically free electric. you can build your colony anyway you want and making it as creative as you want it. remind me of sim city 2000 from ps 1. definitely a good pick if you like city building game.

when playing new cycle in campaign easy mode, the game feels much more relaxed and forgiving. resources are easier to manage, people stay healthier, and disasters are less punishing, which gives you time to focus on building and exploring instead of constantly putting out fires. it feels more like a calm city-builder than a survival challenge, and i even managed to survive four in-game years without losing anyone, with the only deaths coming from old age rather than sickness or disaster. the only drawback is the camera movement, which feels a bit locked since you can’t rotate it with a simple right click like in most city-building games, making navigation feel clunky at times. overall it is enjoyable in this mode, but the game still has room to improve, especially in controls and adding more meaningful depth to keep players engaged longer.
love the game, hope they finish it!

it's not a bad game. it's not great at explaining game mechanics, and the ending seems very abrupt. it hurts the replay-ability of it. i feel like now that i have knowledge of the game mechanics, i could probably do better the second time, but i have zero desire to start from scratch. it'd make way more sense if (**mild spoilers**) they developed some way to continue at the end with a population that is determined by how big you built out the bunker. 16 hours to finish it, and it's frustrating because the early ending means that you have almost no time to explore the advanced building systems like the conveyor system. i have the feeling that the development team plays the game so much that they have tuned the length of the game for someone that really knows the game. good potential, but still needs work. otherwise, it's an interesting game.

i can't recommend this game in its current state and i somewhat wish i hadn't purchased it. i enjoyed learning how to play and the concept is really solid. i really like the world map and explorer building, it feels like a throwback to one of my favourite parts of frostpunk. however, there are major game breaking bugs that emerge when specific circumstances are met. for example, one of the maps available to play on (there are two currently) has a river, and you can build a bridge across the river to exploit resources on the other side. however, the bridge will never connect to your village's main road which has a major effect on the resource's productivity values. you can also build multiple bridges overtop of that bridge -- it's like the game doesn't detect it. the tier 3 kitchen is less efficient than the tier 2 kitchen. with multiple users noting a recent lack of engagement from the devs in the community discussion forums (some claiming abandonware), there is no telling when, or even if, these issues might be fixed. that said, this game does have the potential to be something really great. i hope they don't give up on it.

finally downloaded and played the game after a year + of it being in early access. friend gifted it to me for my b-day. opened it up, started a new game in tutorial mode. went to go lay down my town and explore the area but wasd is so slow i can barely move. go to click and drag the map as you do in any game with a mini-map to move around, but it.... drags the mini-map itself to a new location? then i click on the terrain to go somewhere, and the camera zips across the map and i can't find where i was. i finally decide somewhere to lay down my town and the camera decides its going to zip again. i didn't click anything. its clearly a bug. alt + f4 and uninstall. will try again in a year.

the game is a bit flat and boring. you are often locked behind tech that needs to be unlocked in order to build things you have already researched. wind turbines produce 30 power on a good position and most buildings need 100+, so its a wind turbine building game. new request comes faster than you can complete the previous ones. the graphic is nice and world seems good. the game just lack good game-play. maybe in a year or two if its out of early access ill give it another go, but as is, i would not recommend this game.

the gameplay loop isn't very engaging currently. researching isn't particularly fun, i would have enjoyed a proper research tree instead of just bulk unlocking things in the current manner. not being able to queue up research is a pain as well, so you have to remember what the material requirements are for the research and then manually go in and queue it up when you have everything. overall though you just feel very disconnected from the citizen. you need to manually go in and check up on morale constantly, because there's no indicator on the main display. it's no apparent what the morale sinks are, since before their morale was perfect and suddenly it's going down. even though they are all fed, have health care, roof over their head etc. in it's current state it's just on the boring side for me so it's a "no" for now

[b]kamgusta's mini review[/b] the card rogue-lite everyone talks about. i understand why it's so popular, as almost everybody knows how to play cards and make a "double", a "three of a kind" or a "flush". runs are also quite short and the high randomness makes all of them quite different. as a roguelike and/or deck-building game, it has big flaws: you aren't in full control of your deck (uncertainty and randomness are unavoidable) and the stacking of bonuses ([b]+[/b]chip, [b]+[/b]multi, [b]x[/b]multi) should have been clearer and better balanced. you can get to the point where a single card (a "high") scores more than a "royal flush", erasing all the fun of a card game. game also lacks meta-progression, you just unlock more bonuses to be find on your runs. runs are too short to build your deck or create long-term strategies - you are forced to just hope for good cards and push your luck. best strategies focus only on gaining a lot of money to be able to reroll and trying to get (pray the rng god) that couple uber bonuses. for all those reasons, it's not the masterpiece some people talks about and i only recommend it for casual players (in that case, add +2 to the score). it is what it is: a casual, short-lenght, mobile game. [b]best played with mouse recommended buy price: 5$ score: 5,5/10[/b]

what can i say? i want to like it. i really do. there are parts of it i do actually enjoy. but overall, this is very much not the game for me. act 1 had me hooked. act 2 had me slightly annoyed. act 3 was bad enough i had to mod it to finish it. the camera is a fucking nightmare, the combat feels like a slog through molasses, the rng definetly favors the enemies. the fact i had to do almost two hours of prep work and research to make it through one large combat encounter, on explorer mode, broke me. i played d&d 5e for awhile before i started bg3, and while i do enjoy the world building and the roleplaying aspects for the most part, the combat is honestly the worst part of this game. theres literally no justifiable reason my entire beefed up squad with meta gear and stats should struggle with a group of lizard people, on the games easiest difficulty. the only workaround ive found that takes the combat from nearly an hour per conflict (obviously dependant on size of enemy group) is to cheese the shit out of items and set up a trap guantlet before starting the combat. which, if i was playing on hard or above, i could respect. but i wasnt. overall, bg3 had great potential for being one of the better games ive played, but quality of life and combat/balancing issues abound doesnt make me want to play this game ever again. finishing it felt like a chore and frankly thats just not fun.

as a lover of turn-based strategy and tabletop d&d i really don't see the appeal of this game. what is hyped and praised as a thrilling action-packed campaign in reality is a boring, horrible-paced slog with zero replayability and variation. after act one the quality drops off a cliff and just feels bloated. it's all window-dressing, every choice eventually leads to the same outcome. no, really. try and avoid shadowheart at the start of the game, see how often they thrust her into your path before the game just gives up and drops her magical macguffin into your bag with zero explanation. want to be evil? you'll still fight the same enemies and go to the same places just with less help. the dice rolls outside of combat only feel like they exist to decide if you'll be inconvenienced or not, and these become worse on subsequent playthroughs when you know what you'll lose should you fail. this game is a perfect example of why i don't listen to public opinion on what a good game is, as they'd rather insist that you should like it when in fact a lot of the time you might only like it because it's popular.

age of empires ii is one of the best strategy games i have ever played. the game lets you build your own medieval kingdom, manage resources, and lead armies into battle. you can play in many different ways: relax and focus on building, enjoy story campaigns that teach real history, or play fast and competitive matches against other players or the ai. the game has many unique civilizations, each with its own units and bonuses. the balance is very good, so every strategy can work if you plan well. it always feels exciting to grow your economy, train your army, and fight for victory. even after many years, the game is still active and always improving. i keep coming back to it because every match feels different. if you like strategy and thinking ahead, i can strongly recommend this game. a true classic that still shines today.

one of those rare games that never gets old. age of empires ii is truly timeless, and it feels like we’ll keep coming back to it for many years. the definitive edition only makes it smoother, prettier, and even more addictive.

this game is hands down one of the best rtss in existence. it's hard to really express how well throughout and built this game is. this game being 26 years old at the time of this review and still being extremely playable is a huge accomplishment. in some ways this game is even better than age of empires 4 which i have played more(via steam anyway). the campaign section of this game is one of the best of any rts ever. the historical accuracy and the breath of historical eras covered is phenomenal. the fact that this game still gets dlcs today is incredible. this will be one of the very few games i will continue to play throughout my life. you don't have to be perfect or super skilled to enjoy this game (you may want to avoid multiplayer until you've done some hard campaign missions..). there are many ways to have fun with aoe2 and once you're hooked you'll be back again and again. i 100% recommend this game its in the top 5 of my favorite games ever.

what is there to review? age of empires 2 is among the reasons the rts genre exists. it is a hallmark of video game history, and this is truly the definitive edition of it. it's immaculately balanced, it looks gorgeous and it just feels nice to play. there's content for people who play it casually, as well as professionally, and i doubt that its popularity will fade in the next 100 years.

one of the greatest, if not the greatest rts game of all time. after 25 years this game still consistently has active player counts between 10k-20k, thanks to the incredible work done by the devs on this definitive edition and the timeless gameplay (build a base and an army and destroy the enemy's base), which is intuitive yet deeply rich and replayable. of course, there are countless rts games that have the same gameplay loop but none execute them quite as well as aoe 2. the community is also great and pro tournaments are very fun to watch. this game deserves more players and more money.

what kills this game is how utterly broken the ai is in skirmish, not because it's complex, but because it follows a micro perfect build order that follows only the highest of skilled players. the ai is not fun to fight, always beating you to every age and instantly producing units based on counter the split second it sees your units. this isn't good ai, it's near inhuman cheating. is this how we are with games ai now? lazy and just train it off competitive multiplayer? the ai knows nothing but to rush castle/imperial and just spam out units that they counter you with. they aren't even coded to build walls, completely incapable of doing anything surprising. you can say skill issue all you want, but if you have to follow a competitive multiplayer build order just to beat the basic standard ai then it was never good to begin with. the devs claim the ai doesn't cheat on the de but i'm somewhat convinced they broke it and gave the ai cheats for the sake of "difficulty." at the minimum it does have fog of war cheats...

age of empires 2 is great if you enjoy competitive micro-optimization and memorizing timings like a robot… but if you want something with substance, where “thinking like a general” actually matters and has some historical consistency, it’s a disappointment. also, “definitive editions” should actually be definitive — not a base for endless dlcs designed to squeeze as much money as possible with minimal effort. as someone without nostalgia goggles, i deeply regret this purchase.

isaac and his mother lived alone in a small house on a hill. isaac kept to himself - drawing pictures and playing with his toys as his mom watched christian broadcasts on the television. life was simple and they were both happy. that was, until the day isaac's mom heard a voice from above. "your son has become corrupted by sin. he needs to be saved." "i will do my best to save him, my lord," isaac's mother replied, rushing into isaac's room, removing all that was evil from his life. again, the voice called to her. "isaac's soul is still corrupt. he needs to be cut off from all that is evil in this world and confess his sins." "i will follow your instructions, lord. i have faith in thee," isaac's mother replied, as she locked isaac in his room away from the evils of the world. one last time, isaac's mom heard the voice of god calling to her. "you've done as i've asked, but i still question your devotion to me. to prove your faith, i will ask one more thing of you." "yes, lord. anything," isaac's mother begged. "to prove your love and devotion, i require a sacrifice. your son, isaac, will be this sacrifice. go into his room and end his life, as an offering to me to prove you love me above all else." "yes, lord," she replied, grabbing a butcher's knife from the kitchen. isaac, watching through a crack in his door, trembled in fear. scrambling around his room to find a hiding place, he noticed a trapdoor to the basement, hidden under his rug. without hesitation, he flung open the hatch, just as his mother burst through his door, and threw himself down into the unknown depths below.

i played the game long enough that i 100%ed it for all the achievements, which isn't something i do often so it must be doing something right! it's certainly addictive, with great style and gameplay. i like the strategic side of it and there's decent enemy variety (although i'd like more). the game hides far too much information. if my stats are changing throughout a round, why can't i see them as they change? my damage increases in line with the dragon but i have no idea how much damage the dragon does and how much it increases my damage. why can't i look at the synergies screen or my current abilities while choosing new abilities? it makes it very frustrating to optimise my build and understand which abilities are good or bad. there is good fun gameplay variety with the number of weapons, characters and abilities. i was surprised how much i enjoyed the different weapons and how much they could change your strategy. i do think there is a huge balance issue. some guns and abilities are incredibly powerful, must picks on every run while others are really weak. the three different builds are essentially guns, summons or elements, but elements is pretty bad on its own and fire is especially weak. you're better off going guns or summons and supplementing with frost (or some lightning). going full damage is far more sensible than going defensive, especially in higher difficulties where enemies hit harder. a good way to pass the time, and ideal for short play sessions. i'd rank it as better than vampire survivors but it falls far short of the lofty heights of brotato.

this game is really dope. after a couple of play throughs, where you get to grips with the mechanics, the small tricks you can do (like baiting the large exploding enemies into bombing everyone by running close then backing up as a method of crowd control), the game isn't too tough to master. but i appreciate the fact that it puts the power fantasy first and makes it more accessible and less reliant on rng. it also helps that the game encourages experimenting with builds by having 15 unlockable difficulty levels and a huge cast of unlockable characters and weapons that become absolutely busted when you take advantage of their perks through the upgrades you choose. each weapon is distinct; the smg rocks for elemental builds, while the shotgun is great for crowd control and skills based around reloading. meanwhile the batgun benefits from being buffed by both regular and summon attack buffs, so you can create an army of summons that decimate everything. there are several key skills to buff, like base attack, health, movement speed, as well as bonuses to your guns like elemental damage and other effects. so even if you can't get a skill you want to mainline, there's still pretty much always going to be something you can pick that will help you in the long run. and all the fun is from breaking the game. there are infinite ammo builds, summon builds, multiple elemental combination builds (like one where, when lightning strikes a flaming enemy, they explode), and more based around the individual skills of the characters. played properly, your screen will be a crazy mess by the end and you will have transcended mortality into a crazy kind of godhood. it's a total blast to mess around with.

for $7.50aud this is a really comfy game. i managed to get a solid 20ish hours of enjoyment out of it, and as of writing this review have 100%'d the achievements. what i liked: - immaculate vibes. - i loved the sprite work of the characters, enemies, and summons. - once you've gotten the hang of the game most runs feel unloseable, you'll find a way to build your character within the first five level-ups. - a varied roster of 12 characters with their own unique upgrades following boss-kills. - a standard winning run takes around 25 minutes including time spent paused choosing upgrades, making it a good wind-down game if you're time-poor like me. - meta-progression in the form of runes, which provide upgrades to your stats, and character and weapon unlocks. what i disliked: - the runs can feel very samey after a while, as you're heavily encouraged to lean into your characters 'class'. - this is especially prevalent with the summoner classes, which can honestly be played by standing still for 80% of the game with some minor dodging required when bosses appear. - some rune choices have what is obviously the best-in-slot, and there's nothing encouraging you from changing the runes between runs. - some characters are definitely stronger than others. as an example dasher spends approximately half of your run in their invulnerable deer form which scales with summon damage, which is already the strongest build in the game in my opinion. overall i recommend this game. if you're a fan of vampire survivors or brotato this will slot neatly into your library, and at its current price you'll find that it has great value for money.

it's a decently fun little time killer of a game, 5 dollar price tag feels a bit iffy to me personally though, plus the dev has been radio silent on this game for almost a year at this point, with the last bit of information being about their new game they're working on. there's not a ton of depth to this game and it can pretty quickly become repetitive, just falling into the same gameplay loop over and over and over again, but it's still a decent game regardless. if you've got 5 bucks you're looking to burn then there's nothing wrong with burnin' 'em on this, it's a solid 6/10 game

i've seen this story before: [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/671860/battlebit_remastered]battlebit[/url], [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/767810/tiny_rails/]tiny rails[/url], and, ironically, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/2488510/fatalzone]fatalzone[/url] [i](this one is survivors clone as well, got randomly released as 1.0 and threw away all the good will with crappy (lack of) updates)[/i] a small game goes viral, catches lightning in a bottle, then moves on (usually to a more “profitable” mobile version). can’t blame devs for chasing success, but you can still feel disappointed when the original gets left behind. [b]20 minutes till dawn[/b] is one of those cases. it’s stylish, it’s fun, the pixel-art gun-girls blasting lovecraftian horrors still hit that dopamine spot — but it’s also unfinished, buggy, and clearly abandoned. you can almost see the potential it once had (there is literal roadmap or dev plans in the main menu xd). if you want a polished [b]bullet heaven[/b](?), grab the og [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1794680/vampire_survivors]vampire survivors[/url]. if you’ve beaten that, try [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/2218750/halls_of_torment]halls of torment[/url]. and if you’re after something niche and full of promise, like 20mtd once was, check out [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/2283940/ancient_guardians_the_dragon]ancient guardians: the dragon[/url].

basically abandoned while still buggy. no way to adjust necessary input settings like dead zones, leading to very twitchy and unpleasant controls. no way to set autofire, so i hope you like pushing a button the whole time. it is fun, though. just wish it weren't abandoned.

as someone who has spent far too much time in bullet heavens, this is one of my favorites. the dev appears to have moved on to their next project, however the last post on steam is from nearly a year ago (345 days to be precise) with a promise of new content “soon”. radio silence since. the excitement has long since died out, replaced by disappointment. definitely worth a play if you enjoy the genre, but don’t expect any new content “soon”. https://store.steampowered.com/news/app/1966900/view/4538032056440979676?l=english

it's not a bad game. gameplay is fun, art is nice etc (tho anatomy is weird lmao). what is lacking is a progression system. you just get a generic resource that you use to unlock characters, weapons, and a very limited small skill tree. so i don't feel too much like coming back to it compared to other "survivors/bullet heaven/whatever" games. i guess this is a mixed review.
very shallow pool of upgrades, meta upgrades and enemies, it gets old very fast
this is just vampire survivors with extra steps.

unbalanced, tedious, visually unclear. visual clutter is the biggest problem of this game. it's good that this game was released, giving new ideas to other developers of the same game genre, but it's hardly an enjoyable piece of cake. there is nothing bad in trying this game out tho. i noticed there are only three basic archetypes: gunner, elementalist, summoner and usually you will need perks of all of them in any single run, otherwise it would be hardly a viable build. no distinguishable defensive/aoe/close combat builds. metaprogression feels useful only in the most hard to get perks, expect 10 hours of grind before you will start to benefit from it. very scarce variety of enemies. no working controller support.
i don't actually dislike the game. it's just that there are so many other games that did it better.......sorry guys.

worth the money for a bullet hell. however it's good design and color identity is one if it's biggest downfalls; it lacks the clarity to tell what is a damaging vs friendly projectile when there is already so much on the screen. fun to reach max darkness and get all the achievements but no point really to play past that. also weapons/characters seem extremely unbalanced and appears the dev has moved on to another project and is no longer updating this game.

it's almost a good game. one of the main problems i have is that it's very hard if you're new, but trivial once you get past that point. you have lives, and if you get clipped by one tiny thing, that's a life gone. compare it to another game, say vampire survivors, you'll lose a small amount of health if you get hit by something, and a lot more if you're actively swarmed. but once you understand the game, you almost never get hit. add to that the game has become a lot easier with the later updates, it becomes somewhat trivial and not very satisfying to beat. the developer also seems to have abandoned the game to work on other projects without leaving this in a finished place.

seems to have weird issues on deck with the controls. i'm also not really a fan of how samey a lot of stuff looks in this game. i'd get jump scared by my dragon egg, believing its a standard enemy, and would make a lot of mistakes because of this. perhaps also maybe a fault in expectations, i was expecting this to be more a survivor style game, but its really more bullet hell. you'll very much need to be twin sticking this a lot, and that style of play doesn't feel great on deck. i'm sure plenty of people like it for what it is, but its a pass from me.

gameplay loop gets boring fast. a few potential causes: new weapons and characters all cost the same amount and none are necessarily better than others making loadouts relatively pointless; in-game upgrades struggle to build off of each other, and even when they do, there is no variability between levels or weapons; there's something like 10 enemy sprites total in the entire game; levels/maps have little defining qualities... the list gets more semantic but i guess the point is that the re-playability is boring and repetitive. otherwise, the music and art is cool. worth somewhere in the ballpark of 3 dollars, buy it on sale.

one of the best precision platformers i have ever played! you are playing a character that is having a physical and emotional journey while climbing the celeste mountain. it is trying to give you interesting and meaningful concepts while climbing (e.g anxiety, mental health, self-doubt, self acceptance, depression etc) and the character is trying to face/accept/embrace them. the music was sooo beautiful and its difficulty was solid if you want to finish it casually. however, the game gives you the opportunity to play optional stages where their difficulty skyrockets a little bit because it focuses more on precision and consistency. one last thing..... a lot of stages will be challenging but none of them are speedrunning/frame perfect ones. in other words, no matter the deaths, keep trying and you will make it. this is what celeste is all about.

game is okay but not anything super special, it focuses too much on the precision part of precision platformer, which makes most of its challenges blur together in terms of feel despite there being a lot of variety in level design on paper. the progression of the game is also quite bizarre, where a large swathe of the level challenges are made purely optional to collect strawberries, a collectable that is there absolutely for bragging rights. i am all for intrinsic motivation in games, but what this ended up leading too is a lack of forward progression in levels. you either go for most collectables, in which case you will be stuck going to alternate rooms to do many of these mini challenges, dragging the pace to a halt, or just ignore them all, and get super short levels that don't feel as though they fully flesh out their respective level gimmicks. this isn't like new super mario bros, where star coins are used to unlock content in the overworld and are placed mostly en route to your objective, which lead to them being useful to collect, without repercussing the pace of the game, yet not making the levels feel hollow if you decide to ignore them. thus the inclusion of these collectables and their impact on the level design ended up taking a lot of the bite out of the progression in the game. aside from that the story is poorly integrated into the game with middling dialogue quality and i found the soundtrack to be the typical retro ost you hear in these kinds of games without much in it to separate it from what you hear elsewhere. also the game will sometimes heavily lag-spike on steam deck, and that sucks.

i really don't think the developer tested whole session with joystick(xbox), the direction of air dash is always unpredictable which is fatal to my experience. beware overwhelmingly positive doesn't mean it's perfect.

the actual game is amazing. i love the story, and the platforming feels rewarding... but the side content alone is enough to make me feel like the game isn't worth it. hard games are my bread and butter. platformers especially. i love putting my face against the grindstone in order to conquer a challenge, but this is the only game i've ever played where i felt completely apathetic to the challenge mode. the b-sides are totally worthless. not only is the game already unforgiving in only the places it shouldn't be, (absurdly precise hitboxes on level mechanics but large and imprecise hitboxes for spikes, even though it is only a few pixels,) but i feel completely unrewarded for conquering them anyways. sure, it means i can access chapter 9, but i can do that without them too with a mechanic the game literally teaches you before that cutoff point. it's a good game overall, but i can't recommend it in good faith since only the main game feels like it rewards you in any way. 5/10.

easily one of the best games of the last decade, if not the best overall. soundtrack is incredible, storytelling is incredible, art direction and world design are incredible, characters are lovable, enemies are interesting, gameplay is engaging. it never felt too repetitive and there's plenty of tools at your disposal to keep the gameplay fresh, and each playable character has a very unique and charming playstyle that suits their personality and design. if you haven't played this yet you're missing out. if you have played this, the bar for all games in the future has been set extremely high, considering a small aa studio created something that is essentially a masterpiece. there are a few areas where you could tell they wanted to do more but ran out of funding or time, but the game still feels complete regardless and i look forward to any future content (the upcoming "bonus" update) and any future games in the clair obscur universe.

originally completed this game on gamepass before purchasing on steam. this game is a work of art that managed to ressurrect my interest in gaming. truly original in concept, great storytelling, and turn based combat that flawlessly evolves the formula. the soundtrack is unreal. 10/10 game and a must play. this is the kind of game that sticks with you for awhile. the characters, beautifully crafted world, and soundtrack will leave their mark.

the amount of emotional damage this game causes is not worth it. reminds me of the books you have to read in school and everytime it's a drama. because comedy was seemed not worth it, to be written down back in 1800 or 1900, so they took tradgedy, like in this game. it has a parallel to the real world, we flee into things, to forget and what happened and be happy in this new world, we fled into. but we can't stay infinite time in that dream world and have to come back to reality. this is kinda depressing and true. the game battle mechanics reminded me of the southpark games "stick of truth" and the second one. great soundtrack, the only issue for me is, they didn't implement some bonus tracks on the digital soundtrack edition on steam. songs like "for those who come after" and i think "our painted death" are missing. one funny spoiler is, if you dress your whole team in a bathing suit, then "renoir" is also wearing one bathing suit in his cut scenes. not sure if he is weaing it in fight too. theg game looks pretty in most scenes, has a great story, can be complicated to understand. some minor ugly things can be the world you travel around. the world map looked sometimes not properly scaled, which changes if you recieve your big helper to move around. great characters to discover. the music is just awesome in it. thx for the game, stop emotionally abuse your customers. i hope you create another great game.

sadly a case of extremely overhyped. i was really excited to play this game after all the reviews but honestly for me it's a huge letdown. the story completely drops after act 2 (not getting into spoilers) and the whole dodge/parry is incredibly annoying mid to late game! have fun pushing the parry button 15x in a row because enemies can have combos that long... also the dodge/parry can be extremely wonky! the game is good but it's not nearly as amazing as the hype says.

the volley ball game is comparable to the racing game in mafia. how devs can justify wasting someone's time with the most unfair, rng based bullshit is beyond me. the entirety of it relies not on you being good, but the everything else weighing you down so heavily that it takes you forever to complete. it took 45min to turn such a great experience and sour the shit out of it. congrats to the fool who thought it up and the bigger fools who left it in the game, you won a negative review. hopefully by the time the game ends, it'll have washed the shit taste from my mouth and i'll change it to a positive.

great game but giving negative review for lousy pc implementation: - on my machine (rtx 3070) the fog was so dense that it was unplayable (youtube videos have much less fog so it is somehow hardware and settings depending). they do not have a setting i found which reduced the fog significantly so i had to fix it in the .ini file (google how to) - key bindings are not great and frustratingly, some keys cannot be changed. and these were the most used combat keys like one key of asd as well as esc key. pressing esc every time after aiming is just horrible experience. what were they thinking? did any developer play the game on pc? - game heavily depends on dodging and parrying but on my pc it was nearly impossible to do so effectively due to input lag and stuttering. hope they can update this quickly. plus, there is a lot of potential in exploring the psychosocial and economical effects of the gommage in lumiere (e.g. recklessness of people when they know they will die very soon, maybe in a future dlc?)

i'm really enjoying this game, actually. good acting, beautiful designs, interesting story, satisfying combat, and more. however, i'm giving it a thumbs down because of the lack of a map. i cannot believe this game, inspired by so many digital role-playing games, doesn't include any sort of map, which has existed in this genre forever. it even fits the theme and story. i'm pretty sure these expeditioners would take notes and make maps as they go through these labyrinths, no? if the game were strictly linear, i wouldn’t have minded, but a good portion of it is about exploration, and you never know if you're going the way that will progress the story and trigger a cutscene, or if you're finding a side path with optional enemies and items, or if you're just circling around aimlessly. the exploration right now is honestly so excruciating, and it feels even worse because i genuinely want to find everything, but without a map i'm having so much difficulty. sometimes i just prefer to move forward because i have no idea if i've missed anything or not.

weird graphical issues everywhere (grainy/ant shadows, black artifacts in hair, inconsistent fog), black cutscenes with just music, clipping in every dialogue interaction, wooden dialogue line transitions, horrible audio mixing, combat and cutscene music is about twice as loud as everything else, some cutscenes seem to be 720p stretched to my resolution... and all this in an hour of gameplay. feels like i'm not playing the same game as everyone else.

i've had it with this game after years of repetitive gameplay. i find myself playing the same campaign with a slightly different coat time and time again. both wide and tall playthroughs i find myself ending the game within a generation or two of achieving the main goal of my campaign. the occasional decent dlc paradox drops usually adds only few hours of decent content before i feel i'm playing my average cornwall or bohemia playthrough with a new coat. it's been five years and paradox is still filling the void that is crusader kings 3 with overpriced dlc's. this game offers little to no late game content other than fighting the mongol empire or forming a hegemony. the release of various new governments has resulted in the five base game governments to be forgotten and never expanded upon. maybe paradox will one day finish this game, but it will likely take several years of extra dlc before they finally retire this game and release another empty crusader kings entry. i personally don't see myself playing this game again even when that day comes, because it is has already been way too long since this game's release for it not to be finished.

this was my first ck and i found it honestly terrible: the war mechanics are way too simple as well as the economy. the activities are boring, unrealistic and pointless. the whole relationship with vassals is very weird, and i am pretty sure not historically accurate.

i tried really hard (52 hours) to learn the game, and i kept failing at it. it was a constant barrage of new rules. i found playing with gemini on the side was necessary for me to understand how to get out of tricky situations. and even with this extra help it didn't work out for me. sometimes i felt in control, to find out 20 minutes later that my lineage was gone and i had no way to carry on. other times i went through what felt like a never ending war, not winning nor losing for hours (playing at standard speed). i lost some battles that were predicted as guaranteed wins, and vice versa. still no idea why. it feels appealing when one finally understands a bit of the game mecanics. but too many times the game smashed my face into the ground and i didn't have a clue why. sorry, not for me!

on 7950x3d, 4070 ti super, 64 gb ram you do will experience slideshow, 5 fps, input lag, because this awesome game is written in a way that can't handle more than 1 cpu core and everything is binded in a single thread, so unless you have quantum cpu - stay away from it.

don't get me wrong, ck3 has its fun moments, but it has one massive, underlying issue: it's a combination grand strategy game and life sim. because of this, it never really is able to be a good version of either. it's strategy components are puddle deep and easily exploitable. warfare amounts to building centralized military in the 800s, and because the ai can't think strategically, you just steamroll everything that hasn't been over-buffed by the devs (like the mongols). the roleplaying elements have a shelf life because everything is handled through events, you play through menus so you can only be given character moments through text, and because its all random events that have been pre-written there`s a distinct lack of character for your characters. several of the game's systems have also just been left to rot completely. i don't even need to list them here because almost every game system has just been neglected. devs are focused on adding new content, which is fine, but surely you can hire a new team to update and upkeep the old content? stellaris is actually a great example of this working. (despite that game's current issues.) unfortunately i just don't think you should play ck3. if you want a good grand strategy game, play eu4 or hoi4 or even vic3. heck, go play imperator: rome. it's very underrated and managed to have characters included in a way that wasn't game defining. if you want to roleplay, go play kingdom come or manor lords. ck3 is an unhappy marriage of two genres and it need to split, one way or the other.

the game itself it's pretty cool. you can literally marry your sister, your stepfather meanwhile you screw your own father. but the dlcs are very predatory and covered with hidden mechanics that are very hard to predict. you almost need to be with an excel on your side to try to play this and win in normal mode sometimes. there will be times where your 10k army will be anyhilated by a 3k one and you will be there scratching your head like... what? yeah... commander crap, plus terrain features and things will make everything harder. sometimes it's hard to have fun.
