it's inevitable that this is going to be compared to baldur's gate 3, so i might as well frame my entire opinion around that comparison. the combat in this game is much more interesting than in bg3 - the action point system gives you a lot more freedom and cultivates interesting choices almost constantly. a big advantage over the very rigid actions offered in bg3. the writing in this game is severely inferior than bg3. many characters are just grating to interact with, and will routinely harass or otherwise disrespect your character/party and there's never any options to tell them off, let alone start a fight over it. these npc are just annoying to interact with and the game forces you to roll over and take it so you can complete the main quest. what a joke. whoever replaced the head writer for bg3 made the right choice.
tried really hard to like this but it just isn't for me. way too slow

mix feeling. great to be back in d&d environment and this game is taking a lot care on getting it right, but - party-management is a desaster. you need to constantly split them to ensure they are not blocking each other - close combat feels always off and massivly weaker than range - personally i do not like most of the playable characters (play style) - the overall story is not my thing
crap the studio is woke crap etc etc

if the game wasn't crashing so much i would definitely recommend it however at the moment it is crashing more often then not so until there's an update, i wouldn't recommend anyone wasting their money

i would love to give this game a very positive review. the actual content in the game is wonderfully built and very fun to play. but it won't work for me. i crash constantly, either loading into the front menu or into the game itself. if i save, i crash. i have tried everything under the sun to fix this because i really enjoy the experience when i get to play. i have: verified game files, put it in windowed mode, run the .exe as administrator and put it in compatibility mode, taken all overlays off of the game, disabled 3d settings, deleted all save files, deleted config files (for re-downloading), fully wiped all data from the game and re-downloaded, updated my graphics driver, turned auto-save off, have nothing running in the background while playing, disabled cloud saves. nothing has worked. it is so disappointing, especially coming from the relatively stable bg3. i hope that it is fixed but i doubt it will be.

so far ive encountered in the first area no way to progress, i have spoken to every npc extensively and the only "ways out" are though combat encounters that just are not possible on normal difficulty with my full party with all of the gear i could find. so unless there is some sort of you practically have to use x build or obscure nonsense it just waits until after the refund window to just stop you.
just a bit too clunky.
don't understand the hype, was really boring, couldn't get past 3 hours into the game cuz i was just so checked out.

not enjoying the combat system. it's doable but i don't enjoy how it creates challenge. for example pre-positioning enemies in good positions and clumping up the party (when the fight happens on a new map), setting them them up to get blasted before they can do anything. or, just making enemies far stronger than the party members, forcing you to figure out what areas to avoid by dying and reloading. the game does a poor job explaining how things work. you get a lot of options and variables without context, and you need to pick wisely or suck. it all results in having to google how things work, and meta-gaming before fights, which is detrimental to the immersion. also, the game world is supremely bleak and depressing; i don't need a game for that.
dont like it ! ! ! ! !
game is super boring with poor graphics and boring as hell game play! a definite no buy even with being on sale at time of this review....boring!!!!

i essentially had to force myself to get to the end of this game, after owning it for years and restarting it repeatedly. it's gorgeous, d:os1 is one of my favorite games, and i was so excited to play the hero characters and experience their storylines, but playing this game was [b]tedious[/b]. several puzzles were so nonsensical and presented so blankly that i (like many other players, it seems) kept having to go online just to figure out what i was supposed to do... which ended up making the puzzles boring. same with a lot of the combat (one of my favorite parts of d:os1) - there's giving players a satisfying challenge, and then there's forcing the player to slog through endless tedium. this was unfortunately the latter. the ending...oof. i chose the option i thought was best, and it ended up being cynical and depressing. looking online, it sounds like the other endings aren't any better. the epilogue was dull as dirt and droned on for way too long. i can't even say "well, i'm glad i finished it at least". it just wasn't fun. huge bummer. guess i'll go replay d:os1 again.

really good act 1, but pacing problems happen from act 2 onwards. also the puzzles are pretty absurd and made me stop playing blind. i thought it was ok, especially after getting it on sale. however, i can't reccomend it to the majority of people.
in act 2 now but playing feels like a chore. my gear and my enemies are higher level than me. the game doesn't feel well paced.

a french themed souls-like with pretty fun fighting mechanics and an interesting setting. i appreciate that the game doesn't try to drag itself out for too long, but there's still content that i left untouched because navigating the maps felt overwhelming at the end trying to remember where the locations were and how to get there. also a small nitpick but i wish it was all voiced in french with english subtitles, they sprinkle in french words here and there but for better immersion i wish the default was french. overall, no complaints. as always, wait for a sale but definitely worth picking up and trying out.
it is a great souls like game, i am having a great time playing.

decent soulslike, easier than most though, pretty repetitive, some glitches that just freeze the game and force quit due to janky interactions with boxes or other various geography as you dash over/through them. overall, not bad but not a ng+ contender. deep sale purchase and blow through it.
this is a fun game if you just want to explore and enjoy playing a game, its a different take on soulslike type of game but different is good, 10/10

a bit hard to recommend, but still i enjoyed my time with it. not a lot of enemy variety, even less variety with weapons, too much dialogue and the game is overall too easy (and this is coming from someone who's not that good at soulslikes) however, tha artstyle and general atmosphere looks great, combat was satisfying and i do think the game did plenty to be unique and interesting to the very end. next time, make it a little shorter and add more variety
just a pretty good game

unique and thrilling! steelrising offers a fresh take on the soulslike genre with its stunning parisian setting and fluid combat. aegis is a fantastic protagonist, and the mechanical enemies are both creepy and cool. definitely worth playing!
not the brightest bulb on stage, but a needed refresh from the usual american based ideas

a solid soulslike set during the french revolution, taking you on a journey from the storming of the bastille to versailles. the game incorporates metroidvania-style progression, with new abilities unlocking as you go, encouraging backtracking and exploration of earlier areas. later sections can be quite challenging, as the distance between "bonfires" increases and healing options remain limited, making each run feel tense and demanding. the game’s main drawbacks are the underwhelming boss fights, even some regular enemies pose more of a threat as well as the general lack of enemy variety. still, it’s a well-paced experience that doesn’t drag on too much.

it's dark soul style, with hard battles and where death is harsh. however, i really appreciate that the game designers knew not everyone would want to play that style and gave the player the choice. you can enable assist that allow you to adjust the game to your style. the game is beautiful by the way. i also loved that even though you're following a pathways, there plenty of exploration to do. my one negative about this game is the map. they needed better maps of the cities. the compass is helpful but when going back for breakable doors and secrets, not so much.
it´s like lies of p, on a budget and not as difficult. it was cool, the bosses could´ve been better - a strong 7

great game. although it falls under the soulslike genre, this title is one of the more accessible options - making it a good starting point for newcomers. the storytelling leans heavily into psychological thriller territory. there are no jump scares, but certain moments - and the eventual realization of what’s really happening - can be genuinely unsettling, even goosebump-inducing, due to how disturbing the narrative becomes. there is a known optimization issue related specifically to vertical synchronization; simply disabling v-sync resolves the problem. the visuals are stunning - i played with a mix of high and epic settings. overall, it's well worth picking up, especially on sale. i had a great time, and achieving 100% completion felt rewarding rather than tedious.
absolutely amazing game, highly recommended. the fighting is fluid and dancelike if you use a lighter weapon. the story is great and the graphics are amazing. 10/10

*steel rising* isn’t revolutionary, but it’s a solid improvement on the action-rpg formula. the story is fine (3 endings + a dlc that feels more like a side quest), but the real highlight is the **world-building and map design**. the 7 regions are interconnected and layered in a way that makes exploration rewarding and atmospheric. gameplay is fun enough — good weapon variety, decent armor sets (though less important than in other games), plus grenades and elemental resistances for combat variety. i personally liked the anima farming armor since leveling past 40 becomes a grind. graphics are beautiful, but note that full textures at 1440p require **10gb for high** and **13gb for ultra**. **critics/bugs:** * after finishing the game, you *cannot return to your save*, which means no dlc access unless you start ng+. * ng+ gives you duplicate weapons/armors instead of replacing old ones — clutter and pointless selling. * store bug: oil burette can’t be upgraded past 5 doses / ~340 hp. materials for upgrades in ng+ are a trap and waste anima. store also sells items you already own. **overall:** with bugs and flaws → **5/10**. fixed/patched → easily **8/10**.

only 1 problem with the game is the fps performance is too bad to get 90 fps on max settings for my pc it should be 200+ fps is okay i still love the game is very nice souls like game and for all hunters is a easy game to 100% <3

oui, est trés bien, j'aime cette game :) sometimes the animations for enemies just stop and they have to "power up again", otherwise i like it, i'm having a hard time defeating the small bosses even tho they.. aren't that hard... and im kind of embarassed... xd hopeful to get more fun hours in to this since i am 8 hours in! (mby one hour was me afk but still :3) je recommande, 10/10 this far and i think you should try it <3
então esse é o famoso dark souls 4?

i think this game is a good entry point for someone who likes the souls formula, but finds it too unforgiving and punishing. it's definitely on the easier side of souls-like spectrum. the game actually allows pausing. the items and equipment menus are still live, but there is a pause menu where you can adjust basic settings. pausing the game also auto-saves, so you don't need to make it to a vestal (bonfire) before quitting out. you can just quit at any point and continue from there. the game is pretty generous with vestals, so runbacks arent really a thing. there are either a lot of them, or there are several shortcuts back to a particular one, so runbacks aren't as common or as grueling. there's almost always a vestal near the boss. one common complaint i saw that i just don't agree with is the level design. it's not labyrinthian or hard to navigate at all. most areas are straightforward. there aren't a ton of branching paths to get lost on. the levels all tend to loop around and give you shortcuts back to where you started. there's a compass you can buy that points you toward various objectives. the story is decent. i thought va was pretty good. enemy variety is a bit meh, basically everything bipedal and humanoid, which come in flavors of grunt, warrior, elite, and heavy architypes. some quadrupeds. and stealthy guys. character customization and weapon variety is good imo. overall pretty fun souls-like. better than lotf, not as good as lop.
really nice game! really recommend for those who appreciate souls like.

i only recommend the game since i paid $5 for it, which it is certainly worth. the setting in french cities is really nice, although i would prefer a little bit more variety. graphics are a bit outdated, but serviceable. my biggest gripe (and the reason why i would not pay more than $10 for it) is the combat. it is imprecise and not very fun. most enemies and bosses can easily be stunlocked by spamming heavy attacks. hence, it is not very challenging. i would recommend lies of p instead, which is a much better game.
napoleonic: yes souls like: yes automatons: yes thats enough, i guess

was pretty fun, you can get this game for a low price on sale with the dlc. overall it's pretty decent, the dlc is disappointing which consists in one area with some new enemies, you can pretty much complete the dlc in 1 to 2 hours.

here's the short and simple part you want to hear: yes it's like dark souls, yes its good, yes it will keep you busy for a dozen or more hours. buy it on sale. here's the long version: all of the above + the game is super easy and the story is mostly nonsense you can ignore. maybe it's just me but i could not care less about the story when every single main character in the story (save 3 out of like 10+ important characters) are just old white guys in powdered wigs who all want to take over france for they're own gains. play it for the unique take on souls like combat, the cool looking automatons and the incredibly easy difficulty. your character is a nuclear bomb with a charging heavy attack button and all the common enemies and bosses are basically newborn babies you can and will stun lock to death once you put a couple points into your prefered damage type. if your looking for babies first souls like game, steelrising is the way to go.

a mild soulslike — fun for a weekend, but lacks challenge i picked up steelrising on sale, and for that price, it was worth it. it’s a short and relatively easy game compared to most soulslikes, but it does have its charm. the story is simple, easy to follow, and a bit predictable—but still enjoyable enough to keep you moving forward. the gameplay starts off fine, and once you unlock the main abilities, it becomes very easy to clear levels. combat feels smooth, but it doesn’t take long before you’ve mastered it and stop needing most of the items the game throws at you. bosses are not challenging at all. i beat most of them on my first attempt, which was a bit of a letdown given the genre. the game also holds your hand quite a lot—something i personally didn’t enjoy since i prefer a tougher challenge. exploration is also on the weaker side. most of the time, your “reward” is just a consumable you’ll probably never need. there isn’t much incentive to go off the main path. that said, it’s not a bad game. it runs well, looks good, and the setting is interesting. it’s just not on the same level as the heavier hitters in the genre. bottom line: steelrising is a mid-tier soulslike. worth picking up on sale if you want something light to play over a weekend, but don’t expect a big challenge.

game is kinda fun, unique and intresting, and always on sale. if you get it on sale, its worth it, but i'll be honest, its no lies of p. its a much more janky and indie version of that, you can see the inspiration of it throughout this game, but after 4/5 hours of the game i think i got a good grasp of it. exploration is fun, and with all indie game it is well thought out. ways to get from point a to b have like 2 or 3 solutions if you know how to work around the weird mechanics, which is cool, but speaking of mechanics, they're bad. and i dont mean, im complaining bad, but they're bad. the jump is weird and the pause at the top of the arc is a little too long, especially when you're in battle. the weapon and the attacks are slow, even when using a fast weapon. and there's this weird startup when you run which makes it unusable in battle because you pause for a split-second, then run, and if you know game mechanics you'll know what im talking about. its fun, but after a couple hours, the gameplay is the main turn off for me. story was awesome though.

a good game. much better than greedfall by the same studio, that i absolutely despised. has its flaws and while it is not perfect from a technical point of view, the graphics are beautiful. the french revolution ambience is pretty neat too. a bit clunky and not always super-balanced, pretty easy to beat, but overall a humble yet good aa game.
solid souls game. reminds me of lies of p and ds

i'm having a lot of fun with this game. it's refreshing to play a souls game that gives you that little bit of feeling on edge whether you should venture a little further or retreat to safety and level up without being frustratingly difficult. there are constantly little side hallways to venture into and i love that the direction that is the side hallway and the main path are not always clear so your mind is constantly working to make sure that you don't miss out on the very rewarding chests that could be in any little nook. update: 9 hours in and having a blast. the build options are pretty robust and all of them can essentially become broken good if you invest in them enough and play to their strength.
wasted potentials. things could've gone way better for this game if only the devs cared

4/10 steelrising is, in many ways, a clear imitation of dark souls—from its combat mechanics to its overall gameplay structure. while it captures some of that familiar challenge and atmosphere, it struggles to offer anything truly unique. the map design and story simply didn’t grab my attention enough to keep me invested, and i found myself losing interest before long. it’s not a bad game by any means, but it’s not particularly memorable either. there are plenty of stronger soulslike titles out there that do more to innovate and engage. steelrising feels like one to play only if you’ve already exhausted the rest and are looking for something similar to fill the gap.

after finishing it, i am strongly disappointed. a few hours into it the combat and story completely fall appart. i was just button smashing, since doding was barely needed, even for bosses. there were also no new game mechanics and enemies barely changed. all side quests force you to run multiple times through the same areas just to pick up letters. game would be better if it was ~6h, rest is really boring padding. --------------- after my first 4 hours: looks great, plays great and performance is also great. setting is interesting, writting and voice actors are good. hit boxes are tight, visuals for attacks are clear and patterns are fun to learn. weapon variety is there. levels are fun to explore. locations loop back to the bonfire and are quite detailed, so orientation is not a problem. encountered only one visual bug.

this game is a mediocre soulslike, fine if you want to grab it on deep sale and give it a play. the main critique of the game is variety. there are a total of 11 base enemy designs, half getting used as early bosses. most variation is a new attack or different elemental effect. similarly, weapon variety is limited to 9 classes with 4-5 variants using the same special ability pool (block, parry, flurry, ranged attack, and elemental buff). the gameplay itself is fine if easy. you get to active reload your stamina bar in exchange for a partial freeze buildup. play hyper aggressive to stagger and crit. most bosses went down on the first try. all the sidequests pop up near the point of no return after you're maxed out, so you can go back and do them all, or just speedrun past the 0 new enemies in the last 3 areas.
this game wish it was lies of p. and it fails gloriously at it lol

the goat: i love the french and paris vibes, the lore, the setting, even the baguette-flavored despair. game combat’s also decent. the clown: too many bugs and worst. isn't optimized properly, it's 2022 game but like pretending in early access. the conclusion: loved the concept, hated the clown performance. game’s good, but the clown side is stronger. negative it is 🤡🤡🤡

el juego no es bueno. combate super repetitvo con animaciones burdas y toscas. aunque las armas son interesantes, rápidamente te das cuenta de lo que realmente vale la pena tener. el parry es demasiado bueno. es tan bueno y fácil de hacer que puedes hacer parries constantes a los jefes, lo cual lo facilita muchísimo los combates. se vuelve más fácil cuando te colocas el módulo para curarte cuando haces parries, y si lo combinas con el módulo para curarte cuando stageas a un enemigo, casi nunca tendrás que curarte. el juego es totalmente mediocre, la historia es malísima y te ponen una custscene larguísima incluso antes de conocer a tu personaje, la actuación de voz mala, y yo estoy jugando con una rtx 4080 y en muchos lugares le cuesta el juego cargar. los enemigos son los mismos, y para empeorar: los jefes nunca se sienten como jefes. sólo se siente como enemigos básicos que tienen un poco más de vida. básicamente, la primera hora del juego ya viste todo lo que tiene que ofrecer. lo único bueno es que tiene niveles estilo metroidvania: poco a poco los vas desbloqueando a medida que vas progresando pero resto... realmente no lo recomiendo, en lo más mínimo. incluso the surge / the surge 2, que ya de por sí no son tan buenos, son muchísimos mejores que este juego porque ofrecen algo distinto. imagínate que te compraste lies of p a través de shein/temu, pero en vez de lop te llega este juego. eso es steelrising.

i did my best to try and like this game, but the terrible camera that would get stuck in walls or alter the direction of your dashes, controls that felt like they both slipped around and were unbearably stiff at the same time, and invisible terrain in the ground that is apparently able to stop you from moving (example, a single step either up or down is a solid wall when dashing, walking and sometimes when jumping), i could not find a way to enjoy playing this game.

shame the da for the paris city is awesome. the main character is nice, and tu automaton concept is very cool. but everything else is really bad. i tried to finish it, but i just cant.. i get bored after 5 hour of play, once the discovering of the game is over it feel like a obligation to launch the game again, the tech is outdated as hell, the game is uggly ( technically, the da is awesome ) the gameplay is very limited, there is barely 10 different enemy, the boss and the overhaul difficulty are no challenge. you will run on the game without dying once. i would have loved to like the game and enjoy it... but there is no way. it's barely a 4/10. do not buy. save your money.

not recommended in my quest to play as many souls-like games as possible, i stumbled upon this mess called steelrising. on steam it’s listed for 50€, but honestly, it’s worth maybe 10 at best. i’m glad i only paid 3€ for a key, because if i had spent full price, i’d be furious. the game has nothing of value to offer. the cutscenes are boring and badly done, the mechanics feel clunky and unpolished, and bugs are everywhere — from enemies glitching out to broken hitboxes. the combat is stiff, the level design is uninspired, and overall it feels like an unfinished project that was rushed out the door. if you’re looking for a solid souls-like experience, this isn’t it. there are countless better alternatives out there for the same (or even cheaper) price. save your time and money.

wow, the artstyle is beautiful and the setting is interesting and the concept is intriguing and the protagonist has potential and the historical side characters have a rich background to draw stories from. so, how come this game is such a borefest? it's aggressively trying to put me to sleep! i don't understand.

i couldn't get into it. i personally don't find the combat to be strong enough to trudge through, and find a gameplay style suited for me. i was unable to find a weapon that particularly stood out as fun to use. when switching from a light, and fast weapon to a heavy, and slow weapon i fully expected to see a response from the enemies when being hit, but i was disappointed. the animations are much too slow to feel rewarding when you don't get feedback from scoring a hit. the frost batons in particular were truly awful to use. in level design, i think there were some strong points, but the heavy use of groups so early on with enemies whose main difficulty is interrupting your actions made the initial experience more frustrating than i could tolerate. maybe it gets better. maybe there is a playstyle that i would love later. maybe the enemies become more fun, but i couldn't push through. i think the company has a strong start, and i will look forward to seeing what they make in the future, but i bounced off of this one because of the feeling of the core gameplay.

the game crashes way too much, about every few minutes. i did everything the internet suggested. this is a problem for several years from what the forums tell me. i liked the premise of automatons taking over in france right before the revolution. but i cannot play a game that crashes every few minutes, even if the auto saves prevent you from losing a lot of time. 15/100
after finishing this game i can say: don't.
runs really quite badly. lies of p is a much better game - play that instead.

pros the game has a cool main character i love the design of the weapons cons the story is pretty boring and usually not so important for soulslike, but the combat is easy enough that a good story would balance it out the characters look bad level design is pretty bad jumped down in an area once i didn't recognize and had to do a 10 min runback it feels janky for the jump and run segments horrible performance, 60fps while just running, drops down to 15 when near water all in all buy on sale if you want something to play with time to kill i got it as a humble bundle game but 50€ is just insane for this edit: also suddenly had a choice system in a single sidequest out of nowhere which was never alluded to just bad game design in general that made me stop playing, just get lies of p

one of the worst "soulslikes" (and that word is doing some heavy lifting) i've ever played. awful mechanics and gameplay. the first boss is turned into a normal enemy less than 5 minutes after you beat it. when they are recycling assets that quickly you know you're in for some lazy game design. the story seemed cool but this game isn't worth your time. spiders games never are.

the game freezes during gameplay , and crashes in some areas , error code [ removed hardware ] i even tried ddu wiping the drivers , rolling back the drivers of my system nothing actually works , i looked at reddit and a lot of people have huge problems both on nvidia's side as on amd . we finally had a respective good game .... and it's sadly for me unplayable . some people on reddit told to check temperatures and those where all fine , since my system is liquid cooled ,, cpu temps where well below the low 66 c , aswell on the gpu 67c ... so no overheating. also this is the only game thad has a problem ....

playing this game is honestly depressing because at every step you are reminded of how good this game could have been, from bosses, level design to weapons and combat. it all could have been good with more time in the oven.

this game is bs basically, delay in everything, when i off marking enemy, it makes step forward and then walks where i want it to. jesus, i cant even make make a chain attack without it stop moving and activate "go back in basic stand" animation when im also vulnerable. its just impossible and nothing compared to other souls i finished and its the only time i blame the game for causing the mess.

steelrising started off strong for me, but the deeper i got into it, the more the fun wore off. the enemy design quickly became repetitive, the same basic types reused over and over, just with different elements like fire or frost to make them “unique.” after a while, it stopped being exciting and just felt like a chore. once i realized i had essentially hit the cap on weapon upgrades and certain specs, the sense of progression disappeared. that’s when the game really lost me. by the second-to-last area, i found myself just running past enemies instead of fighting them, not because i couldn’t handle them, but because i was simply bored. looting also felt unrewarding. gear upgrades were expensive enough that i never really switched weapons or outfits, so there wasn’t much incentive to experiment. the whole system made exploration feel pointless. in the end, i didn’t finish the game, not because it was too hard, but because it got less and less fun the further i went. it’s a shame, because the opening hours showed promise, but for me, steelrising ran out of steam halfway through.

i was going to give this game a solid 7-8/10 until literally ten minutes ago. i just beat the final boss. heartfelt cutscene. cue loading screen for post-cutscene cutscene. game crashes for zero reason. i load back in to find my save right before the final boss. sure, i'll do it again just for the sake of rolling credits. except that i go to interact with the lever that opens the door to the final boss arena, and no button prompt. nothing i can do to get back in and truly finish the game, even if its just final cut-scenes and credits. if this doesn't bother you, then by all means it's a pretty solid game. would be a nice and easy introduction into the soulslike (or soulslite?) genre. but both reddit and steam have several threads about this issue that seems well reported over three years ago and it seems they can't be bothered to fix such a small minor issue that creates a completely impassible softlock that prevents people from finishing the game. so i have to say do not recommend purely on principle.

this game makes me wish steam had more than just upvotes and downvotes. in short yes, the game is super fun. if you like difficult games and don't mind sinking a lot of hours in, reading the wiki or watching youtube tutorials, then this is the game for you. you can get it on sale for super cheap and i've played this game along with the together version and will continue to do so. the problem is that the game doesn't tell you how to do anything. don't get me wrong, it's fun to figure stuff out on your own. but how am i supposed to know that giving meat to a bird in a bird cage enables me to make amazing new food or that bunnymen will attack you just because of you holding meat items, causing me to die 15+ hours into my run. i know dying, learning from your mistakes and starting over is the whole point of the game, but it can get frustrating and repetitive. also certain parts of the game like the adventure/story mode are poorly designed in my opinion. it's running around searching for random items on your map for 4 levels, just for you to die on level 5 because you didn't know the final level was in total darkness. reading the wiki, watching youtube tutorial and using mods like display food values, geometric placement, craft pot and minimap feel like necessities for me to enjoy this game.

it's certainly a product of its time: the early post-minecraft survival/crafting boom. unfortunately for me, many of the core systems feel fundamentally float-y and unsatisfying, in particular the combat or base building. don't get me wrong, the game is well made: the presentation is curated and consistent, there's a lot of content, and clearly there have been loads of extra improvements over the years. at release the game may have been hard to beat, but maybe because the field at that time was so narrow. absolutely a fine game and for the price it's a steal. if you've never tried a game like this before you'll probably enjoy it, but it just didn't resonate with me.

i am really not a fan of games that don't tell you how to play first. i'm ok with minimal direction, but this game is more complicated than it should be, when it gives you no idea of what to do. it's complicated enough to have several button choices and a huge list of things to do, but nothing is highlighted to give any kind of idea of what you can or cannot do. there are monsters around, but no info on how to heal or fight back. you have to move around and collect materials, but for what? the binding of isaac and dark souls have more "how to play" than this. i understand there are gamers that enjoy this sort of thing and power to them. i'm not one of them.

don't starve, according to its overwhelmingly positive reviews, is a great game. if you think you'd like it, you probably will. unfortunately, i didn't. don't starve is a survival crafter with no tutorial and no explanation. this fits the other-world horror theme of how you suddenly found yourself in this strange and confusing universe. i can appreciate the lack of handholding. is that red or green mushroom going to heal you or hurt you? one way to find out! when i say no explanation, i mean [b]no explanation[/b]. you do not see how much damage your axe does, or how effective your armor is. i found multiple headgears. what do they do? who knows! just pay attention and maybe you'll find out! when you die, you start over completely. the only progress you make is the knowledge you take with you. (hopefully that mushroom didn't finish you off!) while it's a rare take on crafter games to be so unforgiving, i can get behind it. i enjoy a good challenge and mystery. except... man, oh man, is it going to feel repetitive going through your lessons. if your game is going to force players to go through the same motions over and over and over again, you better make sure that experience feels smooth. and [u][i]that[/i][/u] is really the sin of the game. everything feels clunky. combat? clunky. you'll have to "kite" all your enemies. stab, run back, stab, run back, stab, run back. very rote. inventory management? clunky. it all just feels like... "what's the point?" the theme did not sufficiently carry the day.

i don't like games where i feel like i'm forced to do bad things. the humanoid pigs in the game are neutral and can speak. there's really not justification to kill them, but many crafting recipes require items obtained by killing the pig people or destroying their houses. my other complaint about the game is that it is extremely unforgiving when learning. i feel like several of my deaths were just because it was the first time i encountered a new monster, event, food, etc. i know i could brute force my way through by playing and dying lots of times, but i would have to invest far too much time learning that way. one way to address this issue at least with foods would be to clearly explain whether or not a food is going to hurt the character (e.g., +10 hunger, -10 health). my third issue is that it's not clear how much damage weapons are doing. it's hard to tell if one item is better or worse than another. inventory management is a pain. if i'm in my base i should have access to all my items in all nearby chests for crafting rather than constantly digging through different chests.

dota 2 remains one of the most strategically complex and competitively balanced multiplayer games available, offering near-endless depth through its vast hero pool and dynamic itemization. the game’s constant updates and meta shifts keep both casual players and professionals engaged, ensuring that no strategy remains dominant for long. its matchmaking system, while occasionally criticized, generally succeeds in creating challenging and rewarding games that test mechanical skill and strategic thinking. the esports scene surrounding dota 2 is exceptionally rich, featuring high-stakes tournaments like the international that showcase world-class talent and innovation. overall, dota 2 stands out as a demanding yet deeply satisfying experience for players who appreciate mastery, teamwork, and ever-evolving tactical gameplay.

management sims, and especially sports management sims, have always been my bag. i've won national championships in the old ea ncaa games, started a expansion team in 2k, and even had cm punk retire due to a drug addiction in one of my many fake wrestling promotions. but nothing compares to the stories that have come from the various iterations of football manager. part of it is simply how complex soccer is. there are hundreds of leagues and thousands of players. and the game itself can be very complicated. a player who is amazing in one scheme can be dogshit in another. even egos and personality types come into play -- i distinctly remember one liverpool save where i bought harry kane and it caused my whole team to mutiny. sports games all come with management modes now, but compared to the depth of football manager it's like the difference between swimming in the deep end and wading in a kiddie pool. it's not for everyone but if this is your type of game it doesn't get better than this.

football manager 2020 isn't just a game; it's a deep dive into the world of football management. the level of detail in this game is astounding – from player transfers to tactical decisions, it encapsulates the essence of being at the helm of a football club. what really stands out is the game's realistic transfer market and the dynamic nature of player interactions. you feel the weight of every decision, whether it's in training sessions or crucial matches. the 3d match engine brings your tactical choices to life, adding a visually engaging layer to your strategies. the learning curve is steep, but once you get the hang of it, it's incredibly rewarding. whether you're a seasoned veteran of the series or a newcomer with a passion for football, football manager 2020 offers an immersive experience that’s hard to put down. a must-play for anyone who fantasizes about managing a top-tier football club.

i've played football manager since the very beginning when it was called championship manager. i have watched how it has slowly grown and became so much more realistic over the years. unfortunately is is now going backwards. the database and game itself is second to none. the tactics of the game is awful. managers do not need to change their tactics and tweak every 10 or so games because the opposition figure them out. the best managers in the world have used the same tactics for a decade. altering it to change the flow now and again. they let the opposition worry about them and not changing a tactic because they might get beat. they change the system within the game. fm20 is the worst ever for this. just when you get a decent tactic you have to start all over again. this is just not realistic. because of this fm20 will be my last addition. the game is now dead. i think eventually everyone will get sick of having to create a new tactic 3 times a season. its just isn't a football sim anymore where you pit your strategy against other managers, even if they are ai they should all still have their own character and styles. instead, you are playing against the same ai regardless of what team your playing against. goodbye fm. thanks for the years of entertainment. rip.

as an avid fan of the fm series stretching back to cm 04 - the year i started i woudl consider myself a veteran. the last version i played was fm 2017. decided to pick the 2020 version curious as to what ai modifications and improvements had been made. i have been left dissapointed - it seems som of the underlying algorithms have changed. it is much harder to scores goals to the point that you need 10 chances on target pr goal. there are matches that have generated 2 clear cut chances and up to 20 shots on target that have ended 0-0. the fun factor and gravitational pull for me has definately been removed because goals are now at a premium. - the game crashes - i have never experienced fm crashes in any of the previous versions. yet on this version 2020 and playing on a laptop with a core i7 processor - i encounter occasional "freezes" in particular after having been awarded a penalty meaning you have to shut down and start afresh. despite following the youtube guides on how to resolve this issues - the crashes still happen from time to time. - the beauty of the fm series was that over time you sensed that your imprint on the team would be more and more discernable - your style of pay and so on. the interaction between you as a player and your team was what provided the incredible gravitational pull to this game. i don't feel that in this version. i think i will revert back to fm2017 which is everything that 2020 is not.

+ only usable manager on the market + has original names sometimes + managing aspect of the game works out + looks fun + its deep - "football" simulation itself is one the worst of its kind - game gives useless advices - ingame turorials are minor and not very helpfull - way too much repetitive clicking - no difficulty change - not possible to score a goal if your tactic settings wont pass the in game goal calculation - hardcoded scoring possibilities - low tier managing stuff can't be automated 300+ hours in, still feel very uncomfortable watching this game simulation and my strikers missing 95% of chances while although playing like messi in the passing departement. game itself gives useless advices on how i should start my games, which are most of the time tactics i never trained before and therefore will loose me games. although i have a strong feeling that goals are only calculated by current values like player abilities + tactic setting and not the game evolution itself. that is why you will see 60-1 chances and 80% possession for your team on a regular basis but only 0-0 these games. changing the tactic in game is although not thought through. lots of clicking and annoying window switching will happen too you. the managing aspect of the game can be fun if you are kind enough to overlook the heavy repetive clicking which makes this game a clicker in some way. the heart of the game, the engine is the worst. it ruins most of the fun of this game. how its programmed and how its presents football is like the beginning of football coming to pc in the 90's. fifa did a better job simulating football in 2001 than this does 20 years later.

this was my first fromsoft game, and probably one of my top ten games in general. super fun once you get the hang of it, and i really really love delving into the lore of it all. certainly a good start if you're looking to try a souls game or soulslike, but don't know where to start. the open world aspect means you can leave and come back later if you feel stuck on a boss or area, so you aren't forced to fight something if you aren't having a great time. of course, that doesn't mean it's easy; it's still a hard game, no matter where you go, but the option to go wherever you want (for the most part) makes it a fun experience. also very fun to read messages from other people, and leave some of your own. dog ahead :)

i was terrified of fighting malenia and i avoided her for so long that i 'accidentally' spent 30 hours leveling up instead. when i finally walked in, i didn’t really fight her, instead she just instantly regretted my mimic's presence. honestly, the hardest part was admitting i was scared of the loading screen.

a world that pulls you in... hours played: 21.4 hrs (at time of review) recommended? 👍 yes after 21.4 hours, i can confidently say elden ring is one of the most immersive experiences i’ve had in gaming. the world feels alive — every corner hides something worth discovering, whether it’s a new boss, a hidden dungeon, or just breathtaking scenery. the combat is punishing but fair, and every victory feels earned. what really stands out is the freedom: you’re never forced down a single path. i’ve spent hours just exploring, finding my own way, and still feel like i’ve only scratched the surface. the sense of scale and mystery keeps me hooked, and i’m loving every moment. if you enjoy challenging combat, deep lore, and a world that rewards curiosity, elden ring is absolutely worth it.

if you care about good story telling or a compelling narrative this is not the game for you. not because the story is convoluted, or because it's hard to follow, but because it is utterly and absolutely meaningless. nothing you do matters in the end. characters act as if nothing changed, literally, they act like you didn't actually do anything, likr they didn't even notice it, despite you supposedly having just completely turned the world on its head. nope, not even some cheap repetitive filler comment from the very few characters left hanging around. they say these games are punishing, the gameplay is fine, the most punishing part is how little care was put into having any sort of closure to a somewhat decent adventure. having finished the game more than once, and being disappointed more than once, i cannot recommend this game, based on *my* perspective. if you want a challenging game, with interesting (but completely meaningless) lore, it's a decent game.

elden ring is clearly intended for people who like to check shit out... on the internet with guides and stuff like that. regardless how difficult this game is.... elden ring is not "a hardcore" game for hardcore gamers; because of that reason. i would say... i always go vanilla, without zero guides and so forth. in this manner elden ring was not a pleasant experience, because you might miss a lot of stuff in your first playthrough. and obviously to understand the lore you have to check out some youtube video explaining all that stuff. and what's up with the "open world"-formula? it's empty and shallow, and sometimes even reminiscent of a bethesda game like oblivion, skyrim, fallout 3 or 4. sure, the main difference between elden ring is that it does not entirely suck like a bethesda game. it's got at least two amazing boss fights, but remember it's got loads of mini-boss fights that are just plain out repetition. and yeah, i did finish this on my console copy. meh.. sometimes less is more!

the game is fine overall and i like a lot of it, especially the dlc which in my opinion is the only thing really worth playing here and i wish i could skip straight to it. the reason i'm writing a negative review is because i believe fromsoftware is in an arms race fully against themselves when it comes to boss design which has negatively affected my enjoyment of this game and genre as a whole. there is also the whole final stretch of the game which feels incomplete, rushed and just wasn't a good time for me. it feels like the developers were too ambitious, made the game too big and couldn't finish it in time. i think the game would've greatly benefited from being much smaller in scope. there is a lot to love if you like these types of games, especially the dlc which excluding the final boss is my favorite part of the game.

i can’t quite see the appeal of this game. as a roguelike, its rng design feels off. there’s a large pool of weapons, but in practice they barely differ beyond dps. meanwhile, the maps, enemy encounters, and bosses vary so little that runs feel like pre-designed stages rather than true roguelike experiences. character building also feels shallow: you rarely get meaningful choices at chests or shops—most of the time you’re stuck with a simple take-it-or-leave-it decision.

play the tutorial, then it loops back. can only walk through one door, to tutorial, then back. choose another character, play tutorial. 1 hour of playing tutorial over and over. maybe they should make a tutorial for brain dead slobs, to get past the rat humping tutorial.

using controller, specifically 8bitdo controller, the input sometimes wont register, i reinstall the game multiple times but still persist. the controller works fine on the games i played like silksong, cult of the lamb, or any games that support controllers but this game specifically struggle to even register common inputs. maybe this brand of controller struggle to this. are there anyone also experience this???

this might be my least favorite roguelike yet. it missed the mark so hard. it feels like they collected a big pile of assets and then put them into an rng. they could have used these resources to actually make an awesome game. to me, that's not really a 'game'. it feels really lazy. like i'm just gambling with my time at their unfinished casino. the progression is very unrewarding. the entire challenge of the game feels like i'm suffering through the developers laziness instead of enjoying their vision.

as much as i love the aesthetics and gameplay of the game, it just feels downright unfair at times. don't get me wrong, its a great game all in all, but 7 out of 10 times, it just feels downright unfair and unfun to play. you get a good run with amazing items, but then you get no healing items or items that increase your health pool. this game in my opinion entirely relies on rng to even beat it, and if you dont have good guns/items, then its just impossible to play, and feels impossible to beat. i've played for 60 hours, and ive gotten quite good. but ive only made it to the final boss once because of terrible rng. would i say its a good game overall? yes i would, but i feel as if you want to truly beat the game, you'll have to pray to rn-jesus.
not a big fan of the pseudo ice skating esque movement. the game as a whole is beautiful, but the arcade version is more fun tbh.

no leveling mechanics, so there’s no ability/weapon synergy like you’d see in other roguelike games. basically, you go into a level with an annoying pea-shooter, praying the one gun you find somewhere on the first level is worth a damn. the reloading mechanics are a terrible idea for this kind of game, and after each run you feel like you’ve accomplished nothing.

i played this game right as it released so that should be taken into consideration if you read this review. that said ... i hate this game, lmao. the rng was unbelievably obnoxious. i can appreciate a difficult game, but when your success relies on a certain amount of rng in order to reliably handle the more difficult content yet the rng is absolutely horrendous and the item pool isn't all that great ... well, let's just say my experiences overall sucked pretty hard thanks to that. i managed to beat the game a few times which for sure was great the first time i managed to do it ... but the time it took between runs in order to actually have a powerful enough setup to reliably complete the game completely killed all of my motivation and drive to keep playing this game for years to come. i don't know how it is now. i never gave the updates a chance because my experiences were such a pain in the ass, even when people told me "oh it's so much better now, they did x y z" too little too late, man, i was already sick of this game. it was almost good ... but really ... it was just another copy of boi in the end. also, with news of enter the gungeon 2 coming out, i'm removing this game from my account and putting both on ignore. if etg 2 is anything like what i experienced with the first game, then there's absolutely no fomo for me and i'm better off pretending it doesn't exist.

this game has failed multiple times to care for my time - it is not worth playing for runs where one simply cannot get a new gun even after clearing everything and my index finger can only click so many times before it goes numb shooting at the ammoconda with the starter pistol. was i supposed to involuntarily participate in a challenge where the starter weapon is the only weapon? was i supposed to shoot only by holding the mouse, making me have to care about when to reload? i was not given guns in a game called "enter the gungeon" ... more like "enter the geon", if you ask me. unbalanced and annoying.

this game has a lot going for it, but whenever i think about spinning it up i remember how dang slow it feels to play. regardless of actual time, it feels like it takes 15 minutes to get to the first boss. in nuclear throne you get to the first boss in something like 3 minutes. 30 seconds, if you use a skip. a good run will take an hour in both games, but in nt that hour is full of action whereas here you spend a lot of time walking through empty rooms looking for treasure chests. it's not good. this game does have a dodge roll though, so that's nice. wish i could get my money back. bullet-hell ... why did i buy this thing ... because of the good reviews ... thx internet trolls. if you like to play games without getting hit, this is the game for you. if you enjoy non relaxing games with no meta progression, this is for you. the only goal of this game is getting better via learning bullet pattern. playing all souls games no-hit back-to-back is easier and more fun. my first and last bullet-hell game. i do not know what kind of person you must be to have fun with this. for a pixel game performance is bad. and there are tons off issues, depending on your pc setup, for me game crashing/not-starting, wasted 1hour to fix the "problem".

i do enjoy this game but i could never recommend this game to anyone, its too blatantly unfair and reliant on rng to a degree that makes ftl look easy in comparison. 1. the camera is crap, you can't see the whole room in a lot of cases and then get clapped by multiple enemies who cover the entire room with bullets. 2. the chests are so random that the chests themselves don't even matter what tier they are. 3. the enemies health scaling is insane considering how rare ammo drops are. 4. while most bosses are perfectly learnable there are some whose attacks are purely random and make them just rage inducing like gattling gull and ammoconda. 5. while i get that unlocking guns and stuff makes it easier as you unlock better ones they are just so expensive and there are so many that you are expected to play hundreds of hours just to get to that point. 6. final complaint is there are zero explanations on anything, you want to know what something does then you have to go to the wiki. i still find the game fun but its just too unbalanced to be able to recommend this game, i don't this it deserves the thumb down i gave it but it definitely doesn't deserve a thumbs up just wish there was a neutral option but since there isn't its definitely more towards thumbs down.

continue?9876543210 is not going to be a fun game for everyone. many will find its lack of guidance frustrating, or its over simple art style and gameplay to be an overdone trope. but i feel this isn't a game in the traditional sense, in the same way poetry isn't prose. this game makes you reflect, look deeper, and even contemplate existence as you wander through simple yet beautiful worlds interacting with the people within. it truly is a beautiful game, and if you want to have an experience of contemplation and love rather than just skill, i highly recommend this game. 10/10
there is no fighting the inevitable extermination.
now i'll always press continue because i am afraid of dying.

i reallyl like continue?9876543210. it can be confusing, but provides a constantly changing experience, topdown exploration, platformer fighting, some really nice cutscenes as well. which is nice since many games do not dare to change it around like that.

not everyone is going to like this game. i can guarantee you this much. i, for one, love this game very much, it's a very metaphorical experience. take note, this game has a bit of an arcade style to it. you play until you die, then start again from the beginning. yes, the game saves, automatically at the beginning of every level. yes, you can skip the introductory cutscene, you have to click somewhere and a box appears in the top-right corner saying "skip->" some people will not take appreciation of the metaphor used in this game. others might, but will not enjoy the gameplay for some reason or another.

christians like to explain what happens when people die. problem is, easy answers ignore the gravity of the situation. death is confusing, especially for the living. jason oda’s game, continue?9876543210, takes a long road through the mourning of a life lost, awaiting absolute termination. players aren’t sitting immediately with jason oda as they play his game, ruminating on life, death, and eternal destinations. but the invitation to enter into that tension is one that joins his longing for life and meaning at the point of death. when in mourning, we’re a mess and life isn’t fun. death is confusing and frustrating. and the game’s metaphors are so unclear that i don’t even know what we’re mourning. is it our own existential death? or the death of a loved one? in the end, i don’t think it matters. what does matter is being able to mourn with those who mourn and rejoice with those who rejoice. read more: http://gamechurch.com/death-and-mourning-in-continue9876543210/

this little indie gem is actually an interesting game. it gave me a feeling of futility and wonderment. the first few playthroughs can make you a little lost but the setting in which it takes place is dark. if you know anything about processors and how they operate, this games gets you thinking about entities it operates on, however unrealistic it may be. dark, depressing, and a pleaseant addition to my library. 8/10

and though i left, i took with me their lightning and their prayers. i've never come across a game more contemplative and philosophical. it's got a gorgeous pixel art design (like a more colorful swords and sworcery), hauntingly melancholy music, and a unique concept. you are a video game character, and the game starts when you die. you are set on the path for deletion, but have an opportunity to run. what do you do? the game's story focuses on acceptance and reflection, which is at odds with its gameplay, which has a focus on action and timed sections that are fairly frenetic. and the action sequences are more challenging than you would expect from the rest of the game. that being said, the feelings this game engendered are not common for games, and if you have an interest in seeing what games can do outside of their traditional boundaries (but are capable enough to play traditional games), this is an experience you won't soon forget.

in this immersive game, you play a character that failed to complete his quest and now faces an unavoidable fate : deletion from memory. filled with beautiful soundtracks and thoughtful dialogs, this game will make you think about your own existance and mortality while you struggle to survive attacks from the relentless garbage collector.

emogame and emogame 2 were staples of my adolescent experience. they turned me on to a slew of music that i wouldn't have appreciated otherwise and managed to be both hilarious and thoughtful throughout. when i saw that the creator of those flash games, jason oda, had developed this odd-looking title, i was intrigued. so, i'll lay out the negatives first: unskippable intro (that you will have to sit through many many times), boring and awkward combat, unintuitive gameplay mechanics. with that in mind, the game is a remarkably beautiful meditation on mortality explored by proxy through slain video game characters facing deletion and finally oblivion. if you go into this expecting a hack and slash dungeon crawl, you will be sorely disappointed. this is more of an interactive poem than a game, and it excels in that respect.

i am very much in love with the 'indie' genre of games. it is inspirational when i hear a group of only a few people who go through the effort of making a game all by themselves. this game, being my game nomination of the year, has amazing art, an amazing soundtrack, a great storyline and decently appealing gameplay which makes for a fantastic game altogether. the only difference is, it was made by only one man.
this game is fun... but really confusing in the beginning
artsy and pretentious, but in a good way. play it for the content, not the gameplay.
it's not fun to play and it's frankly pretentious.

this game is over ambitious very confusing and over all a mess of ideas. the main puzzle element of the game is delivered through on screen unvoiced dialogue, the font choice is so terrible that it strains the player to read it. the spacing between the words on screen is so tight that is almost dizzyingly bad. the gameplay isn't very strong if it's even there at all it's probalby one of the worst games i've ever played, purely form a gameplay,writing,presentation and story telling point of view. the game trys to be meta and place a game within a game and break the 4th wall of what it means to be a videogame protagonist and it fails in every respect.

honestly, i don’t get it. my prayer? my lightning? wtf? chasing fading silhouettes? talking to same strange inmates in unidentified prison? using shelters to avoid garbage collector? of course shelters are built by prayers… game is filled with all that nonsense. actually call it a game is bit exaggerated. easiest combat ever with no real interaction, just pressing one button.

i decided to try this game because i was interested in artsy exploration games like antichamber. i knew this game wouldn't be quite the same, but hoped to get the same kind of feeling from playing it. i thought the game would explore death more seriously, or make you feel like you were in the presence of something profound. it did not. at first, i was drawn to the atmosphere. it captures this sad sensation, something a little bit alien, but doesn't fill you with dread that you'd think a death would. and the pacing is very, very slow. when you die, you see a white screen that takes about 15 seconds to refresh. when you run out of time, you have to watch, very slowly, as your buildings are destroyed. this wouldn't be so bad if the visuals were more stimulating, but they are not. it gets boring fast. in the game, you're asked random questions and can answer in 2 different ways. you figure out that there are right ways and wrong ways to answer based on what people in town say. but the questions are very random, disorienting, and devoid of meaning. and a meaning, or at least some presence of a purpose, is what this game lacks.

a great premise but i can't recommend this game. i'm all for philosophising and a deep story, but the premise is all this game has. i couldn't really find a story behind constant references to prayer and lightning and very brief discssions of nihilism. tedious gameplay with no proper gamepad support and obscure mechanics further marred the experience. if you want ruminations on computer people - play the talos principle instead.

this game feels like it's trying to tell you a message through metaphorical nonsense that is just complete gibberish. very artsy game, in the sense that i'd imagine the dev's wearing billowy poet shirts and writing this garbage while musing under a tree or in a cemetary. the actual game mechanics are just annoying, run around, read and try to memorise nonsense, get to doors before your timer runs out and repeat back the nonsense to have a chance at progressing to the next level. what i'm trying to say is that, well, some people are going to really love this game but to most people it's going to be a complete waste of time.
play skrillex quest, its a better version of this.

very interesting conceptually, but very depressing. is there any way this game has a happy ending? or is it really inevitable digital holocaust for the protagonist and the various npc he tries to save? i recommend it for people looking for a unique artistic experience, but not necessarily to gamers.
the game story is about failing. so the game. interesting cut scene, but graphic style ruined it all. 1/10

it's a very personal game that has deepness. unfortunately, this is all it has. gameplay is ridiculous, the visual experience is horrible. the story telling is slow and a bit overestimated, add to that very aggressive sound effect, and you'd understand why i won't play beyond the first hour.

i purchased this game based on what i saw in the video trailer. i saw a retro-style action adventure game with a deep, sad, yet sweet story that would make me think about life and fill me with a desire to help this poor protagonist sprite. perhaps it's my fault for misinterpreting the trailer, but it seems to be more like the developer misrepresented the game quite heavily. rather than your typical adventure game where you advance the story by exploring new areas, fighting the bad stuff, and engaging in dialogue with npcs, you have here a frantic experience of rushing to find disappearing npcs to talk to and doors to enter punctuated by uninspired slice-and-dice minigames. on the up side, the introductory cutscene sequence is a beautiful thing to watch, but i could have done that on youtube.

there's a major problem with games as art. you need both the game and the art. is continue?9876543210 art? certainly. is it a game? yes. do these work together? no. binding of isaac shows you can concentrate on the game; while dear esther shows you can concentrate on the art. now imagine shooting tears at esther, and you can see what the problem with continue is. like salmon and marmalade, they work great on their own - but together you just feel nauseous. skrillexquest is a far better game with a similar concept - also by the author. continue always feels like it's trying to hard.

the intro is the best part of this game. the gameplay itself is fairly repetitive, and when i had reached the point of repeating levels or scenes, many of the sequences cannot be skipped even when i had seen them a number of times. i really like the concept which is why i bought it despite the poor reviews. i do not really care for the execution and was quickly bored with the title. additionally the linux port is not very good. no resolution/fullscreen configuration without finding the config file and editing it, unlike the windows launcher. it also does not handle widescreen aspect ratios unlike the windows version.
too much story with not enough anything else. an adequate art style put together for someone to do nothing while experiences an okay story with a good premise. do not play unless free and bored.
this game is more like a thesis paper. no fun to be had. the game is a commentary on games. do not buy it if you want to have fun.

i really regret buying this.. it is confusing and really irratating being in the same places over and over...and over.. the font is so robotic i cant even read some of it, but it might be my resolution. you could get a lot more with $10.00 outa steam.

the idea is entertaining, the first moments of gameplay is fantastic... but you do get bored after a while. sadly, this game is quite repetetive and isn't even that challenging. you could easily finish this game within moments. perhaps it would've been better if it had a larger variety of gameplay, and more places to explore. sorry, but this is a thumbs-down from me.

this game is trying way, way too hard to be artsy and philosophical. it's especially frustrating when all you want to do is exit the game and instead you're forced to watch a 5 minute cutscene telling you that you should dance with scarecrows. continue?9876543210 feels like the video game equivalent of those crazy yoko ono tweets.

as somebody who wanted to enjoy this game, i was left bored and irritated in about 15 minutes. this is a good "games are art and experimental" game, but don't play it if you actually expect to have fun doing so.

this is a game about, as the description says, a failed video game character wandering around the world of random access memory. i was interested in this game since i first saw it, it looked like a fun little indie-adventure game, and i was put into a beautifully made and well-run game, though not quite expecting as much action as there really was. it was a lot more difficult than i thought it would be (or i'm just bad at games) and it's very confusing. i didn't know what i was doing when walking around the levels and i couldn't find much story to it which is a little odd for this type of game. of course, experiences are different for everyone and for me it wasn't that good. half the time i was confused and the other half i was getting annoyed that i had to fight off 20 munchy enemies every 20 seconds. the game has a good concept and is beautiful, but it isn't for me and i wouldn't recommend it.

(originally posted january 8 2014) i played continue?9876543210 the last couple of nights. a weird game, apparently based on the developer's personal experience of getting lost in a desert while under the influence of a hallucinogenic. not quite a "roguelike" (maybe a "roguelike–like"?), it was a bit difficult and stressful, but very atmospheric and fraught—the kind of game that makes you question the/your purpose in life. i can't say that i "enjoyed" it (actually it made me feel quite sad), but i'm glad that i played it. i didn't "beat" it, but i think i'm done with it for now.

kinda wish there was an 'eh' button for reviewing. thats what describes continue?9876543210. when i first found this game i was excited, interesting concept that i don't think has been done before, it had great potential but fell flat. i was (and still am) confused on how to 'beat' the game, i say that because after a half hour of play it seemed like i finished it, took me to the main menu and everything, i was dissapointed so i played again to find the same thing about 30-45 minutes of play time per game. it's entertaining but i would definitely get it on sale.
when u lose it repeats a waste of money

maybe if i play it more it will get better, but for now, this game could not have disappointed me more. each playthrough is its own experience it seems, complete with a story that makes... basically no sense (at least to me). without much backstory, or story for that matter, it left me wanting quite a lot more. the gameplay is strange as well. game boards (or that is what i am calling them) need to be cleared in a certain time limit. if you do not, the game ends, and you have to sit through your character running away from being deleted and dying. after that, the game starts over. the in game manual, if you can call it that, kind of gives you some insight into the mechanics, but not much. the biggest redeeming quality of this game is the music. it is very whimsical and gorgeous. the worst thing about this game however, is the flashing. possibly my computer (maybe), but in some instances of cinematics or certain effects, it is as if you are in a rave. epileptic gamers beware. overall, the game could be better, and less confusing. 5/10

the developer was willing to publish it on steam and charge money for it, but not to give us a menu with the most basic configuration options present in every 3d platformer since the '90s. it can't be maximized. none of the options can be changed. it just runs in a window. what the hell were they thinking? this is just sloppy.
skrillex quest was much better and it's free
the controls are too frustrating to overcome and actually focus on any "experience" or interesting ideas that are included.

i believe that an idea is much more important that how the idea is expressed. as a conseqence, i am almost always willing to overlook bad gameplay provided a game has substance. contine?9876543210 is the exception to this. ostensibly the game is a contemplation of death, but the gameplay is so awful that it ruins anyting that the game is trying to communicate. specifically: -the instructions provided are totally inadequate. -the controls are unredeemably bad. -most sections of the game have arbitrary time limits. these appear to be included solely out of spite that the developer has for you. -a substantial portion of the game is composed of unskippable cutscenes. it seems like the total length of the cutscenes for the total game is probably less than 20 minutes, but thanks to the awful controls you will have to replay most of them for hours before you win. given this situation, it is probably only a matter of time before some masochist posts them online. since the main point of the game is for you to contemplate the cutscenes, if that happens you will essentially get the substance of the 'game' for nothing. finally, do not be fooled by the trailers, they do not accurately represent the game. if you are truly interested in buying it, wait until some gameplay videos are posted online before you make your decision. the only positve aspect of the game was the music.
pseudo intellect: the roguelike. play at your own risk.

the developer said it themself: "this is one of those love it or hate it experimental art games." take that into consideration before you purchase this. if you're expecting entertainment or a pleasurable experience then you'll be disappointed. this isn't like bastion or limbo that pair a deep dark story with solid gameplay, this is strictly the former. unfortunately it was just a bit too experimental and surreal for me. i couldn't get into it no matter how much i tried. the fact that the game bugged out within the first 20 minutes and stuck me in an inescapable room didn't help - but hell, for all i know, that might be just another attempt at relaying some covert message to me.

i played this game for about .... 1 minute, but it took me 10 to get into actual gameplay which was me going from the start to the end of "level 1" to get into another cut scene. the sounds are extremly harsh, the animation is weak ( considering the simplicity of the models the rigs should be super simple) and i had no idea what was going on,
no saves. too quick. there's no time to explore and get a feel of the game. you can't even quit.

i keep it downloaded all the time because its small on my drive and pure fun in my heart. love seeing updates happening and always fun to play with a podcast or youtube video going. the fun of a rougelike with the pants explosions of peggle, will always have a place in my pc.
aw hell yeah peglin mode
it peggled me all over the place. 10/10.

peglin has been one of my most-played games for over a year now, and for good reason. the continuing updates keep it feeling fresh, and i love the different combinations of orbs. definitely recommend to anyone who likes to build a cute deck!
just when i thought i was out, they pull me back in!
peggle x binding of isaac. love it!
a lot of fun, only negative feedback is some of the final achievements are crazy to get
as a goblin i endorse this, and it's not because i collect marbles. it's not. not at all.

i have spent over 700 hours on this game, and i am only at cruciball level seven. come on, devs, is it really supposed to be this hard? it's ridiculous to have spent this much time, only playing cruciball the entire time, and only be at level seven. i am not even 'bad' at the game. am i just this unlucky or something? what am i missing here? this is one of my favorite games out of over 2000 games on steam, as you can see, and here i am so frustrated i am actually writing a review just to express my simultaneous love and exhaustion. :(

legitimately one of the most fun and addicting games i've ever played. near infinite replayability and a game loop that has me constantly saying "just one more run". pachinko got me messed up

i love this game so much, i know a lot of it's rng based but i just find it really fun ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

peglin has got to be one of the most fun games for the price lately. i have never enjoyed roguelite/rouglikes much, but something about peglin is just perfect. the gameplay is very easy to understand, a run isn't very long i average around 50 minutes. which is perfect for how the game loop is. it feels casual and relaxed, really great to an individual who wants a casual game to relax with, but also has offers for the people who prefers to optimise their gameplay. enemy types are varied, but not over bloated to the point where you forget what certain enemies does. over all the game is great, very fun and even at full price it would be worth to someone who enjoys pinball mechanics or roguelikes, on sale it's great for someone who wants to try this genre out.
it's fr everything i wanted peggle mixed with a cute roguelike its so damn good

i feel like if you like peggle + rougelike games, you will definately love this game, i've been more or less kinda addicted to this (i play between the pc and mobile versions, although the mobile version will let you play the first stage for free compared to the pc version of the game)
this game is so peak

i love this game, but fair warning, the balance of luck vs skill skews heavily toward the luck side. anything past the easiest base difficulty is mostly luck, and you will have runs that you are doomed to lose because you can't get the items you need, the refreshes are in the wrong place, or you just get the wrong miniboss too early on. that said, beating a run and being able to jump up to the next difficulty is very satisfying.
this game keeps me coming back for more, even after 36 hours there are still new things to unlock and enjoy.
perfect to play while listening to a podcast or audiobook, surprisingly high replayability.

i can only play this game once a day, it makes me so goddamn angry. but i do keep coming back to it, so i don't know what that says about me.
its fun. its a pegle roguelike
yea this game got the juice
