10/10 would get pegged again

bought this super early, hop on every now and then and kill some time. nice to see it still getting updates. over 100 hours in the game and basically everything unlocked, its a fun casual game when you just wanna sit around high and click buttons while watching youtube.
amazing game, and the sounds are half the fun
truly addictive, incredible gameplay loop(s), and possibly the peak of gaming
who up peggin they orb

a really fun and satisfying peggle-like with a pachinko twist. there are skills and strategies to be learned but a lot of the game is rng. build variety is lacking and some playstyles are objectively better than others, especially at higher cruciball levels. update 1.1.18 addressed this somewhat by putting the more "niche" items that you could obtain from chest encounters into the shop. the game is really fun when you are have a good build and a broken run. the standard difficulty is very forgiving and probably the ideal way to play the game, while the higher difficulties can be incredibly frustrating if luck isn't on your side. overall, i still highly recommend the game and it's a good addition the library of any roguelike enjoyer or someone who enjoys peggle.
numbers go up! making combos are also fun. had to get this game after watching a lot of angory tom
ball physics feel awful even on 2x speed, feels super clunky
the fact that 50% of the time you have zero influence in the path you take makes it a horrendous experience at higher crucibals...

peglin has great pixel arts design and interesting enemies, levels, orbs, relics, etc. however, i wish the impact of luck wasn't so powerful throughout the game. the map, relics, orbs and even navigation through the map can affect the gameplay widely based on the random number generator. the game design is relatively addictive, but everytime i go back to it and the rng hurts me again l remember why i put it aside last time.
game is fun but some of these peg boards are either poorly designed or completely luck based. losing an hour long run to a board where 1/4 of the pegs kills the enjoyment this game could have.
the physics in this game feels awful compared to something like peggle.

all of the updates have made this game a lot worse. everything was broken so the game was fun, but literally everything got nerfed so you have to stick to 1 playstyle now or else you wont even beat the castle boss. so boring.

peglin is a blast of a deckbuilding roguelite for the first few completed runs, however once you start doing runs at higher cruciball difficulties, the cracks really start to show. the game does not give you the ability to adequately gain strength to a degree that can contend with the rapid difficulty spikes of act 2 and 3. i have over 70 hours at the time of writing and not once have gotten lucky enough to pass cruciball 10. because of this, combined with a distinct lack of meaningful meta progression, means that the fun build variety you'd usually get out of roguelikes does not actually exist. a lot of "upgrades" (often received from fighting bosses) come with downsides that far outweigh the positives they could ever give you. a lot of pegboard layouts focus far more on the theme of the encounter than actual play-ability. there are many where a single bad refresh peg spawn can end entire runs and others that practically require specific balls or upgrades to even contend with, resulting in very unsatisfying deaths. for the price, it isn't worth it. if the devs ever show interest in levelling the playing field then i'd consider picking it up, but until then save your money for a game that respects your time investment and allows you to interact with the tools it has on offer in fun and impactful ways.
focused more on porting this to mobile than actually adding or completing content.

this game has a charming concept but i just don't feel it man. the enemies being tied to the board makes the game very monotonous, especially considering how little board variations there are per area. by the late game areas i'm either too under-powered to defeat the beefy enemies or too over-powered to feel like my input on the ball even matters. if you're really into pachinko you might like this game, but otherwise i'd say to give it more time in the oven
most unfulfilling roguelite ever made
the rng at higher levels is just straight up not fun.

as far as i would love to give peglin a nice review, i can't. the game itself it's nice, relaxing, of course it brings the good peggle vibes. the problem appears once you unlocked every character. they are just 4, imo the hardest to unlock was the armored one, but once they are there to be played, the maps are the same, there's no biome/zone despite the 3 we always see. more relics are always welcome, same with game balancing and more orbs, but the game feels bored. i love it, but can't enjoy to play always the same exact maps.

i'll give this game a thumbs up for being a unique game and being genuinely fun at the base level. this game does have problems though, as others have pointed out this is a relatively 'solved' game at harder difficulties, and it's likely due to peggle being a poor translation for an ascension focused deckbuilder. there are not a lot options for orbs that will have a positive effect on your run, and the boss relics are situational at best but usually a skip. skipping most of your run because anything you add would actively harm you is not enjoyable difficulty. the games concept is fun, the gameplay loop that they created is fun, and since bigger number always means better person- it has to mean better game too, the damage you do can scale insanely high. i just wish they put more effort into the difficulty settings. casual gaming: excellent and worth it difficult gaming: maybe skip edit: after further consideration, and seeing the game on the app store for $5, i feel taken advantage of.

rng the game. higher difficulties are just reset until you get a good item to counter the bad things. 2/3 bosses are likely runkillers in all zones. every run is just a fucking slot machine, and i'm not even talking about the peggle part. that has its own issues. the boards are mostly super unfun made to not even work. you bounce into one other peg then hit a wall and fall into a pit. some of the layouts are fun, they seem to have added more fun layouts recently, but that doesn't fix the old ones being just super unfun.

you gotta balance luck with skill better than what peglin does - its way too far in the luck spectrum. many of the balls and items are just not impactful in any noticeable way. getting too many of these dud balls or items early, you'll know you won't be able to get through some of the specific battles later in your run.

i really liked this game, but there wasent really enough content for me. i was able to beat the final boss on my first ever run. very fun, but couldnt justify spending money for that little of content. refunded <3

unbalanced to the point of absolutely ruining the player experience. early game is fun but too easy and the difficulty scaling is really bad. there is no skill. it is pure luck. save yourself some time and don't touch cruciball. it's not too bad but pretty quick it turns the game horrible and exposes every single flaw this game has... which is a lot. it sucks cause i bought this game for early access almost two years ago and frankly it has become disappointing. the devs clearly do not care about balancing, which is crucial for a roguelite. pachinko boards are already bs, this game makes me want to avoid every version of a pachinko board in existence. you can see i've put a lot of time in this game. i bought it on mobile when that came out. i want to like it so bad but its just frustrating.

it's like peggle if it were like every subpar indie game released in the last 5 years - boring pixel art, no onboarding whatsoever, bad physics, and overall boring gameplay for $20 you could buy the peggle pack, nubby's number factory, and probably a number of other peggle-likes and have a much better experience

it's good fun for a couple of hours, but not nearly worth the price. it's in desperate need of more levels, 3 is not close to being enough. just as you start assembling your build, the game ends. it's very underwhelming and gets really repetitive playing the same 3 levels over and over again. the "end game" is literally just replaying the same 3 levels but with a few tiny modifiers added that barely change the game in any significant way until your 10th repetition. and even then, seeing the same enemies and fighting the same few bosses gets really boring. not recommended unless you get it on sale for $5 or less, as going by the $1/hour rule there is not enough content for > 5 hours of gameplay. i really stretched my patience to see if i could get any additional amusement out of this game, but even with mods and way too many playthroughs, i only got 18 hours before i just couldn't play anymore; it stopped being fun at about the 4 hour mark and started becoming a painful grind, which is still a far cry from the $1/hour metric at the game's current price of $25.

this game is such a creative concept for a rougelike, but the execution just sucks. i've played this game a lot cause i thought "maybe i just haven't figured the game out yet, even if the items you get are random, most rougelikes have a way to work with what you're given" but in all the time i've played this game i figured out that there is 1 singular good build that completely trumps every other possible build that only requires a single item to work, so why the hell should i keep playing this game looking for new fun ways to play? i've tried building for spinification, but it requires so many different balls and relics and it just doesn't ever come together before the game ends. i've done some slime runs and those were pretty cool, but that also only really requires the item the slimes 1/17 pegs and some high damage balls. the game just refuses to let cool synergies work which is the whole reason rouglikes are fun in the first place. i really tried to like this game, and probably will keep trying cause i think it seems like a cool game, but every time i pick it up its just a big disappointment.

i want to like this game, i really do, but it's just so poorly balanced that i can't give it a positive review. there are some orbs and relics that can nearly solo the game, and there are some that you would never pick under absolutely any circumstance other than trying to fill out the collection of things you haven't picked before. some events like that too. the menus/map navigation are frustratingly slow, restarting for a required good relic at higher cruciballs is annoying, and there isn't enough build variety, as there is almost always a best build for a character unless you're relying on luck to deliver synergistic relics one after the other. the worst part is there *have* been updates to the balance of the game, but they don't address many of the worst problems. i don't understand why.
short as a toilet break when you have diarrhea

i want to give it a mixed rating, and this game is fun until, you hit cruciball 6 or so. from there on in just feels incredibly frustrating to get anywhere. the game will just work against you in these later cruciball levels, dumping you against enemies you have no chance beating, because you weren't lucky enough to get the right orbs and/or relics to get a decent enough build. it feels many of the relics are just bloat-like, thinning out the chances of having a good build and run. when you get the build you are after, it is quite fun. however, some of the level designs and 're-designs' are just horrendous and strips a lot of the fun out of the game.

i enjoyed this game when i first got it. then some "updates" were done; harder enemies with more life. i've found it almost impossible to get through a game now. if you're going to give then enemies more life, why can't we purchase more life in the shop for the characters? it's more frustrating than challenging now.
not worth it at full price. acceptable at -70%.
i hate to say it, but it kinda stops being fun and just becomes a tough, frustrating, and random slog after cruciball 8. fun until that point though

my game keeps crashing 2-5 minutes into every new run i start. it started happening after i unlocked the second character. would love to find a way to fix this because i loved the short amount of this game i got to play. (it's not my pc every other steam game is fine).

has the components to be fun, but isn't really. seems like it needs a longer build - i had no idea what to expect from anything and was able to win in one run. i enjoyed what i played but it felt cut short. i was surprised it didn't keep going on and scale a lot more as you slowly get more control over your loadout. looks like there's an ascension mechanic but it makes the beginning more difficult to start rather than an ending that's more challenging to overcome. other roguelikes are better.
i guess i'm just bad at the game but it's infuriating how many times i can't aim the fucking ball where i want it to go. oh well.

me and my partner play peglin on my account, and we both face fhe same issues. too much rng. some times you can't even chose which path you would like to follow... and good luck if the r ends up in a corner at the bottom and the game doesn't give you a "choice" to spawn r's. it can be very frustrating and the first levels can be very boring.
not a fan of the rebalance.

i, like others have stated, cannot recommend this game in it's current state. after cruciball 15+, this game becomes a grind of, "hope you can get lucky with the right combination of orbs/relics, otherwise you'll lose for the 25/26/27th time in a row." thd game is plagued with the "death spiral" as others mentioned, and the orb/relic selection becomes too random to be benefial at higher cruciball levels. i understand the purpose of the game becoming more difficult, but there needs to be some re-work of just about everything if they want this game to be any fun at higher levels. i can't even count the number of times i've had (what i thought to be) an amazing built, only for a simple fight in act 2 or 3 to counter the build entirely. horrible refresh placements, orb/relic options that do nothing for your build, and enemies/boss fights that you're powerless to do anything about (unless you have that one specific build) are all reasons i'm slowly pulling away from this game. i've managed to crawl my way to c18 on a couple characters, but its always followed by 10+ failed runs before a win. it truly is an incredibly fun game to play at lower levels, just don't expect to feel any joy whatsoever past c15. 4/10, if the devs bump the difficultly scale down a touch, or even give players some form of support towards the ending cruciballs, this score can change. edit 7/9/25 - i currently have 50+ losses in a row on cruciball levels 17+ between my steam account and mobile. it is ridiculous that i can go that many runs, trying my hardest, and still get screwed over because of poorly designed levels, bosses, and terrible synergies.

brotato: finally, a game for the rest of us! i used to judge those people with thousands of hours in games, you know, the ones whose skin hasn't seen sunlight since dial-up was a thing. "get a life!" i'd scoff, adjusting my perfectly ironed shirt before heading to my incredibly fulfilling job, where i'm a respected leader of a small, but vital, team. i'd then spend my evenings engaging in meaningful conversations with real humans, or perhaps mastering a complex new recipe. but then... brotato. now, my colleagues wonder why i'm "too busy" to join the lunch team-building exercises. my carefully cultivated social life has been replaced by an intense, unspoken rivalry with my own past high scores. i haven't seen a full night's sleep in weeks, fueled only by the primal urge to get that one last potato upgrade. my perfectly ironed shirts are now... optional. this game is a deceptively simple, time-devouring vortex. it is my life now. and honestly? it's pretty good. i mean, who needs a 'life' when you can be a potato with 6 arms wielding rocket launchers? definitely not me, apparently. 10/10 - would neglect all responsibilities again.
great game, with a ton of replay value. ~20 minute sessions per run, so a nice way to take a break in the day.

it took me a while to actually beat this game. i bought it near to 3 years before this review because it art. i am sucker for religious paintings or perhaps enjoy romantizing martyrdom, this game succeeds in bringing a captivating beauty through misery. speaking of misery, the gameplay of course takes large inspiration for metroid and dark souls. the game does well in making the game feel tough during certain bosses, though after a point it does become easier (i say in better or for worse terms.) the gameplay admittedly didn't sway me, if i had never played a mouls-like or a metroidvania, it would be completely fresh to me but only recycles these ideas and i am afraid to say doesn't bring much to table in terms of new ideas. the gameplay itself does feel almost like an ign review of an indy game. but, the game's atmosphere, and story is where the game begins to shine and find it's identity. it's a fun (though maybe blasphemous,) retelling of christ. the penitent one goes into world to free it from suffering. though in this game it's done by violence and not by kindness. it's an interesting and grim retelling of my beliefs. it's hopeful enough to not feel like an edgy gorefest and bleak enough to feel impactful. there is some gripes i do have with the story, but since i haven't played the sequel, i think it is best if i bite my tounge for now. i would give it probably a 7.5/10.

great game with a vibe that is next to none with the themes of twisted catholicism, sin, penitence, suffering. very interesting story with a world that is insanely immersive. the map is very well designed and fun to explore with fun combat and fun fights. the art style is also very compelling. deff recommend this game to metroidvania fans or anyone who is into that dark fantasy feel. gonna be picking up blasphemous 2 here soon

what can i say about this game other that is an absolute masterpiece. the story, the environment, the soundtrack, the characters, the art, blasphemous nailed each one of them perfectly. i think everyone should give this game a try to admire the passion the developers really put into this game <3
it was fun, not fun enough to go through and do alternate endings or grind post end game content though. kinda releaved when i beat it.

blasphemous is a brutally beautiful metroidvania that blends dark gothic-religious lore with tight hack‑and‑slash combat. you play as the penitent one, exploring a twisted land called cvstodia, fighting grotesque monsters, and uncovering deep, sorrow‑laden secrets. pros: stunning pixel art and a haunting, atmospheric world. hard-hitting, rewarding boss fights and combat. lots of build variety through relics, prayers, and abilities. rich, dark lore that feels unique and deeply unsettling. cons: platforming can feel finicky and punishing at times. some instant-death traps and cheap spike placements frustrate players. backtracking is often required, and fast-travel isn’t super generous. the learning curve is steep; not super forgiving for newcomers. realistic score: ~8.5/10 — it’s not perfect, but for fans of challenging action-metroidvanias with incredible style and atmosphere, blasphemous is a deeply satisfying journey. most players are very positive about it, but be ready for a dark, demanding ride.

not just a game; it is an experience. developed by the game kitchen, this is a title that carves its own unique niche by seamlessly blending the tight, exploration-driven structure of a metroidvania with the brutal, pattern-based combat of a souls-like, all wrapped in one of the most striking and original aesthetic packages ever seen in the medium. it is challenging, grotesque, and at times unsettling, but for those willing to endure its penance, it is an absolute triumph.

this is an incredibly fun game. played it once i finished with hollow knight and it provided what i was yearning for, a challenge. the bosses are not friendly. the journey around cvstodia is not friendly. you will scream or wallow silently like i did multiple times but it will be fun. the music is a delight to listen to and the art/animations are phenomenal. exploring new areas instilled dread in me but became a breeze as time passed. many memorable moments both in boss rooms and exploration that i'd love to relive again but alas that is merely a dream. i will say, there were occasional glitches/bugs. they were thankfully humourous and not experience breaking. so heads up for those. but in all a good game. would recommend

balsamaceous is easily one of the best metroidvanias out right now. the dark, twisted lore adds so much depth to the experience, and the sense of mystery constantly pushes you to explore every corner of the map. the art direction is on another level—cvstodia is absolutely stunning. every area has its own unique beauty, and every enemy and boss is crafted with incredible detail. i genuinely enjoyed every moment of my playthrough. going for the platinum was a great experience too. it wasn’t overly difficult, but it had just enough challenge to keep things interesting while still feeling chill and enjoyable. overall, this is without a doubt one of the best metroidvanias out there, and i recommend it 100%. a true 10/10 experience.

blasphemous is not just a game, but a haunting and unforgettable religious experience delivered through gothic horror and stunning pixel art. it is a brutal, beautiful, and essential masterpiece for fans of dark fantasy. graphics and visuals: at the peak of modern pixel art. the world of cvstodia is a breathtaking nightmare of baroque architecture, grotesque monsters, and meticulous detail. the animations are fluid, impactful, and intensely visceral and stunning. music and sound: world-class. the soundtrack features mournful pieces with spanish and religious undertones, creating a heavy atmosphere filled with dread. the combat sound effects make the sword strikes feel weighty and responsive. mechanics and gameplay: a perfect blend of metroidvania and souls-like. the combat system is precise and unforgiving, emphasizing parrying, dodging, and correct timing. the use of the fervour meter for powerful abilities adds a strategic layer. exploration and narrative: the map design is clever and full of secrets. discovering shortcuts and new items is highly rewarding. the game's lore, conveyed through environmental details and item descriptions, possesses a terrifying depth and allure. conclusion: blasphemous is a triumph of artistic vision and uncompromising game design. it is a challenging but fair experience that is highly recommended.

never realised how underrated this is, very interesting story and world with amazing art to top it off. fun gameplay and full of small secrets and easter eggs, at first it can be difficult but relatively easy after your second and maybe third pilgrimage. recommended to anyone, as long as they unlikely to give up after dying twice lol.

it was fine. i'm really on the fence about this. the game is lifted up by its over-the-top imagery, intricate graphics, interesting level design, and delectably obtuse story & dialogues that practically beg a wiki to be written. but blasphemous is swiftly brought back down by the moment-to-moment gameplay, plagued by clunky combat & one-trick enemies. gameplay is king for me, and i just couldn't bring myself to see the game through when so many other more fun games are calling to me from my backlog.

i was really enjoying it at first, and i tried my hardest not to give up on it. but every minute of progression felt like it cost me ten hours of trying to figure out where to go next. i spent more time searching where to go than actually playing. tabbing out every second to look up guides, wandering in circles, and wasting time not knowing what the next step was just completely killed the experience for me. i wanted to love it but i just couldn’t go on anymore. what made it worse was the map. every time i opened it, it looked like a scribbled piece of shit paper drawn by a 7 year old arkham asylum patient. it’s genuinely one of the most confusing and unusable maps i’ve ever seen in a game. it’s a shame really, because the art, music, and atmosphere are all incredible. but when you spend the majority of your time lost and confused, it’s hard to appreciate the game.

story is nice, visuals are great but the gameplay itself is kinda bad in some areas. 1. no i-frames on dodge, so the game compensates by making the bosses easier 2. traveling on the map is horrendous until the very late-game, moving from one end to another just to spend more time in the game. now don't get me wrong, i like going back to the first levels and rediscovering stuff, but this game just makes you go from one end to another for almost nothing 3. no hints on how to unlock fast travel between respawn points 4. no way to know if you completed a room or even a zone 5. hardest zone is made overly difficult for no real reason and it feels kinda weird to be ready to fight the last boss but some random mob can 2 shot you, while the boss needs ~4-5 hits, without you needing to parkour around him 6. making a platformer time-based speed-run puzzle part of the progression but having janky controls (at least on the steam deck) is a big no-no from me: - for attacking to latch onto platforms, you can only do it in the exact location of the dedicated area. it doesn't matter if you are in the attack animation while in the zone or if you spam attack in the zone - regarding latching onto edges, you can't latch to all of them and it's not obvious which ones are latch-able. even when trying to latch, if you're in a different animation, you won't latch - death zone hit box is bigger than the graphical description (the spikes) and not consistent i'd only recommend for the story and visuals but not for the gameplay

i've had this game for 2 years and it's now become beyond playable. every time there's a new patch issued to "fix" the game, it becomes more unstable everytime i attempt to boot the game. i've attempted game file verification, clean reinstall/uninstall, and completely shut off all background programs, adjusted bios settings, and yet it still yields zero results. i’m running a ryzen 7 7800x3d rtx 4070 super with 64 gb of ram, and helldivers 2 is the only game that completely freezes my system — no keyboard, no mouse, gpu stops, and the only way out is to hard restart. i'll echo the previous sentiment shared: this is not a “performance issue,” it’s a critical system-level failure caused by the game or its gameguard anti-cheat. for a aaa-priced title, this level of instability is unacceptable and beyond disappointing. i strongly advise others not to buy it.

helldivers is an incredibly fun game, few other games scratches the same itch of coop pve. however, long story short, it's often a crapshoot whether the devs wanna make the game fun for the players, or follow their vision of the helldivers being grunts more than heroes. i love the game, but i hate the intentions behind some of these changes over these last two years.

the bugs are, to this day, game breaking. especially in the cities, tileset issues cause you to clip through and under terrain, where you get stuck, hitboxes desync from the enemies, damage done to the player feels wildly inconsistent, you can do the same action or face the same attack and take wildly different damage values. explosions are far wider in radius than their visuals would indicate. everything ragdolls you. weapons feel inconsistent and weak. enemy spawns seem capricious, spawning on top of you constantly. until and if they get their shit together, i cannot in good conscience recommend this game.

the game is good. the publisher is not. after finally bailing on playstation brand due to sony's progressive, insufferable incompetence and fully switching to steam, i decided to buy helldivers 2 again, since as i said, the game is good. however, sony managed to screw me over here as well. despite having the whole "link playstation account" thing set up, which was unnecessary and caused huge controversy and backlash back in the day, there is no form of cross-progression at all. the only things this linking accounts was mean to do. these fools can't get one thing right. after 200 hrs on ps5, i refuse to start from scratch, because of sony's incompetence. unacceptable.

extremely fun game; immersive, epic, and with tongue-in-cheek humour. gameplay loop is engaging and the battle pass system in the game is generous and free-to-play friendly. some say the balance is off-whack, but i think it adds to the more casual nature of the game. i have little qualms about the game itself; it is amazing and i applaud the devs for the years of development that went into this modern live-service masterpiece. with that said... the optimization is extremely subpar; game literally shuts down my pc with no bsod. helldivers 2 is the only game that does this on my setup. the game literally screws with the hardware of my computer, which mind you, is fairly beefy and was built a year or so ago as of writing this review. the anti-cheat in the game might also have something to do with this. also, 130gb+ storage space is appalling when on consoles it is less than half of that. its not worth saving 130gb of space on a game that has the potential to kill your computer without warning. i absolutely adore this game, but i cannot in good faith recommend it in its current state; not until the devs polish up the game. if you do buy this game, play with caution.

i loved this game in the beginning, even with its flukes, but now; i think one of my favorite studios has fallen to the power of capitalism when i thought it was for consumer fascism. shame on you, shame on your family, and shame on your cow!

boons do too little and don't synergize nearly often enough. you are entirely at the mercy of rng for a viable build or not. hitboxes are way too generous when you're being hit but way too precise when it comes to landing an attack. visually beautiful but good f***ing luck deceiphering what's happening behind 13,459 projectiles, aoes, and 20 different enemies with attack patterns all out of sync with each other. when the dust settles you will be a red smear on the floor and back to the beginning. no to mention all the times enemies move to a spot that cannot be reached or which makes them invisible thanks to the isometric view. in summary, it's a visually stunning mechanical nightmare. take your money to a casino if you want to gamble. at least in the casino you can win money. all you're going to get playing this game is high blood pressure.

don't have a history of playing hack and slash roguelites but gave it a go due to reviews and i liked the artwork. first ten hours were very exciting, but eventually the game turned into grind. a combination of things that i really disliked are: 1. it takes time to get to bosses that kick your ass and every attempt takes time and further you go, more i feel like i am wasting my time clearing first levels. 2. the game beats you by throwing a lot of sfx which makes it extremely difficult at times to see what's going on and react. combined with importance of life preservation it makes for a frustrating experience. 3. the deepest runs happen when i use weapons i am lukewarm to. combined with random boons that force gameplay style i don't enjoy a significant chunk of playtime turns into a chore.

as they say in french, "un pas en avant, 2 pas en arriere" (one step forward, two steps backwards). hades will punish you for getting better and stronger for no valid reason other than to strech its very short playtime. don't get me wrong, it's super addictive once you get the hang of it and it's fun to make and test various builds, boon crafting is a rewarding process. it's just that the game seems to have little frustrations implemented here and there for the sake of frustrating you. they're not narratively engaging or interesting. without spoiling much, after the grind when you finally feel like you have conquered a certain realm or biome, and you clear it up more consistently, it just suddently gets tougher for no reason and all your progression is thrown out the window, and you have to work your way up again, i suppose they did this because otherwise the game will be super short, like it would have 5 hours of content max, but with their little trolling system thy can squeeze 20 or 30+ hours of your time. so yeah, very fun and addictive gameloop, but i wouldn't recommend if you don't like unecessary hard difficulty. after 20 hours, i'm starting to feel a serious fatigue for this game that up until now was very engaging and exciting. after a 3rd or a 4th step down, i'm tired to go back up again cause what's the point? how long is this going to take... i may or may not continue. we'll see.

i grew up on halo. i've enjoyed its highs, loathed its lows; explored the many levels for skulls, terminals, super bounces, and everything in between. i appreciate what infinite has done for both its multiplayer and campaign after the massive departure from everything i loved in halo 5. its not easy in the current world to backtrack the direction you've been headed, accept the loss, and return to your roots. infinite does that in alot of ways while still trying to maintain some momentum and freshness it sought to bring to the more recent titles. honestly the game has alot going for it, but it really lacked forge on launch when player count was at its peak. community is what made this game memorable for so many of us, and not capturing that community by initially delivering a half baked product really hurt this game overall. enjoying it none the less.

i have a rtx 8gb on my msi laptop and halo says that the card is not supported. i run win11 25h2 and latest nvidia drivers that just updated and for about a year now this game keeps saying it cannot find my graphics card or that it's not compatible. i used to play this all the time on this laptop but something happened last year and now i can only play this on my ati rx580 desktop pc. so weird that the game supports a 10 year old card but not a 2 year old one. oh well, i can play it perfectly fine on xbox live on this laptop but something inside steam has ruined the game for my msi laptop and my macbook pro, both with rtx video cards. seems to be a common issue with nvidia drivers getting updated and the steam redistributable not being updated to match the vender drivers. steam is getting worse and worse since that ceo took over. good thing all the developers are releasing their own launcher for the latest games so i can bypass steam directly and actually play my purchased games.

i am the worst console game player ever - i can't get the controller to work for me, partially because i'm dislexic and a <rt> <rb> hint comes up and i have to work out which side is right). i also use the arrow keys to play pc games just to challenge myself... :d this game is so good when it comes to key binds and mouse key binds (i have an 11 button mouse) you can also toggle the runing, jumping, web swining to an almost automatic level, all you have to do it steer with a mouse. it makes me feel so much like spider man :) i have the difficulty levels right down, but as i play the game more i will either put them up or do i whole playthrough at a higher difficulty. i gave the controller a go, but when i tried to set up gameplay with keyboard and mouse - i found it worked like a charm. so many thanks to the developers. the looks great btw, i'm playing at 3440x1440 without any problems.

brilliant and relaxing traversal (web-swinging is amazingly fluid and fun), decently fun combat (albeit a bit easy and overpowered (even on the highest difficulty), but it's much more flashy and fun than the arkham combat), and a great last bit of story. the beginning of the game with fisk and the lack of a good showcasing of everything is a massive turnoff, though, and the sections where you essentially just run around and hide as miles or mj are very, very boring, to the point where i began to dread them arising. i also had some weird performance issues and bugs, at times. otherwise, this is surprisingly a very good game, and the end of the story allowed me to now somewhat like the character of spider-man (the final fight was also just very graphically beautiful, even if not very in-depth, engaging, or difficult).

swinging around the city is fun, but there’s some crazy stuff going on all the time. a lone civilian gets mugged in broad daylight by ten masked guys with crowbars and assault rifles. you fight enemies who randomly yell “sweep the area!” right in the middle of a brawl. drug dealers in balaclavas hang out on rooftops for no reason. and so on. i get it — game logic — but it’s a bit too much nonsense. as for the game itself, the story’s average, missions repeat, and there’s not much to do in the city besides photographing landmarks and collecting 55 backpacks — not exactly exciting. meh, 5 out of 10.

if you don't have this game already...don't bother unless it's on sale for cheap. spider-man is famous for his rogue's gallery yet the game barely scratches the surface when it comes to villains. there is no green goblin, sandman, hobgoblin, venom, kraven, vulture, carnage...the list goes on. and miles morales is introduced but nothing happens. the combat & gadgets are cool, the suits are nice, swinging through the city is nice as well....but after a few hours of game time, it just feels... hollow just buy it for cheap on sale. then, it will be worth it because the combat is fun when you unlock everything (which takes several hours)

this is one of those games i wish had a "maybe" option, it is not bad per se but there is so much filler content that for the most part isn't fun. the actual main story is pretty cool but seems rather short and if you're trying to do all the side missions for achievement purposes or just completion it takes forever to get there. i waited years for the original game to drop in price and just as it was starting to the remaster came out and the original was taken off steam and the price is back up to 60€. i finally caved and got it 50% off and was left with a lackluster experience, i expected something like a marvel version of arkham knight but this is nothing like it, the formula is the same but the world is just kind of .. empty and the character models are uncanny valley and flat. if you really love spiderman you might enjoy it but i suggest getting it on heavy discount, if you can't stand peter parkers constant lame quips and is hoping for some solid gameplay i say pass.

marvel's the amazing spider-man remaster is full of subliminal messages. here and there you can literally spot graffiti of a pyramid with an eye - which symbolises the corrupt elite that control society through manipulation and crime. this ties with the following points. the story with otto octavius and mayor osborne seems to suggest and follow the narrative that corrupt business men get away with stealing credit and reap the rewards from the real innovators and people who want to make a positive influence in the world. this reminded me of other real world cases such as nikola tesla and martin fleischmann. before becoming dr. octopus, otto is at risk of personality changes/ psychosis? when plugging in to the 4 armed machine to ensue vengeance against osbourne which implies that anyone that feels motives to target a corrupt person in power suffers from mental illness. this nonsense can be seen in numerous real life cases such as luigi mangione and charlie manson. to me, the game subtly hints at the idea that the powerful stay on top and people who raid their ivory tower are silenced and your job as spiderman is to enforce that. peter's motives at the end of the game are questionable and the game gives you no choice in the matter. ps. new york is unsettling. the whole play-through it felt like the devil's advocate. new york satanic

i've played the game for over 100 hours so you can take it that i can give an honest review on this game! hollow knight takes you through the difficulty curve pretty well and for me it was an amazing challenge. i've played cuphead before coming into this and the early game was easy comparatively. the late game bosses especially the dlc comprising of grim troupe & godhome was an exceptional challenge which i was looking for. there is a huge story behind the game and it's interesting, engaging and spikes your curiosity. the art style is beautiful and the music (bgms & ost) is amazing given the scenario at hand, there are many areas to explore which is amazing but can lead to finding specific stuff being a tedious chore (but you have plenty of guides online if you aren't into finding them yourself). overall the game is not for the faint hearted if you aren't used to dying a lot for the late game optional challenges (but that's what makes it fun!) but the base game is well rounded for most people. i'd recommend this to everyone who wants a challenge and an amazing story/lore unravelled about the world our little knight treads in.

i want to like it, but i just can't so many deaths feel cheap and out of place it's insane, it makes me rage quit every time. in most metroidvanias you feel powerful while remaining vulnerable and this game you just lose for the sake of losing. for how difficult the bosses are (<- that's good) benches are extremely far away (<-that's bad) you lose half your hp before you even reach them. and you can't even practice them in anyway before that. half of the journey is travelling to the boss rooms. the nail arts are so inapplicable in an actual combat scenario it's basically just there for show. you can hit them once per hard fight if your pre-prep it before you get there and that's.. that's it... backtracking is insane, and the fast travel is *extremely* limited. it is also extremely unclear where you should go in this game, one wrong step and poof enemies just delete you or you're in a boss room without even knowing. it reminds me of the snes times where you needed a booklet with a guide to backseat you the entire game. if you play aimlessly, like i did you backtrack and retrace steps way more than you actually play the game, it gets boring. playing with with a guide to backseat you also gets boring, but there is no other way to play.

i like and hate this game. was trying this multiple times. but was ever dropping it. i like this game's exploration a lot. metroidvania aspect is just amazing. it's super funny to open new ways, secrets, abilities, etc. but many gameplay aspects is created just to hurt you. there's no reason for bosses to have so much health. yeah, that's cool to solve boss. to understand it's moves, it's abilities. and be able to counteract it. but if you need to repeat this counteractions for about 5-10 minutes for a try - that's not funny, just frustrating. and especially if you need to run 5-10 minutes more from bench to boss. benches near hard episodes and less bosses' health and this game would be great. most toxic relationship of my life.

like many others say, the game is good enough until you realize how unforgiving the checkpoint system is. most reviews i see talk about this. you reach the first really tough boss, end up losing over and over again and are reset to a checkpoint that is miles away to walk all the way back and try again. this is a souls like game that instead of offering you retries, punishes you for dying. oh you lost? now walk all the way back from beginning. also you lose all your upgrades until you reach the point where you last lost. then hope you don't die again to waste more time traveling back to the fight again. it's a cute game, good music, good graphics, fun game play. awfully unforgiving checkpoint system with no retry option for tough battles. quality of life is very low on this game. i may not play again for a long time if ever. i've wasted my money.

honestly i don't get why this game is overwhelmingly positive. is it good? yes, but overwhelmingly? imo no. half if not most of the game is running around trying to figure out what you're supposed to do, i don't find that fun. i would have preferred to have directions or a hint on where to go or something. yes exploring is fun, but not when you spend most of your time going over the areas you've already been, running around trying to find what the next objective is. imagine gta v but without mission markers. it gets boring and annoying having to google everything. later on you can buy markers to put on your map. great! just mark where i've already been or where i want to come back, right? nope, you get a max of 6 markers (for each color) for whatever reason. ok i'll just remember where i've been, right? well, what happens when i don't play for a few weeks then come back? already forgot everything. then during boss fights, or i guess in general, if you die, instead of respawning nearby, you respawn at the last bench you saved at. it's not fun and frustrating dying and then having to walk all the way back while taking damage along the way. then there's also the fact that, for whatever fucking reason, in order to see where you are on the map you need to sacrifice a slot which could be used for other upgrades. same thing for automatically picking up dropped coins from monsters, like why aren't they just permanent upgrades? i'll probably still finish the game, but i wanted to share my frustrating experience for a supposedly top rated game.

[h1]insanely beautiful game with really satisfying gameplay[/h1] very immersive and fun to play, the story is good and the characters are well-written, but where the game really shines is just how beautiful it is - you could just make a screenshot with about any frame, and how well made is the gameplay itself (easy to learn, satisfying and i love how you can solve problems in various ways).

one of those games that deserve to be played for the story alone, though the world and machine designs are nothing short of marvelous on their own, with engaging combat with a lot of variety in weapons and tacticts and a good soundtrack. the game does get a bit repetitive after a bit and character designs, while pretty to look at, lack almost all facial animations, giving them a bit of an uncanny valley look, however the problem has been addressed first with the dlc and then in the second game, as well. an amazing action-adventure with a very unique story setting, can't reccomend it enough.

10/10. perfect game to play. interesting battle and character's ability upgrade system. different weapons effects and mechanics. battles difficult but interesting, even at the end of the game. good economic balance, resource crafting and item upgrade mechanics. friendly interface, comfort charachter control. awesome optimized graphics and visual. different territories and envirement effects - rain, wind, snow. interesting idea to mix mechanical beasts with spear and bow fighting. interesting story but it's a pleasure even just exploring the world. i've not played anything like that for a long time...

[h1][b] horizon: filler spawn [/b][/h1] a solid game, albeit not perfect. the game world and its backstory are well crafted, beautiful, and immersive. the creature design is bad ass, and so are some of the characters. others a bit less. the game inserts a lot of filler and repeated content though to artificially increase duration. i can't stomach these endless hunting challenges. the shop, crafting and inventory management systems are tedious, but at least the weapon variety is good. i tried to stick around a bit for the dlc after the end but it just felt like a bunch of chores after a short while. play it for the main story.

tldr; the environment is very pretty, but game is dogpiss. dont buy even on sale. in my opinion the only thing that was consistently positive in this game is the environment and the mechs. it is extremely pretty, even though sometimes it's blinding cos you can't turn off lens flare. and the mechs are sick as hell. - story seems interesting in the first few hours, and nothing actually happened during that and then at the last 10 hours they loredump heavily - combat is a little dogshit, the enemy has an invincibility window a couple of seconds after you crit them, so you never actually feel powerful even with all the upgrades you get. and the enemies just get tankier and tankier as the game progresses - most dialogue is trash, and aloy isn't a very easily likeable character. i think this was made during the marvel era sassy dialogue so she's consistently negative about almost everything. - the backseating on puzzles is insane. aloy would consistently tell us what to do before and during it. - and for some reason, to me some of the people are either grey or very yellow, but that could be my monitor being weird.

got a new computer, ready with snacks and drinks. could not finish the game. give multiple chances, could not finish the game. i was happy to know there was a pc port since i don't have a ps4. this is the first game that i want to like so hard but just cannot go through it. eh, maybe i'm a small minority of players that just cannot play the game. ~great things about this game~ awesome concept and world. great soundtrack and ambiance. great to test gpu performance. ~bad things~ exploration is on the threshold of between fluid and clunky. really 'bumpy'. gameplay is not engaging comparative to other action games (e,g days gone, far cry). dialog is so monotonous, i'm watching my phone most of the time. story was engaging at first but the dialog made it worse as the story goes on and it stagnates. the animation and characters are stiff most of the time except on key cutscenes. the people of the world doesn't feel "alive". many free to play games feel more "alive" than this game. i was willing to push through day's gone and wanted to do the same for horizon. to my surprise, i think day's gone is far better than horizon. for now, i think i'm going to play more day's gone. lmao. solid 5 out of 10.

it's an astonishing-looking game; no complaints about visuals. however, the story and the open world are quite lackluster. the writing is awful, and the open world feels empty and repetitive. sometimes i feel like they just create a map and then randomly throw in generic collectibles and side quests to make it feel alive, thus failing miserably. side quests are extremely boring and repetitive, and the optional objectives are an absolute waste of time. after a good amount of hours doing open-world stuff, i just got annoyed at the game and ended up rushing the story because i was just fed up with the world as a whole. not going to even bother with the dlc. if i have to summarize my experience with two words, it would be… once again: "boring and repetitive"

i recommend this game as an adventure game, i do not recommend it as a card battler. however, i bought this game because i love card battlers, so it gets a negative review. this game starts out pretty good. it's a decent card battler and the graphics are cool. then, the game starts incorporating different mechanics and it turns into more of an adventure game. this is cool at first too. then you start to realize the game is taking itself way too seriously. the actual card battle matches start to feel more and more shallow and tacked on. it becomes more about exploration and the story is trying its best at 4th wall breaks. it's unfortunate that the game starts out seeming like a promising card battler, because that's the best part of the game. after the first several hours, the game changes and only for the worse.

act 1 is the highlight, though with the card augments it becomes inevitable to win. the "puzzles" are thinly veiled stopping blocks and most the game just gives you the solution. act 2 was fine, though i felt like i just autowon any battle without really using my brain after a certain point. act 3 is a rehash of act 1 but pushes a painfully slogged, incremental-improvement mechanic that slowly pushes the player over the edge of a game that has light strategy, that can feel deep but the decision choices are few and lacks punch when the game checkpoints so frequently.

this game is actually much deeper than it first seems. i only got through the first act of the game then stopped. i found myself very frustrated by the rng, especially because the final fight is basically impossible without one or two boons you get right before, but you don't know the metrics you need to achieve to get those boons beforehand, and they're different each run.
propably the most overrated game i've ever played. act 1 was awesome, but the next two were nowhere near as good.

the game has a unique style. the music is atmospheric and can be a little boring. after playing this and slay the spire, i just don't like roguelike deck builders. if you like them , you'll like this game most likely. but, if you have played other roguelike games with permadeath and starting the game from the beginning, you probably won't like this game.

i do think this game is worth the price and was overall fun. i am leaving this negative so people who are actually looking to buy the game have a warning about something i wish i had known before i bought it. the game you see in the trailer is only about a third of the actual game. partway through your playthrough the game fundamentally changes. i won't say anything else, because i don't want to spoil anything. but just be aware that the game you are paying for might be a lot different than you expect. if you are willing to give it a chance, this is one of the weirdest, yet coolest, games i have played in awhile. but during my first run through i was pretty frustrated with how the game pulled the rug out from under me, and i think prospective buyers deserve to know that going in.

unfortunately, i'm gonna have to go with a "do not necesarily recommend" on this one. very much the family guy joke about the godfather "insisting upon itself" -- this game does exactly that. folks seem so convinced of its genius, but i found the "twists" and "turns" to be insufferable, the meta-textual nature of it boring and more than a little tryhard, and despite truly enjoying much of the core gameplay loops of act i and act ii, act iii and the "ending" require researching an arg to fully get there. even then, the juice is not worth the squeeze! there's a lot of promise here, i thought my time with this game was going a different way for most of it, but... man, i just cannot get past how wack it ended up being. even if it started so strong. also, i have no idea what people in other reviews are talking about with 'endlessly replayable" because mf no it is absolutely not lmao
act 1 is fun. i did not enjoy act 2 enough to finish the game. i ended up finishing the game. i only enjoyed act 1.

act 1 is pretty fun, even with some rng deaths, but i did get frustrated at one point and had to take a break. boy is act 2 and 3 not worth beating leshy. act 2 takes on a kinda lame 8bit graphics vibe and if you play undead deck it sucks, after smashing my head against every hard boss and relying on good old gamblobot (best card in the game). and then you get to act three, where the enemies spawn several cards that deal 6 damage a turn in total every turn and you start with 1 energy and get to play 1-2 cards that deal 0-1 damage and have 1-2 health for the first 4 turns until you get enough energy to play 1 card that is as good as the cards your opponents get to play every turn.
too grindy and repetitive enough it gets boring fast.

wish there was a middle rating. this is a good game with a lot of heart and passion into it. the problem: it decides it doesn't want to be a traditional card game, but rather try and tell a reddit-tier story and betray its solid art and atmosphere in the first part. the latter parts felt not as nearly as polished and thought through mechanically and felt uninspired to me aesthetically. you either like it or ya don't.
the card game roguelike aspect is ruined by forced losses for the sake of quirky internet video essay ah story progression and dogshit rng aspects

be warned, what you see is not what you get with this game. the 3d card game is a temporary act in the game, then it goes to a pokemon lookin 2d adventure with far worse mechanics and none of the charm the game had until then. i was enjoying what it was, but now i'm locked out of returning to the part of the game i actually liked, so that's where i'm done with it. i honestly can't recommend buying something that will tease you with a fun gameplay style just to rip it away and force you to slog through something that's not advertised or made clear at all. i loath this dev trend of mixing up gameplay styles with no rhyme or reason to it, it just comes across as "i had way too many ideas for the game than what i could be f***ed to animate so we're doing a 2d ags game now". its pretentious to act like we should have to play through the entirety of whatever slop is served to us when clearly one part is better than the rest by miles. i've never played undertale because that game looks like crap, i couldn't care less about the story, that can be enjoyed on youtube, the gameplay is what matters and it looks awful, and because i know that, i can make an informed decision based on my own tastes to not buy it, this game just shows you the part that looks good then pulls the rug on you just long enough into the game that you're passed the refund window. absolute bullshit.
this game is good but isn't a style for me, i can't adapt with the mechanics and is very rng dependent and this is very frustrating, this time i really dropping the game

the best game in history, the best series of the metro series, in my opinion, the graphics are very wonderful and the story is very beautiful. we play the role of a risk-seeking and risk-taking man named artyom, who always goes through many difficulties, including boss fights and facing strange creatures and enemies. in addition to these, there is a woman named anna who loves us with all her heart and thinks of us and puts herself in danger for us. it is a very good game, highly recommended, hashem's dlc is very useful and entertaining

you can really feel the level of care that went into this game. it's one of the last games released before the current ue5 slop era of gaming. the graphics are amazing, and very performant. i easily get 500 fps on 2560x1440 on the non-enhanced version. this level of performance puts any recently released game to shame. if you're looking for a fantastic story driven fps, this is one of the best. i recommend non-enhanced if you care about motion clarity, the enhanced version performs much worse and doesn't really look that much better. (i also recommend looking up how to turn off mouse acceleration and smoothing) fantastic work by 4a. it's tragic games are no longer made by people who care this much.
great trilogy, must play if you like metro

a balance of linear progression while keeping a open world experience choosing to crouch around enemies, row around them, run by them or fight them, theres a lot of similar experiences like that. the gun customization, different guns, the inworld map and having to pull out your backpack to craft limited items create an immersion like no other game.

an unforgettable post-apocalyptic journey metro exodus is not just a game; it’s an emotional journey through a ruined world filled with danger, hope, and breathtaking moments. from the very beginning, it feels like you’re living inside a real story. the characters are incredibly well-written, and every choice you make feels meaningful. the visuals are stunning. the open areas are rich with detail, each region having its own atmosphere—from frozen wastelands to dry deserts. the lighting and shadows are phenomenal, especially in dark tunnels or during sunsets over destroyed landscapes. gameplay is perfectly balanced: deep weapon customization limited resources that make every encounter intense a smooth blend of stealth and action atmospheric music that enhances every scene but the heart of the game is its story. it's emotional, human, and makes you feel truly connected to the crew of the aurora. even the quiet moments around the campfire are memorable and meaningful. metro exodus masterfully combines open-world exploration, a dark and immersive atmosphere, emotional storytelling, and exceptional artistic detail. it’s one of the best post-apocalyptic experiences you can have.

i thought escaping the metro meant i was done wearing a gas mask. i was wrong. turns out, the world is still a giant toxic mess, but now it's got more trees and fewer rats that look like tiny bears. this game is basically a post-apocalyptic road trip across russia in a train named the aurora.

pros: • good gameplay • large maps • high-quality graphics • addition of new game mechanics cons: • change in miller’s appearance • reworked mutant graphics appear already in moscow; the explanation of a “different type of mutation” feels illogical since we are still in moscow • save system – the game does save, but when loading it sometimes places you elsewhere or up to 20 minutes back, even though the save timestamp shows only 5 minutes ago (i'll probably get a bad ending because i don't have the patience to do it correctly five times in a row.") • miller has prosthetics from the start; it would be more interesting to first see him in a wheelchair and gradually show him getting back on his feet (could include 1–2 extra missions)

the game is a plain ok for me, followed by a couple of technical problems with it. first of all, it runs on a separate window instead of through steam which results in various crashes, when alt+tabbing for example. secondly, i couldn't roam the caspian level because the vehicle was stuck between desert particles; i was unable to move it and roamed through the level on foot. story-wise, there were a few enganging moments but nothing too serious nor it had the crisp of the other two installments in the franchise. side-stories, additionally, felt too detached and quite "empty". combat is mediocre with some erratic movements from the enemies. point-blank range can fail and for long-range there were no distinct physics that would result in avoiding the target (or maybe i couldn't identify them) the reason i uninstalled, and thankfully i played two colonels dlc first, is the autosaves that did not happen for half an hour in the sam's story dlc. that resulted in a huge loss of progress. however, that issue was not present in the main game and the flow was fine, overall, i would rate this as 3/5 and 2.5 with decimals allowed.

i have some thoughts about this game. in my opinion changing the chapter based formula to chapters are now open world with a small chapter between them wasn't good. it doesn't feel like metro to me. the hole game feels like some weird kind of story speedrun. you don't have time to bond with the characters on the aurora. you bearly know them and talk with them. i didn't have the time to start giving a crap about them. good example of the story being so fast is stepan and katya. it feels from my perspective like they just met and suddenly they are married! like what?! when?! why?! the game feels soo short. the things i liked were customization for guns and gun play. it has that feeling it had in 2033 and last light but made even better. the fact you can change the weapon parts freely whenever you want is an improvement in my book. summarizing the core gameplay was good and actually improved but the pacing was atrocious.

recommended ✔️ hours played: 40+ steam review: lethal company stands out as one of the most unexpectedly amusing and genuinely thrilling co-op experiences i’ve encountered in quite some time. it strikes an ideal balance between horror and humor — one moment, you find yourself stealthily navigating a dimly lit corridor, listening for any signs of movement, and the next, you’re shrieking as your friend inadvertently opens the wrong door at the absolute worst moment. the game’s lo-fi visual style surprisingly enhances the eerie ambiance without detracting from the enjoyment. the diverse enemy types keep each mission engaging, while the sound design is exceptional; if you notice something breathing behind you, it’s probably too late. what truly sets this game apart is its player-driven chaos. every session unfolds like a unique narrative: - there’s always that one person who gets overly ambitious for “just one more piece of scrap.” - someone inevitably forgets to secure the bunker door. - and there’s always a player left behind during takeoff. the replayability factor is immense, as even after numerous runs, i still find myself both laughing and feeling frantic simultaneously. if you enjoy cooperative gameplay, light survival elements, or shouting at friends while hurrying towards an extraction ship, this title is definitely worth purchasing. **10 out of 10 would willingly sacrifice my coworker again.

i will try to be very objective in this review. this game has brought me many hours of fun and enjoyment with my friends. however, i can’t turn a blind eye to the current state of things. the game, as it stands right now, is very lacking—no significant updates, extremely basic “changes,” and a complete lack of effort to keep players engaged. sadly, it seems to be heading down the same path as many other indie games. what i mean by that is it appears to be stuck in early access hell forever. it wouldn’t really be an issue if the game were free-to-play or sold as a complete product. my biggest gripe with all of this is that this is no longer a small project. the game has sold well and even had a collaboration with epic games. the means were there to continue developing the project and not leave players in the dark for so long. however, the predictable choice was to almost fully abandon the game and focus on other things while the game you paid for rots in early access limbo. in conclusion, as of right now, i cannot recommend the game unless it somehow gets back on track.

amored core is the 6th game in an entry where the last game was over a decade ago made by the people who made a game franchise that still gets used as an inspiration to this day. with that preface, do you like violence? do you like guns? do you like the feeling of cold hard cash after slaughtering anyone who gets in your way? do you enjoy a game where you can freely craft the perfect combat automaton to counter anything that gets in your way without commiting to a specific style? do you want a easy to follow yet deep story which is the polar opposite of how fromsoft handles all of their storytelling and lore in the souls series? do you enjoy making your gundam look like a ferrari? if you answered yes to at least 2 of the ones above, this game is for you. if not, go watch the keanu reeves vid, then come back to this.

this game has some of the best characterization via voiceacting ive ever seen in a game. the mechs are really fun, and the game is gorgeous, but the writing and fact they can make a character loved, pitied, or hated solely via nothing but comms chatter - that is the truly great thing about ac6. to put it simply - the characters in this game feel like actual people, that could actually exist, it has one of the most genuinely hateable antagonists ive seen in a game, a cowardly, selfish, arrogant man without a good bone in his body, but somehow, he isnt boring, or annoying, or over the top. he is just that - a man. the same could be said for the characters i love, who are like people that i would want to be friends with in real life. also, if you were like me, and prefer mechs like battletech/mechwarrior over more anime-ish mechs akin to gundam - still give this game a try. playing a slow lumbering mech is totally viable, and a ton of fun. nothing feels better just eating an enemy's strongest attack and watching your utter brick wall of a mech shrug it off, and then deleting them from existence. would reccommend for the writing alone, and doubly so if you like giant robots of any type.

i've been gaming for over 30 years and this is one of the rare games that i honestly can't find a flaw with. in terms of what it is trying to do in its genre, i would give it a 10/10. to give some context, i think i have only ever rated crono trigger, metal gear solid, and breath of the wild a 10/10 off the top of my head. that puts this game in rare company. that being said, i don't think it necessarily is one of the best games of all time, i just think it is a flawless game. everything from gameplay, the missions, layout and story are awesome. and honestly i think this is the literal best instance of how to do new game + correctly. it gives you a reason to replay the game while also dolling out tiny bits of new content while doing this. the only other game that might be a better instance of new game + is crono trigger and i put that as the best game of all time, so that is saying something.

armored core: fires of rubicon – review 8 armored core: fires of rubicon feels like a time capsule from the golden age of gaming—a reminder of when titles were tough, gameplay-first, and unburdened by fluff. its lineage goes all the way back to the late ’90s psx era, and that heritage shows: this is a game that knows exactly what it wants to be, and it delivers with confidence. visually, the game isn’t a powerhouse. graphics: 8 —nothing spectacular, but clean, stylish, and perfectly functional for the speed and clarity a mech game demands. the real star is the combat. gameplay: 8.5 —high-paced armored-mecha action at its finest. like the classic entries, it expects you to adjust your build for each encounter rather than brute-force with pure skill, and that philosophy is still part of its charm. the presentation hits solid notes across the board: sound: 8, with industrial beats and sharp effects that fit the world, and story: 7.5, a simple but compelling narrative that does more with restraint than many modern blockbusters do with endless cutscenes. if you’re tired of bloated open worlds and checklist design, fires of rubicon is a breath of fresh air. it’s focused, challenging, stylish—and the kind of game that can make you fall in love with the medium all over again.

great potential, terrible game... it's like whenever they give you a new item in the store, you must equip it or else the next lv powns your ass. what's the point in having customization if you are going to dictate the needed items? the controls are cumbersome and it feels like when you hit a button in an old fighting game, and the character then does a 3-10 second scene with the move set. not responsive like a good mech game should be. i haven't played a mech game in a long time, and i was looking forward to this and tried really hard to like it, but yea... the potential is there, but it has some major flaws that make the game so it plays more like a scripted mindless grind iuno. if anyone is interested in fixing this game i am more than happy to help because it could be and should be awesome, it just feels like its another title that has gone for shiny over playable maybe? controllers could probably use some love on this one too, but that's just a preference not a game flaw.

not sure if i don’t like the game or if i don’t like that this is not what armored core used to be back in the day. so take my review as a failed attempt to manage my own expectations. unlike in the older ac titles where strategic planning and resource management were still a thing, ac6 focuses more on mechanical execution of combat maneuvers, dodge timings and overall button pressing technique. the stagger mechanic rewards ultra-aggressive combat style over any type of cautious approach, meaning that the action is extremely frantic all the time. you can spam all your weapons simultaneously and most of the time an effective combat approach is just to mash all four weapon triggers without thinking. failing a mission is not usually caused by your build or miscalculated strategic approach but more often just a consequence of wrongly timed button presses and badly executed combos. mech parts you regret having bought get fully refunded when sold and the only penalty of failing a mission is the annoyance of having to replay the mission again. this is underlined even more with the very forgiving checkpoint system, which on the other hand is really mandatory due to the overtuned boss encounters. having no consequences for bad decisions means that there is also no incentive of getting invested in planning. the linear story is expressed through brief and meaningless radio chatter that supposedly tries to be cool and serious but ends up being deeply embarrassing to mature audience. if you want to have another action game influenced by the new generation from software games but this time with a mech reskin, go for it. if you are looking for the classic armored core experience, there is a high chance that you will be disappointed.

armored core as a franchise has gone through distinct eras with numerous changes/differences between them. just because you liked the games from one era, it doesn't mean you will like the games in other eras. i liked the original era and had mixed feelings with the two eras that followed. i hated the fourth and fifth eras. this game is another new era. it has borrowed mostly from the fourth and fifth eras with some compromise with other eras and chunks inspired by systems from other fromsoft titles. i found it to be a miserable, ugly experience. movement felt bad, combat felt bad, and every aspect of the game's visual and audio design was unpleasant. i need to accept that this franchise has long been done with me, and i need to be done with it.

in many ways, the work of a critic is easy. we risk very little, yet enjoy a position over those who offer up their work and their selves to our judgment. we thrive on negative criticism, which is fun to write and to read. but the bitter truth we critics must face, is that in the grand scheme of things, the average piece of junk is probably more meaningful than our criticism designating it so. but there are times when a critic truly risks something, and that is in the discovery and defense of the new. the world is often unkind to new talent, new creations. the new needs friends. last night, i experienced something new: an extraordinary game from a singularly unexpected source. to say that both the action and its consequences have challenged my preconceptions about fine decisions is a gross understatement. they have rocked me to my core. in the past, i have made no secret of my disdain for life is strange's famous motto, "this action will have consequences." but i realize, only now do i truly understand what it meant. not everyone can become a great artist; but a great artist can come from anywhere. it is difficult to imagine more humble origins than those of the genius now working at life is strange, who is, in this critic's opinion, nothing less than the finest developer on steam. i will be returning to life is strange soon, hungry for more.

if you like games that take away your agency / control frequently and for long periods of time (multiple minute) with cut-scenes that you can't skip even on 2nd play-thrus and feel very disruptive to your gameplay so that the developers can better tell a story, then you might enjoy this. if you like having "guns bad" and similar ideology subtly pushed at you, you might enjoy this. if you like having characters that (when you can actually control them) move at the pace of a elderly, disabled snail travelling uphill in the dead of winter, then you may enjoy this. otherwise, it'll be a matter of how much you can tolerate those things compared to the quality of the story experience. story was ok - i tend to be a big fan of time-travel themes, the rest was so-so. that said, the frequent, slow, and long cinemas that kept taking away my agency for extended periods really soured the overall experience for me. also, just to be clear there are bits of dialog that you can skip, but only after you have listened to the slow version once and then rewound time (and that's per play-thru so if you start over, then you still need to listen to the slow clip once before you can skip it). also, while that applies to most dialog, it seemed like there were a few lines here and there that you couldn't skip and you definitely could not skip the cinemas that played at the beginning and end of each chapter as well as during whatever random story point they felt like. disclaimer: i was gifted this by another steam user. afaik, neither of us have any affliation w devs/publishers.

the honest & candid comment from me is life is strange 2 is an absolutely breathtaking narrative experience that blends powerful storytelling, heartfelt character development, emotional depth, and beautifully crafted choices into a journey that stays with you long after the credits roll! additionally, the choices in this game carry weight unlike anything i’ve experienced in other narrative titles, with every action shaping not only the story but the very person daniel becomes, creating a truly powerful sense of responsibility & connection. furthermore, every episode feels like a meaningful chapter in a beautifully told story, filled with real emotion, relatable struggles, moral complexity & a heartfelt exploration of family that elevates this game far beyond a typical choice-based adventure.

spoilers ⚠️⚠️⚠️ stunning game, and i love how the models are made like legos, especially the hair, the lighting and environments are simply lovely what a heartbreaking journey and characters development through all the twists and turns that they take. you get to visit many different locations which is sometimes jarring to transition between chapters, but it offers variety as well. sean is a great protagonist that has to assume the role of being both a parent and a brother after tragedy strikes, daniel is the perfect annoying younger brother, and i know that will put some people off but this is what having a sibling is like. i opted for the "happier" ending since i didn't want our journey to be for naught it's quite a heavy game emotionally, and there are some mild issues with pacing imo with how long of time is spent on certain areas vs. others, but i would love to play through with some different choices in the future and get all the collectibles. i recommend this game on the basis that it's a great story, with some fun choices, yes there are some moments that are frustrating but overall i grew to love the characters and the story they've given us. and i especially believe it has relevant materials in it which i am sympathetic to, and is important to pay notice to.
