i really enjoyed the first life is strange. it sucked me into the world and the characters. i felt there was definitely some jank in involved in the game and the dialogue, but overall it really worked for me. this one didn't. i'm not sure if its because the main characters are younger and i had a more difficult time getting invested in them because a lot of the choices that were made by the characters and by the player felt childish or that the story just didn't connect with me, now i know the leads are children here, so the childish responses and choices make sense for these characters, but it doesn't change the fact that it really felt frustrating watching them make bad choice after bad choice and then giving me the option between 2 or more bad choices. now with that said, its not terrible, it just didn't connect with me. the music is still good and the art style is still the same as the first life is strange, so those are both points in favour of the game. i feel this game has less “game” to play. it felt even more like just watching the game this time around. when there is so little gameplay, the story really needs to hit and i just didn't find the adventure was as interesting as i would have liked it to be. it's not a terribly in depth review, but i really don't have all that much to say about the game. i started to lose interest in chapter 3 and the rest of the game i was just waiting for it to be finished so i could move on to the next game.

i’ve played through all the previous parts. compared to them, this game feels so much worse when it comes to story and emotions. it could still be decent, but it’s stuffed with in-your-face woke propaganda. you can see it most clearly in the way the characters are written. it’s full of old, worn-out clichés. almost everything here is black-and-white. people opposing mass migration are shown as xenophobes and fascists, or at best just rude and nasty to others. on the other hand, anarchists, hippies, gay people, and those living in communes are always nice, smiling, and cool. anyone tied to the church has to be a villain, or at least a brainwashed lunatic with no will of their own. in the end, of course, the church has to burn. migrants and minorities are always portrayed as good guys and victims. people protecting their country or opposing migration are painted as thugs. the border fence is “evil” and must be torn down to save the heroes. there are also layers of symbolic references placed throughout the game. for instance, the main character bears a symbol of baphomet on their sleeve. overall, the impression is that the game is designed less as a story-driven experience and more as a vehicle for conveying progressive ideas. after a while, it becomes difficult to ignore the sense that this message takes precedence over the narrative itself. it’s disappointing, especially given the studio’s earlier achievements. sad. dontnod, enjoy yourselves without me.
i'm sorry, but... this game is disappointing, and it had so much potential. 4/10

to be honest i'm dissapointed by this game. it gives you the delusion of choice, but forces you to "do the right thing" by all the narrative around. i'm not happy only how poor power of the daniel was but how it's all been developed. no one cares about sean except some of the later events in the dessert. only repeating how he have to be the adult one and protect brother and such. the game forces you to put priority of daniel's happy first no matter what. that's stupid. game of choice without a choice to be honest. to more technical stuff - damn, this game bugged more than i expected, just because i moved a bit too quickly from the place, cause i didn't hear the next dialogues starts... like wtf, i had to reload checkpoints few times, that was annoying. anyway, for me this game is kinda 5/10. it touches tough topics and they're showed without feeling that they're forced too hard, but overall the story wasn't that great for me. it had some good moments, but a lot of choices were forced to get it daniel's way and i don't get it how people love his character. he was such annoying brat, that i would leave behind if it was an option in early stage of the game and just run away alone if i was at sean's place. i'm surprised that i forced myself to go through all episodes.
max and chloe solo i'm afraid.

i don't recommend this. it's my first experience with this franchise, and since there's very little fun in the gameplay, it's all down to the story. and overall, that gives me more negative feelings than positive. even the ending can't make up for that.

first game i decided to play in 2025. given that lis 1 was an ok game i gave it a go. damn it was a rough one. the writing just doesn't make sense, the characters are borderline sociopaths or in daniels case a narcissistic sociopath, the voice acting is terrible and the story has way too many holes. overall the game felt like a drag since episode 1. even if the game is free i would suggest you to do something better with your time. only play this game is you are paid to do so. 0/10 and definitely in the top 5 worst games i've ever played in my life.

there's something missing in this game when compared to it's predecessor. the first one was amazing, the main character, most characters, intriguing story, cool power mechanic... plot twists... but in this one i got bored and annoyed. even true colors, that was a bit woke, was much better and intriguing. i just don't feel invested like in the others.
this game didn't grab me as much as previous life is strange games. after finishing the first episode, i had mixed feelings. i honestly don't think it's worth the time.

i wanted to recommend this game so much. while there were moments i really enjoyed, overall i feel it’s a step down from the first game. despite sean and daniel’s story seeming like it should have more emotional impact than sam’s in the first game, it just didn’t connect with me. the game ends in one of two ways, neither of which feels particularly satisfying: sean’s life is either ruined by surrendering and going to prison, or he escapes to mexico by forcing his way across the border (at least, those were the options presented to me). while reaching mexico is the goal of the game, there isn’t enough shown of their arrival to make it meaningful. the brothers deal with some gang trouble, then have a beer and look at the ocean. there’s no real follow-up on lyla or other supporting characters like jacob or brody, who helped the brothers along the way. it feels like there should have been an epilogue to show more of their new life, but instead we get maybe two minutes at most at the end, and that’s it. a bit of a let-down, considering how much i liked the first game. i’ll probably give the next game a go, but i doubt i’ll replay this one, and i don’t think it’s a title you need to rush out and buy.

its not a bad game. but it is quite frustrating at times and i can't recommend it. most choices dont really matter, each episode we meet quite cool characters but we go to a new location in the next episode and don't see those characters again, so your choices with them dont really matter. this game is god awfully slow most of the time and i wish cutscenes weren't so long and dragged out. tbh, i was bored alot of the time. but, overall the story is good, its just not implemented well and struggles with pacing issues. the characters are mostly good but they don't have that much impact on the story.

the "choices" are all fake, and dont change the outcome at all. and not just the final ending, it doesnt changes the literal next thing. "do you wanna fight this guy or go away?" both options leads to them fighting xd xd its like that with every single choice in the game

i had this game wishlisted for years and was pretty excited to play it but i'm really not comfortable with being forced to play a 16 year old boy that's talking so casually about sex with his friends. i want to say it's predominantly the age that's an issue for me, but maybe it's just that i don't want to see or experience that being demisexual myself. i looked it up and there are forced sexual scenarios later in the game as well. overall this might be fine for most people, but i don't think i can enjoy the story because it's just stuff i really don't want to see/experience.
game is over a decade old and won game of the year. what possible reason could you have for reading steam reviews of it rn?

bioware created something that, despite a tempest of setbacks and obstacles during development, is truly a work of art. even if you think this game does reflect those issues i truly think that the passion, love and talent poured onto it overshadows and compensates anything that could've been improved given more time and freedom. the writing is just stellar, with characters that have been developed to a point that they can rival any others in traditional literature or art cinema. no game can be perfect and there's so many more standards to be met when something isn't the first in a franchise, but when we speak of a game's quality there needs to be an aknowledgement of how almost 100% of time capitalism maims talent and intention to varying degrees. this game is something beautiful that speaks through that noise. one of my favorite games of all time.

so far so good, it is easy to get into there is a lot of lore to get through, but if you are not into it you can easily skip everything and just focus on gameplay. focus seems to be on exploration. the world is vast and you can hardly walk in any direction for longer than 10 seconds without running into something.

the game would be so much better without the wicked eyes and wicked hearts quest. this quest completely destroyed my ability to feel joy, or even to feel anything at all. aside from that, the game is quite fun, turns into a mini game of thrones simulation mid game

not as good as previous dragon age games, clearly. but it's a great place to start the series if you are a bit screamish about playing old games. major bugs that have been in the game since launch that make some minor quests unplayable. this game could've been so good if they had just polished it a bit more.

i played this when ps4 first came out, it's really great to come back and replay it! it aged really well and there's some stuff i missed in my first playthrough. i'm replaying to get ready to play veilguard.

this game has a very different feel to it than the first two dragon age games, but it's still enjoyable nonetheless. the characters are well written, it has some awesome diversity representation within the game, and the new world style allows for hours and hours of playing. it did take some getting used to after the first two games, however. i also love seeing my choices from the first two games make their way into the story here. overall, even though i enjoy the first two games more than this one, i would still recommend this one.

started my dragon age journey with origins less than 2 years ago and this series quickly launched into my favorite series of all time. inquisition continues to rise up the ranks to reach my favorite game of all time. everytime i play i hear new dialogue, new reactions based on my party comps. i love this game so much and i just can't stop playing it.
loving it so far. have played the other dragon ages and loved them all
yes, but boy is it glitchy! long-ass game, very grindy to start. i did really enjoy trespasser though. very cool story. some of the cut-scenes didn't make sense either but perhaps that's my 'tism.

an end of a great era in gaming history. amazing game
truly i adore this game and most things about it . it is also often unplayably bad and broken . its so awesome . i love dragon age
one of the best games i've played!
great graphics,the gameplay is great,and the story is great!

so i had this game back in the day when it first came out but never got to sit down and actually finish the playthrough. i am a few hours into the game and have been having fun. no pressure from online play just good ole play the game. i am enjoying the graphics and storyline so far. i'll update at a later time once i have had a more in depth playthrough. overall right now fun games and enjoyable graphics and story.
flawed, but my favorite game. & trust the trespasser dlc is worth it

probably the best game i’ve played in a while. sure the graphics aren’t extremely fancy and there’s no hair physics but the story over looks all of that. quite literally hours of fun and guess what 160 hours in and i still haven’t finished my first play through!!! if you want a great game with a phenomenal story telling and characters that’ll get you invest in not only the main story but in their lives, interests and who they are as a person, get dragon age inquisition!! if you want fancy graphics and hair physics, get the veilguard….

dragon age inquisition is arguably the best out of the four dragon age games in 2025. although, origins come very close. the latter only losing out for me because of technical improvements in inquisition (and these happen to be important for me). that being said, this game has several flaws, though most of these are only 'optional' in the sense that they don't affect progressing through the main story. the good: [list] [*]story [*]dialogue [*]voice acting [*]controller support (of course this is only important for those who prefer to sit back and use a controller) [*]some of the supporting characters [/list] the bad: [list] [*]side quests are often pointless and for the sake of being there [*]navigating the world can feel tedious and a waste of time (esp. hissing waves, forbidden oasis, the deep roads) [*]personally, i feel like the combat is mostly a matter of stats (gear) rather than tactics [*]way too much elements of grinding that become super tedious and repetitive (with crafting materials, gold, and prestige) [/list] in summary, this game has an extremely well written story, with believable dialogues and character interactions. there are also a lot of tedious pain-in-the-arse game-design choices that can make you feel like you're grinding half the time, rather than enjoying whatever the game has to offer. there are some very nice immersive moments with the taverns and towns, but most of the world feels barren and somewhat nonsensical.

this was my entry to the dragon age series back in 2016 and still i consider it one of my favorite games. i love the plot, environmental and costume design, and the companions are lively and wonderful. my favorite companions are solas, sera and cole, and i consider solas to be one of the best written character in videogames ever. many find the main antagonist lacking, and i can see their perspective, but i love evil old men and body horror so corypheus striked a chord with me. the locations are absolutely beautiful and mesmerizing and i found myself just taking a pause between quests and admiring the view. the fightings are quick and fun and the abilities are really satisfying, especially when playing a mage or a bow-and-arrow rogue. the politics part of the game is also really intriguing. the plot deals with religion, faith and personhood, and the toll it takes to be a chosen one (namely, the obliteration of personhood). the lore is beautifully woven into the plot, and it is so satisfying to uncover ancient mysteries, especially in the trespasser dlc. overall the game is a wonderful experience. also sera is my wife!

amazing game! the graphics are beautiful, the story is compelling, the characters are well-written, and the gameplay is fun. love the fact that there are romance options too. if you love baldur's gate 3 and haven't played this yet--what are you waiting for? top 10 game of all time for me--for sure.

absolutely love this game. the graphics aged well imo. its pretty, characters are not cookie cutter nice to each other. some like others and some don't like others. the areas are vast, beautiful, and filled with lore and side content that'll keep you busy. the story has good twists. the character leveling and creation is fun and the optimization is good. the story pace is almost up to you. if it feels slow you can just speed it up by doing the story missions, it doesnt force you to do them. overall i love this game.
amazing game, still playing it after 10years

took me 3 trys to like this game just cause dragon age as a series always changes. story was alright with a couple nitpicks here and there. still hate having a dialogue wheel since it takes me out of my immersion. combat felt so bad and leveling up felt so unrewarding with the skill you get to pick. overall mid dragon age game this series gets worse with every entry.

[h2]summary[/h2] back to the roots of dragon age [h2]the good[/h2] - deeper story lines - lore that is interesting - combat relatively smooth [h2]the bad[/h2] - still some bugs, including quest breaking ones - decisions are not as important as dao [h2]the deets[/h2] after the brain numbing slog of dragon age 2, this was such a treat. the developers realized what made dao special and tried to bring back what was lost. overall, i still think dao is a better game. the decisions you make in it have far reaching effects and it feels like it matters. characters are flushed out better and are more worth investing into. however, dai shines in its combat that is smooth and fun to play around with to figure out new unique ways of playing. hey, they must have done something right if i 100% this game and not da2.

a genuinely great rpg with some minor pain points. a solid 9/10. i loved the story, and i feel like they did justice to the characters both old and new. overall the story has a much bigger scale than i expected, with some pretty epic twists that keep you engaged through the whole journey. visually the game looks great, even in 2025. frostbite engine was way ahead of its time and does a great job with the wide variety of environments and cool lighting setups. it helps that the art direction and tone is very coherent and fits the dragon age's gritty world. (unlike you know which game) the combat is decent, but the controls are a bit clumsy and can take a while to get used to. i mainly played as a mage and a bit with a rogue. rogue was surprisingly fun, having a parry mechanic is neat af! and i loved that the game doesn't hold your hand for most puzzles, the characters don't mumble the solutions to you if you're stuck for longer than 10 seconds, and a lot of the puzzles were very fun to solve! on the downsides, the open world bloat is a bit excessive. especially the shards, massive amount of effort for a practically nonexistent payoff. i love my open world side content, but it needs to have more variety and a more balanced effort/reward ratio. the ending left me excited for what's to come, and hopefully one day we'll get a true and faithful sequel to this very cool game!

maker's breath, have i played this game a lot... i have hundred of hours on it on x-box. i bought it on pc to see how it fares with some mods, but unfortunately the ea app is quite spoiling the experience so i didn't get far. i know the opinions are divided and i cannot comment on how this one relates to the previous two games as i haven't played them, but as a stand-alone it is brilliant. i play for the story, the characters, the world and it delivers it all. the combat is just a get-through for me and this game allows me to easily complete it with just the minimum of strategic effort. the world is beautiful, the characters are rich and varied, the storyline is engaging and the lore is expansive. some might say that this game tried to be a lot to a lot and it was its downfall, luckily for me it delivered just in the right places to make me fall in love with it. yes, it's absolutely not perfect, but what is?

i didn't play this back when it first came out; it looked too different from dragon age origins, which i loved. in hindsight, it was the best dragon age sequel we were ever going to get... way better than veilguard.
mod the hell out of this game cause there is way too much bloat. once you are past it... you'll have a damned good time.
takes a minute to get interesting but it does. i like being able to take control of the different party members for added variety.
penis gameplay, had more fun setting the max fps to 1 in the console than actually playing it

this review is 30 hours into the game. so i'm playing this game for the first time in 2025 as i was looking for some open world fantasy rpgs that are not complete garbage. i haven't played origins or da2, so this is my first game in the series. the goods are the graphics are nice and still hold up, and the companions are interesting. the story being a political epic in a fantasy world is not bad either. but the gameplay, oh god. it is extremely boring and dull. it feels like you are playing world of warcraft except it is single player and there way less spells and skill. it is literally and single player mmo where you run around the world collecting and gathering resources. the rpg is the choice to be a tank, dps with 2h or with 2 daggers or with a bow or with magic (cold, lightning, fire). that is it. your choices barely affect anything. again i've just played 30 hours, i don't know if it gets much different later on. there armour and weapons are simple and boring. the crafting system is as basic as it can be. so overall the game is not bad, but it is boring. 6.5/10.
fuck ea. do not support this fucking company. get their games "the other way".

i know it’s an amazing game, but i don’t have a pc/keyboard, which has made gameplay frustrating as it isn’t compatible with the steam deck. will revisit this review when i get the controller options right, but as of now, i do not recommend if you don’t have a keyboard 😢
i played for 9 hours and everything seemed fine, i closed the game. now it won't even boot up.

holy overrated. i've played da:o through multiple times da:2 multiple times i even full cleared veilguard i have tried and tried and tried to play this game but it is just *so* bad. the combat is the worst in the series. the game started as an mmo and you can tell. the terrible fetch quests and pointlessly large maps were clearly an artifact of the devs having to scrap their plans for an mmo and change it to singleplayer. you get a horse to make the travel slightly faster, but it handles like it's drunk. the companions range from mid to awful. solas is cool but wasted on this game. the "inquisition board" game mechanic has real time counters where you send your troops on missions, but it's miserable and has to be modded out for the game to be playable. the writing is actually decent, but the game is just *so goddamn awful* that i don't care. i am honestly baffled how this won goty. again, i love the da series, i've played every other entry start to finish, some multiple times, but i have tried to play this game on four separate occasions and i always stop before even getting through the first act, because it's simply unbearable.

played much of the side quests and took several breaks. ea just ruins the experience with the launcher. all of the male voices are annoying. various errors have me trying to reinstall. wish i had just kept the money. can't see why someone would be reading reviews at this point, but not recommended for anyone.

the system interface is awkward and uncomfortable. although there are brief tips on how to do things, key details, such as how to add your new skill to the number on your keyboard, are not included. the movement keys on keyboard are awkward. i was able to adjust the steps to wasd, but i have to turn the camera by using other keys (left or right only, not up or down) or by right-clicking and dragging with my mouse, which is exhausting after awhile. i just want to move the camera with my mouse without clicking on anything and have my character move accordingly. using a first-person view would simplify matters even more. skyrim, which came out a few years before, has much better controls compared to this game, but the creators do not appear to have learned from their rivals. this game gives the impression it was designed for controls other than the keyboard, and adjustments weren't made properly when modifying it for pc. the layout could easily be adjusted to give players an easier time creating characters. the options for darker skin all look terrible, even after adjusting the complexion. although the option for elves shows a card with blue-skinned characters and no nose bridge, those options are not available at all in the character creator, making them misleading. the subtitles don't work, so i missed quite a bit of dialogue. the game does win some points for animating the bow, which i've found to be rather rare bonus in games.

unplayable. the series is ruined! this is very unfortunate because the first 2 games were 2 of my favorite games of all time. with how annoying this game is to play, my journey ends here. i hate the controls and the open world design and things are so hard to figure out. screw this game! a younger me would have probably trudged through it - but i'm 36 now and with all the bs i've experienced in life, i refuse to force myself to play games that suck.

maybe remove the ea launcher on steam bought games just a thought... it breaks compatibility with linux. funny how the first game i ever played on linux was dragon age origins before even proton was an idea and now games don't even launch

worst crpg ever. semi-linear, as progression is walled by map regions. just a bunch of "go fetch" missions running you all over. combat sucks, cameras are awful and controls are borderline unplayable. graphics are crap, runs like crap. this game has no redeeming qualities and is not worth the time it would take to download nor the 40 gigs on your drive. and certainly not worth the money. i will not waste another moment of my life on this earth trying to play this game, and neither should you.

o game e ok, poŕém não recomendo comprar nenhum game da ea, não enquanto continuam forçando esse lixo de ea app. todos os jogos que normalmente são tranquilos de rodar acabam ficando uma porcaria por causa desse lixo de ea app

it's definitely the worst out of original trilogy. the only good this about this game it's its visuals, it still stands and looks okay in 2025. other than that it is hard to find something good. combat is clunky and buggy, line level writing is meh, main plot is terrible (especially the main villain in a style of "palpatine returned, again"), the worst mount mechanics in history of games and a lot of padding content. like 90% of the game is meaningless padding and war table shenanigans only makes immersion worse. a did i forget to mention the atrocious loot system? 99% of the stuff you loot is basically useless, game economy is stale and you can barely find anything useful from vendors with money becoming meaningless very quick, so the only gear is worth wearing is either crafted one(crafting system was surprisingly not bad), boss drop or atrarium treasure(atrarium mini-games were somewhat enjoyable). companion cast is also disappointing with only worthy mention of duo of cassandra and varric, but even their chemistry is mostly the merit of dragon age 2 above all else. the fact that choices from previous games are either ignored or dragon age keep is not functioning properly anymore also added a grain of salt. into the depths dlc was okay, although other two felt like torture. glad it's finally over.

imagine pouring countless hours into dragon age: origins and dragon age ii—crafting your own story, making tough choices, grinding through quests, tackling every dlc—only to discover that when you move on to the third game, none of that effort carries over. instead of importing your hard-earned world state, you’re forced onto a webpage to manually recreate your past, with limited options that don’t even cover everything you actually did. and this isn’t years later when memories fade—this could be just weeks or months after finishing the first two games, and you still have to piece it all back together. then, to make things worse, you go to play what is mostly an offline single-player game, and if ea’s servers are down, you simply can’t. it’s frustrating to see so much player investment treated as disposable, especially in a series praised for its choices and consequences.

review_text: i would say it's a yes and no for recommending. yes because the story, scenery, music are phenomenal. game has made me cry a couple times, the characters are so endearing, and for being a fantasy mmo the story line is incredibly solid (nowhere near as convoluted at wow). no to trying the game if you do not like korean mmos. i say this because korean mmos are notorious for having end game content rely heavily on spending real money or grinding the shit out of everything making casual play hard. if you know this going in at least for me it made it less of an issue. i hate the system but i knew what it was when i started so i can't complain for willing getting myself into this.

genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Free To Play
review_text: it's my first, and probably only, mmo. i really like the gameplay, which is intuitive and dynamic compared to other mmos i've seen online where you have a stationary character and attacks. graphically speaking, it's extraordinary, with a great style (although it could do with some optimisation). the story has really grabbed me even if its the classic "hero chosed by destiny" thing, everything builded around that idea is amazing. i don't miss a single piece of paper so i can find out every little detail, and when i can, i don't skip any cutscenes (and i don't do it in every game). the progression system is a bit slow, it's true, but it's not as bad as everyone makes it out to be, especially with all the improvements they've made over time. gatekeeping exists, but all you need to do is join any discord dedicated to the game to organise yourself with other new players and learn the various raids. you just need patience in the game and you can do anything.

review_text: game is mixed bag. it has good stuff like combat, raids, sounds and animations, but also tons of bad stuff like terrible progression systems, non existent gameplay outside of raids, p2w, nonstop fomo events and intentional time wasting in leveling. overall i would say its like 20% good and 80% terrible to just try piss you of/make you swipe. i played f2p till current raids and feel like it was manageable with events, but now at endgame its just doing 2 hours of raids/paradise and having nothing else to do. they say you can play only 1 character, but even with full gold earning roster you barely have game you can sink teeth into. there is time wasting like dailys etc, but those can be done in couple minutes eyes closed, which is sad. everything has been calculated that you will never catch up the spenders or veterans without swiping. it could had been great game and i'm happy that i tried it before it inevitably dies after kazeros. most of my playtime is idling as game takes like 5 minutes to start even with new computer.

i have not done a complete playthrough on pc yet as i have only just started the first game, but i have put more than enough hours on console to leave a review here. the trilogy are my favourite rpg games to date. the first game might be difficult for some people to get into as it is extremely slow, but trust me, the rest of the games are worth it. the choices you make drastically effect the progress/ experience of the current game and the next game in line. the combat, exploration, dialogue and soundtrack are fantastic. it does make you very immersed. the remastered graphics are very well done and you do not need a nasa spec pc to make this game look incredible. the dlc included with the le are also great but it is a shame the me3 multiplayer never was imported to this version. i have been recommended by one of my mates to play this game with mods to change my experience. a player called synth has made a modpack which has very good feedback for any of you are interested - https://youtu.be/7eqg9fdclcm?si=kekdwwzu_ng_i6v4

i have finished playing the game through at the time of writing this review. and i have very much enjoyed this game. from starting the first game and learning through talking to all sorts of species and reading through data collections to know more about this universe;. this game was very well made for back in 2007 and beyond and enhanced in this remake. the story is amazing i enjoyed it and the lore. it drew me in from our protagonist comm. shepard learning their past and going through the story and each game. it is interesting in a way that your choices matter i noticed it much more in the 2nd installment. and the lives of the other characters depend on our choices and much more. you transfer your shepard to each game and you determine the personality of shepard through dialogue and action choices. i wont delve into it much just got to try it for yourself. it is a realllly good game if you like story based, decision making, single player games. 10/10 from me.

mass effect 1 is one of my top 10 favourite video games in my lifetime--maybe even #1--and the whole series is a standout, forever-favourite. the story is so phenomenally told, with characters that are unique, fascinating, and satisfyingly complex. many of the cast of characters will forever possess a piece of my heart (especially commander shepard themself, liara, garrus, and tali'zorah, joker, jack, miranda, edi, cortez)--though, ahem, we don't talk about jacob. the games also have a gorgeous soundtrack that draws you into the wardrum heartbeat of the series, though there are plenty of tracks suited to thoughtful character moments, and capturing the sheer majesty of setpieces (like seeing the destiny ascension and the citadel for the first time--wow!). the legendary edition updates a ton of textures, and consolidates everything into a clean menu of the three games that keeps it all feeling consistent and meaningful across the trilogy. super highly recommend--fantastic for fans of the series, and perfect for people picking it up for the first time. i wish i could experience it all for the first time, but honestly, every time i play this immersive game is a joy. mass effect always evokes a kind of wonder, passion, and curiosity all braided together that makes this game unforgettable and genuinely life-changing (especially for being one of the first games to ever show same-sex relationships; liara and jane/female shepard will forever mean so much to me for that).
great game, still a classic

the game and story are great story - 8/10 gameplay - 7/10 music - 9/10 choices matter and game decisions lead to a verity of different outcomes and endings so it is certainly replayable. total - 8/10 would recommand anyone who did not play this yet and likes sci-fi where decisions matter story with shooter/ability gameplay if you pick this up you wont regret it. *note it does require ea launcher and account to play on steam this is a negative but i would still recommend the game especially in current price. (this review is created after i completed all 3 games thoroughly including all side content)

i grew up with the original games, not that i likely should have, but i have always been facinated with this franchise. anyone who knows me personally knows that mass effect is simply part of my personality, and have heard me talk about it at one point or another. this game specifically gave little me all the dlc and addons she could hope for, and it brings joy to my heart every time i get around to playing it all once again. my shepard has changed and grown with me through the ages, and it reflects who i am and who i want to be. this game is and will always be one of my favorites. i will be forever thankful for getting to experiance every bit of it, from bullets to calibrations. if you've read this far, you should just buy this game. it's so good, i promise.

mass effect legendary edition is one of the few games that made me feel genuinely attached to a fictional universe. it’s a rich, emotional journey that lets you build a story over dozens of hours and feel the weight of your choices. there’s a constant feeling that what you do matters, and that these characters are more than just npcs. it's important that the story continues from one game to another and it's something that enhances your connection to the characters. the game is full of quiet, human moments in between the big cinematic battles: talking to your squad in the ship. the world-building is rich (different species, cultures, politics) and it doesn't feel like a lore dump. the legendary edition also makes the experience feel smoother and more cohesive. the game was never top of the line in terms of mechanics or gameplay or even graphics compared to respective competition. it is the feeling it leaves after completing the trilogy. you feel like you've lived through an epic space story. so that makes it one of my favorite games and an unforgettable emotional experience in gaming.

the characters? great. the story? great. the experience for anyone who hasn't played before? fucking abhorrent. i really have no energy to express just how absolutely god awful this game is for new players. i am 8 fucking hours into the first game of the trilogy and it's insane how absolutely terrible this game is from a gameplay standpoint. some of the worst navigation i've ever experienced. after eight hours of trying to enjoy "one of the best rpgs to ever exist" i'm just so tired of how insanely terrible this game is to try to navigate and experience. probably four hours of my gameplay have been spent running in circles and looking up guides on where the hell i'm supposed to go. i spent over 30 minutes alone just trying to figure out how to get off the damn ship at my first destination, because the game doesn't give you any clue at all, and the actual door for it is just a little hidden hallway designed to look like all of the other ones that don't lead anywhere. i had such high hopes for this to at least behave like a normal video game and play like a somewhat outdated one "with really great story."` it held up to the story. it did not hold up to anything else one of the worst gameplay experiences of any game i've ever touched. let the clown awards come in. this game absolutely sucks.

game won't start without being connected to the internet. get rid of the ea launcher. especially after the new acquisition. stop requiring players to create accounts for third party launchers when selling games on steam. i only got this because it was on sale for $5. i already have these games on steam and my high praise (except mass effect 3 ending) reviews of this game series still stand. this game isn't the improvement i had hoped for. it changed very little. the "improved skin rendering" in the trailer actually looks worse. i got the impression the character building and weapon systems would be condensed to being the same in every game, but no. this is pretty much just a game port. the game flaws have still never been fixed. in mass effect 1 the m35 mako still gets stuck on random things and you have to reload to an earlier game or return to the normandy. at some points there are less options than the original games. in the original mass effect 2 you could modify your imported character's appearance. they removed that feature and now you have to manually type in your me 1 character's appearance code if you want to fix the messed up eye brows imported characters get or start from scratch.

wow this aged like doodoo dogwater. the mass effect trilogy is one of those classics that i finally decided to give a try but honestly it's baffling how anyone liked this in the first place. this came out after kotor, halo ce, and morrowind, and it's like a fusion of all of those games if someone blended them up into a smoothie, drank it, peed it out in the toilet, then dunked a ladle in there and went to town. i really tried to give this game a fair shot, but 90% percent of my playtime was spent aimlessly wandering as a soldier with the worst cardio in the universe, wondering where tf to go. i've seen many people say "well this game doesn't hold your hand," but there's a difference between not holding my hand, and throwing me as a baby off a boat into the open ocean. i've played games where you're only given hints where to go and you have to figure the rest out on your own, but the difference is, those games actually give details and provide reasons to explore, while in mass effect, everything looks the same, around every corner there's jack squat, and as an added bonus commander shepherd is the worst note taker in human history. "go to poopenfarten central," cool, where's that? what do i do with this information?? oh, it's marked on my map? oh, but it's not on my current map, it's marked on the map of the area i need to go to. sick. see you in 3 hours. also, the combat feels dreadful, which i could forgive if the story or any other aspect of the game had hooked me, but alas, this game is ultra poop from a butt.

six days in fallujah isn’t just a game. it’s a lifestyle change. i thought i was ready. i had snacks, a comfy chair, and a good mouse. then the first door breached. the sound, the chaos, seeing my marines taking hits, i haven’t been the same since. now i flinch when someone slams a door. my friends call me “lieutenant lag.” i can’t play other shooters anymore. uninstalled twice. reinstalled thrice. oorah! just one more mission id tell myself. 10/10 recommend if you’re ready to trade your sanity for immersion. semper fi

all in all six days leaves a lot to be desired, from general game play, ai team mates, missions and progress. i bought the game when it launched, at launch there were only 4 missions, then they added 4 more and some of the single player missions which serve more as a tutorial then anything else, even though there is already a training mission in the menu. the gun play is very stale, the procedural generation is cool, but more of a gimmick then an actual factor to your game play. once you see the same house 10 times, you understand the layouts and interiors which remove any "unknowing" factor when entering these structures. the devs stay radio silent, and this whole year 2025 they've talked about this big autumn update, but no preview or any kinda teaser as to what it really is besides dev blogs with big flashy words that just fill me with more dispair then anything. many in the community, myself included believe the devs have abandoned this game and just simply made off with the money. the single-player campaign is nowhere near finished, the cut scenes feel rushed and half baked, as do almost all other sysyems in the game. this should game with a "buyer beware" tag, i hope that the devs finish the game and make it the shooter they set out to develop. but at this point in time i can't in good faith recommend it to anyone, when other games do it better, just not in the middle east with a historical setting. six days is far from finished and until the devs start being a bit more transperant, i think you should just wait till its finished or they finally pull the plug

the game has a great concept and some genuinely intense and immersive moments that set it apart from most modern military shooters. you can tell the developers are aiming for something more meaningful and realistic, and i really respect that. that said, the current state of the game has quite a few issues — bugs, crashes, and performance hiccups really hurt the experience. sometimes the game breaks or gets stuck entirely, and it can be frustrating, especially during co-op sessions. but i understand it's still in early access, and that comes with the territory. i truly hope the devs keep pushing forward, because this game has serious potential. i’ll definitely be picking it up again once the full version is released. wishing the team all the best — you’re onto something special here.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text: like any game in active development, there are some minor bugs here or there. that being said, i fully believe that the dev team here care about their game and the community they've built in it's playerbase. they're listening to feedback from us players and with every single patch it gets better. building in this game is easily the best i've encountered in any survival game. i have many hours spent in building our manor, the outlying farm, the gardens, its all been great fun. it's got something for everyone, with fun dungeons, interesting enemies, even npcs you get to rescue and make part of your "village". i'd definitely recommend giving it a try. the minor bugs i've encountered haven't been bad enough to detour me from playing and i feel heard by the dev team working their tails off to make this game better and better.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text: i went into it just looking for something to unwind with after work, and it ended up becoming one of the most chill and relaxing games i’ve played in a long time. the loop is simple: explore, loot, build, chill. there’s no crazy rush or punishment every 5 minutes. you can take your time, set up your base exactly how you like it, and just vibe. the world has this calm atmosphere — even when you’re running into enemies or diving into the shroud, it never feels stressful. half my time has been spent just gathering materials, expanding my base, and trying out new builds. co-op is even better; it feels like hanging out with friends, not grinding. if you want a game that lets you relax, zone out, and still feel like you’re progressing, enshrouded is absolutely worth it. i didn’t expect to sink 115 hours into it, but here i am.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text: early access review! i played the game for about 70 hours in my first 2 months after the release. i got somewhat bored after that and i now returned and there is so much new stuff to do, new areas, new material to build and craft with. new weapon types and all that jazz, i really like the game and i really do recommend it, no matter if you play solo or with friends. playing with friends is ofc a bit more fun for the most part and can make certain things easier. speaking of easier, there is one boss in the game that makes my blood boil. the mechanics and battle arena is just all bad and the only good thing about the boss is the design of the boss itself, not the mechanics or the battle. i cheezed the hell out of that fight by dropping the damage and health of the boss down to 20%, i love being able to customize my worlds with difficulties and resource yields and all that. there are plenty of kinks and bugs to work out but the developers are working on the game and it shows. i hope the full realization of the game will come into fruition with the 1.0 update at some point.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text: there is a lack of content in terms of combat. there is a lot to do for the creative people, so if you enjoy that aspect then this is a given buy. but if you came for the combat, the epic battles, the bosses, the character progression then you will probably as disappointed as i've been so far. as far as i'm concerned there are maybe 1 or two bosses that aren't _just_ tank & spank (minor mechanics). the other enemies are extremely boring and repetitive. the same enemies repeated over and over, just different skins basically. i really think this game has potential, but as it is today i am disappointed in the lack of content and the way the team seems to avoid adding more traditional content. also performance; the game is very beautiful but the performance even on a top tier pc is severely lacking. overall i don't regret buying the game, but i would not buy it again for the price knowing what i know.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text: don't get me wrong, the game is good. exploring the world is fun, farming is effortless, and everything looks beautiful. but playing co-op is simply impossible; constant disconnects not only ruin the experience, they cause a very negative emotions. you just completed a dungeon and earned an epic weapon, and then you get kicked out of the game—you reappear god knows where with an empty inventory. you've simply been thrown back in time 10 minutes. have fun playing this game in co-op.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text: i want to post this review for anyone who is buying this game for the building aspect as i wish i found this out before it was too late to refund. from what i understand, the world is on a grid for building, so the direction in which you can place the walls is tied to that - meaning if there's a place you like that you want to build your house on, you can only build the walls in one specific direction, which is extremely limiting and frustrating. i would not recommend if building is important to you unless they eventually fix this. unfortunately this game was a waste of $25 for me and i wish i could get it back.

review_text: absolute dogshit. everything is janky. no one is ever going to fix the main mechanics. they built a foundation out of crap and are just slapping 'content' on top of it. for example: the wolves. they will just damage you no matter what. put up a block? standing on level ground, facing the wolf? damage goes through. people playing in zones at their own level might not notice this, but we wanted to venture out further. the result—getting our asses torn apart by these f*cking wolves. there is no actual combat system here. and it's like that with every aspect of the core mechanics. people usually say a game is good depending on the price tag. even for free—don't waste your time.

review_text: i went back and forth if i would write a review for this game as i did not finish it but here i am typing. 36 hours i made it, every night me and my duo got on was a night filled with why am i playing this, surely it will get better but it just got worse over time. on the surface this game looks amazing, plays well enough and the world looks great but then you actually play the game and regret your choices. i really tried to like this game and i will start with its main positive which is the building system, you got terraforming and a lot of building pieces to pick from and can rebuild the broken down villages. but that is the only positive i got. the number one thing i noted playing this game was that it just hates the players... like dark souls but i love dark souls i have 300+ hours on dark souls 3. this game actually just hates you... it wants you to get stuck, killed by hidden explosives, a swamp that insta kills you, monsters that hit for 500+ damage when you have a 480 health pool with the best armor you can get at the time and a vertical map that is cool at first but really is just a problem. i really hated this game the whole time i was playing it, and im a survival craft player im not new to the genre. i kept telling myself just give it more time but it just got worse the longer it went. this game sucked a lot and its a shame cause it looks good and obviously had good development dollars but this is a hard no from me.

review_text: [b]# --- my thoughts:[/b] i'd like to mention the fact that i have no issues with the core gameplay of this fall guys clone. it plays smoothly and its everything you expect it to be. no, my issues are of a different kind. first of all, i hate the fact that [i]stumble guys[/i] is [i]all[/i] about micro-transactions. you could make the argument that many other games have micro-transactions, sure, but what really bothers me is that you are [i]required[/i] to spend money on these stupid micro-transactions in order to get some of the achievements this game has. second of all, there are many achievements related to maps that no longer show up [i]at all[/i], or have an astronomically low chance of ever showing up. this locks anyone who wishes to fully complete the game (achievement wise) out. lastly, the currency you would get in this game by taking part in the mentioned micro-transactions is [i]way[/i] too overpriced. due to the fact that 1. i am not made of money and 2. the game isn't [i]that[/i] fun to excuse the micro-transactions, i am abandoning my achievement hunting for [i]stumble guys[/i]. too bad. i would have really liked to put in the hours to complete it. [b]# --- rating: 4.5/10[/b]

even though i haven’t played a huge amount of nier: automata, it’s already one of my favorite games ever. it’s rare for a game to pull me in so quickly, but nier: automata does it effortlessly with its atmosphere, music, and emotional weight. from the very first hour, it feels like you’re stepping into a world that’s beautiful, broken, and strangely human. what stands out the most is the vibe — that unique mix of melancholy and hope that yoko taro somehow makes feel comforting. the soundtrack alone could carry the entire experience; it’s haunting in a way that stays with you long after you stop playing. and even with the little i’ve seen of the story, it’s clear that it’s something deeper than just an action rpg. every character, every mission, every small detail seems to mean something. the gameplay shifts constantly — one moment you’re in fast-paced hack-and-slash combat, the next you’re in a top-down shooter or a side-scrolling platformer — and somehow it all works together seamlessly. even as someone who hasn’t gone through all the routes yet, i already feel the emotional connection people talk about. it’s a game i know i’ll keep coming back to, and the fact that i already love it this much with so little time played says everything. nier: automata isn’t just a game — it’s a feeling, and it’s one that stays with you.
it is truly a masterpiece.

sad robots fantastic combat incredible soundtrack great voice performances one of the very few, non-roguelike games that actually made multiple playthroughs feel rewarding and interesting for me. the game very much deserves its popularity and the impact it had on pop-culture. and while there is humor to be found, the overall themes of the game deal to a great degree with suffering and what it means to be human. so be prepared for some real emotional downer moments (in the best possible way).

i love the soundtrack and story, that can be experienced in full, as there is more new content with each successive playthrough that shows you the world from a different perspective. i appreciate that you keep your items, level and completed quests from the last playthrough, so you don't have to start over with all of the grinding and questing each time, even though this is inconsistent with the story. i only had three negative experiences with the game (one of which was the fault of windows), but thankfully these weren't game-ruining. one was during a simple-seeming escort quest i started at level 23 and immediately regretted when level 50 enemies showed up (on my second attempt the enemies weren't so high level, so i suppose it was just bad luck). the second was having to travel to a certain story-relevant location to progress a side-quest, but a short cutscene was automatically played that made the quest unavailable. the third was losing a days worth of progress after eating a fish, because, as it turned out, windowsdefender "protected" my save-files from being changed, making it impossible to save the game.

i played this game when it first came out and i enjoyed it a lot. i am starting it again in 2025. i am told that this is a game that you have to play more than once to really "get it" and i am going to give it a shot. recommended. now we just have to hope it plays nice with my hardware. switching review from positive to negative. needing to finish a whole game multiple times to see the whole game is stupid. i like the plot but the actual moment to moment game play gets stale. i have been playing it for the last 2 nights after not touching it for years. it's fun but it's just not that compelling to revisit. i cannot imagine how badly this would overstay it's welcome if i was one of those people going for all 5 endings. remember. no matter how pretty it is it's a jrpg and most of the side quests amount to fetch quests or going somewhere and killing a mob. lots and lots and lots and lots of tapping b to pick stuff up. stuff that you would never have a reason to leave behind. needs autopickup.

this is the most grueling, unnerving and tedious jrpg i have ever played. i dont even care anymore how good the story might be, because the underlying "game" you have to play (or much rather endure) to experience the story is so absurdly frustrating. the reasons are: - no autosaves, saving only works at fast travel points which entices you to not travel through the map on foot but rather hug the fast travel points to not lose hours of playtime if you mess something up and want to restart at a save - you have to find your corpse if you die to recover some of your items - the map is terrible, questmarkers and points of interest are all in the same color and all of them are visible at all times. finding what you are looking for is almost impossible - the camera sucks. there are tons of areas where the camera switches from regular third person to one fixed angle like in the first resident evil games from almost 30 years ago - the music will grind your gears after a few hours, because its not an atmospheric backgrund track. its really obtrusive and there are lots of repetitive vocals that get annoying really quick and a gameplay-unrelated bonus point are the (for a 2017 released game) ugly, sometimes borderline pis*filter looking graphics with lod issues, pop in and flickering foilage. i can not fully assess how good the story is, because i will most probably not finish this game as i had almost no fun playing it, but for the actual gameplay, id give it something like a 3/10

i expected so much more out of this series based on the hype and attention it gets, but man this was a let down. visuals are drab, music is repetitive, combat is so-so, exploration is a slog, and worst of all are the performance issues are constant. that is also not mentioning the fact that the camera is absolutely broken in some areas from getting stuck in top down to not being able to keep up with the player during sprint. it just does not feel like a modern game in a few areas and while that can possibly be overlooked, the crashes are inexcusable. if i were able to finish this game, i would assume i would score it around a 5.5, but again, i quit after the myriad of issues.

on paper, it looks like an amalgamation of everything i like: postapoc, androids, bots, greenery, heavy on philosophy plot, multiple endings, rpg, outstanding ost etc. but my omnissiah, what a bore it is. the world is barren, combat is shallow, npc-s could have been an email, side quests are a chore. i could go on, but if jrpg doesn't have neither a compelling story, characters nor gameplay, what else can it offer? this game is famous for its story, yes, but i just couldn't force myself to slog through the gameplay to see it. if anything, it felt pretentious and shallow. unfortunately, 2b's butt is not enough of a plot point for me to stick to the experience. the only thing i liked about the game (long before i actually played it) is the soundtrack. fortunately, that i can experience [i]without[/i] the game itself.
i have a motion sickness from this game...
i don't get the hype. it just feels like fetch quest after fetch quest. map is really annoying and confusing. you can't get to some areas with markers until later on, and that is not made very clear.

play through the opening sequence before you get to the bunker and you'll know if you like it or not. for me, this was an absolute slog. i did not enjoy the combat at all, and the grindy, unnecessary levelling system exacerbated it. i played through to the c ending before i was done dealing with the shitty combat and being underlevelled. frankly, i really don't get what people see in this game. replaying through the same mediocre combat and missions as 2b and 9s is baffling. the quest design is bad, the map and level design is extremely uninspired, the va is spotty, and the characters are very one note. the chip system wants to be something clever like nine souls or hollow knight's abilities, but then neglects to provide any interesting abilities, preferring instead to increase your melee damage by a literal 2%. we can do so much better than this. if you want to experience the story, go watch it on youtube. this frankly fails on every metric i'd evaluate a game by.
not my cup of tea. the combat is not very responsive, although i would point out a very interesting combination of gameplay mechanics.

since the majority of the reviews for this game are old and positive, i think i'll be the minority report. if this game is on sale, resist the urge to purchase it. if you buy it, and you play it, you'll know why i told you not to. you've been warned.

you get to look at 2b while she fights robots and climbs ladders and you can blow off her skirt. some things are great. unfortunately it's a crappy console port. the game was pretty crap at launch but got a patch to fix certain things. unfortunately that patch didn't really address enough of the problems to make this great. the menus are painfully slow to open, we don't have an fov slider, and the game is capped at 60 fps. the game is alright, but lacks qol and polish. if you want to get it do yourself a favor and do so when it's on sale. 2b is top tier, but this game client crawled straight out of the dumpster.

the save system is extremely bad and annoying. the music is extremely good. the gameplay is not smooth at all and most of the time i defeated the enemies with the robot 2b. the user interface of the game is boring. i continued the story of the game until the first ending, but after that the game had no traction at all and it bored me a lot. i was looking forward to experiencing this game but it was not worth the experience at all.

[b]merits:[/b] ▪ a very intriguing premise (told in a terrible format) ▪ dynamic switching between game genres ▪ fantastic musical score ▪ 2b's assets & animations [b]flaws:[/b] ▪ ps2 level graphics ▪ terrible ux, especially on the map ▪ grindy and repetitive combat ▪ a ton of boring fetch quests ▪ requires multiple playthroughs for the full story [b]verdict:[/b] i have heard great things about this supposed masterpiece, however the reality did not meet the expectations. the switching between shoot 'em up/hack 'n' slash/platforming is novel but the pacing of the game is terrible. it absolutely does not respect your time, expects you to constantly backtrack and play the game multiple times. when it comes to the story or lore almost nothing is told to the player and you have to very slowly unravel things through tidbits in the world. my recommendation would be to watch the cutscenes on youtube or better yet, watch the anime series that is based on the game, you will have infinitely better time. [b]rating:[/b] ★★☆☆☆ - average

the game itself is a lot of fun, great combat and music hits hard. but the save system is one of the worst i’ve seen in gaming history and it ruins the whole experience; it constantly makes you worry about losing progress. i feel bad for not recommending it but this one thing ruined the fun for me. i literally played the same thing twice, first time i exited after about 30 minutes without knowing there’s no autosave and lost progress, and the second time i played ~50 minutes then died, instead of resuming i was sent back to the very beginning. that felt ridiculously frustrating. i refunded it for now, if they ever fix the save system i’d happily give it another shot.

i always thought this was a mindless action game with fan service. i tried it out because i heard it had a good story (which i found surprising and suspicious). the gun aiming in 3rd person is fine. in side scroll-er it's up or left or right. nothing in between. which is frustrating. the melee combat is better. the heavy hits feel impactful. i hit my first 'quit moment' 5 minutes into the game. the game yanks the camera all over the place throwing you from 3rd person, side scroll-er, top down, and everything else with little to no warning. the game is trying to be so many genres at once it's like being shoved in a barrel and tossed over niagara falls. i had a feeling this wouldn't be my type of game but i gave it a shot. turns out it was right.
what i expected from this game, i got from signalis.

11 hours into the playthrough. gameplay: terrible graphics: ps3-level difficulty: unbalanced (normal mode is too easy; hard mode, you get one-shot—might as well play very hard mode) story: after 11 hours, nothing significant has happened. i know the story gets better, but how much longer do i have to play before it’s actually enjoyable? characters: likeable also worst map navigation in history of games! so basically, if you’re willing to spend at least 20 hours for the game to actually get good, i’d recommend it. otherwise, you might want to just watch a youtube video—preferably a 6-hour one—which covers everything and is free, saving you a lot of time.

hands down my favorite video game of all time. there is not another game that has had me hooked for as long as nuclear throne has. this is what i would consider to be the gold standard for a tight, refined gameplay loop for roguelites, and every one that comes after should strive for it. doesn't waste time getting to a truly singular arcade-style experience, and will absolutely not hold your hand. win or lose, you will play again, and that much i can almost guarantee you. one of, if not the most impressive games i've ever encountered, and will probably never stop playing. ever.

it's fun until you actually try to win. it throws the most blatantly unfair dog shit at you so you either have to get lucky or lose. my biggest complaint is one particular boss later in the game. the dude shoots like 5 bullets in a straight line at the speed of light. and he can fire at you from off screen, so if you happen to be where he's aiming, unless you have superhuman reflexes, you're going to get hit by at least one of the the 5 bullets. or if you get unlucky, you're gonna be eating 3, 4, or even god forbid all 5 shots and since each bullet does 3 damage, even only 3 bullets is enough to kill your 8 health character. even if you get a health upgrade to 12 hp, you're still getting put down by 4 bullets. this enemy also summons other fairly strong minions, flies into the air and quickly lands right next to you emitting a ripple of fire that evaporates your health for every nanosecond you're in it, has tons of health, moves quickly, and is super tiny and hard to hit. not to mention he shows up only a few seconds after you get to his stage, so there will be tons of other normal enemies in the level ready to gang up and fuck you over.

i feel like i got to this party a bit late. i'm an avid fan of the roguelike genre and nuclear throne does have a very solid minimalist design, but i can't help feeling it's a bit limited even by the standards of its day feeling more like something suited to the gameboy. nt is one of the earlier twin stick roguelikes containing the skeleton of the genre. the gunplay is fast paced, tough, and simple. upgrades come in the form of mutations which vary by character, and each level is a minimal, tiny, blocky arena that can be expanded via explosions. gameplay is centred around the guns and character specific gimmicks. survival is achieved by learning how to wield the different weapons without killing yourself and familiarising yourself with the different enemies, how they react to being shot, and how to dodge their projectiles. the small resolution and tight spaces combined with large explosions and enemy attacks provide most of the difficulty here. it has a lot of charm in it's simplicity but the gameplay lacks nuance so it becomes repetitive fast. i can see why people might grind this one for hours at a time but it's not substantial enough for my taste.

as a long time d&d player, solasta feels like a more faithful adaption of a tabletop rpg than the shadow-casting colossus that is bg3. like the forgotten older sibling whose more attractive and more successful younger brother receives all the love and praise, solasta is the game that gives you everything its got, with all its heart. sure, its not as polished, its voice cast is smaller, the scripting is rougher, and the graphics will look better at the end of the night after a few drinks, but it is d&d. it has personality and quiet charm. its scrappy, nerdy and enthusiastic like a saturday morning dm doing their best to deliver you a fun game with whatever voices they can muster, half-baked stories, and last minute quest hooks. solasta is familiar, fun and delivers that all important authentic feel that only comes from a dm (or developer) with a true love for what they're doing.

pros: good game really close to 5e dnd tabletop experience... if graphics were a bit better and ui too, it would be really awesome :d cons: a bit too easy in the standard difficulty. also is a bit slow game but as i play story gets more engaging ;) recommended if you like dnd

einer der größten vorteile dieses spiels im beriech der rundenbasierten rpg's ist, dass man nicht elendlange dialoge lesen und beantworten muss. ich mag die pathfinder serie und auch die pillars spiele, aber da hat es mich schon immer gestört, dass man eben teilweise extrem lange dialoge lesen muss und das eigentlich spiel darunter leidet. das ist hier nicht der fall. knappe dialoge, die sich auf das wichtigste konzentrieren. dazu eine (für rpg's) sehr gute grafik, stimmige atmosphäre und eine sehr gute story. also definiv eine kaufempfehlung.
