solasta is an awesome western crpg that perfectly translates d&d5e to virtual. the game itself is a hidden gem. it is a cult classic. it is jank in the best way possible. it's very fun and there is tons of combat customization potential. story is pretty interesting as well. the ending is not good, but they gave some dlc to help. looking forward to solasta 2.
it is immersive and very fun

the personality system shines! i fell in love with my four misfits because of their interactions and the dialogue choices that were all a result of their personalities. now i'm playing with a totally different party with their own personalities and the feel is totally different. it's like watching a sitcom with four main characters.

best turn based combat system, it has verticality and a concentration system. spells last for a reasonable amount of time and time is passed so the adventure doesnt happen in the span of two days or three but it is a couple months campaign of adventure

i started playing this after spending over a thousand hours playing bg3 and was looking for another take on a d&d based crpg. i have really enjoyed the efforts at recreating the table top experience and the ability to create different characters and party compositions. after playing the standard campaigns, it has been just as fun exploring the different adventures the community has created in the dungeon maker feature. looking forward to the release of solasta 2!

hard core rpg, learning can be fun! i would suggest easy level to learn it, but normal level is very challenging and rewarding after you learn it. first tried normal without really reading the tutorial tips, and after a few hours needed to restart on easy, but playing easy leaves out some of the fun stuff i like, so went back to normal and read everything! camera control is another thing... my god! a trial in frustration! but, for some reason, i diggin it! pretty cool! 9/10
this game is to my likking, it works for me.

good game overall. if you wanna play something like dnd, baldurs gate 3 kind of stuff this is a good game for that. only thing is that its a bit less quality in general but the combat feels a bit more advanced except physics based things. the best campaigns are the main game's and the dlc palace of ice. the rest is just additional stuff like classes (some classes are dlc locked. yes pretty scummy.) and lost valley is something a bit meh for my liking. overall very good, took 150 hours to beat every campaign available in the game with all dlc. you can also play workshop campaigns made by other people. while its less quality and clearly no voice acting in these ones it adds a lot of replayability.

i am enjoying this game. great tactical rpg with a lot customization, alot. it is not at the level bg3 but what it is it does well. very d&d focused. i like the combat the game looks great. i plan to get more from these developers.
great loot system, just enough narration as to not weigh the game down.
great fun! the minimalistic ui is...a choice; that some will love and some will hate.

i feel like i owe the developers of this game an apology for being too quick to judge. very impressive attention to detail regarding game mechanics related to dungeons/dragons adventuring, crafting, combat, terrain, strategy, storytelling, character creation and development. vastly superior to baldurs gate 3, with the shallow exception of graphics - but these games when done well engage the imagination and graphics should never trump the rest (and the graphics aren't terrible). it reminds me of the first baldurs gate, and what i would imagine a proper continuation of that game to look like (updated to more current rule-sets). if this were ever to somehow marry neverwinter nights (the original with the toolset), i'd expect to be absorbed by it for years and years. i wish the money i wasted on the latest vampire bloodlines fail and expedition 33 or whatever that bad acid trip was called went instead to this developing team. sometimes life gets busy and we walk right past treasures that we mistakenly assume are merely part of the surrounding drab terrain. i encourage you to dust this game off and take a close look and see it for the sparkling gem it is. nice job, solasta team.

to jest hardzo fajne takie jak baldyur ale brzydkie i nie ma tu fabuly i itemy takie se ale fajne walka i fajne rzee se moszesz wszystkich zrobic a nie ze tylko jednego i sie fajnie lazi w to se gadajom miedzy soba te twoje pamperki jakies swoje teksty majom nawet czarowanie spoko i mozna po scianie lazic a w tym baldr nie morzna po scianie lazic ale tu tak nozna po scianie lazic w tym i se bic jakis jaszczurkow i modty som tez
great d&d game, i think based on the srd? not sure. either way, it's #2 after bg3, i prefer the mechanics of it over wotr. so excited for solasta ii.

this one is worth picking up on sale, if you need to scratch that d&d itch. we will not see the like of baldur's gate 3 for some time, but this one is serviceable. solasta is more gritty. there is no multi-classing, and the main campaign is very stingy with loot. you have to make due without the more fantastical weapons and armor. a +1 item that you can actually use is considered good loot and will be used for a good part of the campaign. the best items are crafted in the main campaign and getting the recipe, correct faction requirements, and ingredients will take you half the game or more to put together. the 2 dlcs that add new classes and races are straight up rip offs that should have been dropped for free. the full bundle is a good deal when on sale. you get all the races, classes, new dice, and 2 extra campaigns. i just finished the palace of ice dlc and it was great. getting the loot thrown at you without worrying about factions and recipes was very satisfying after the main campaign. i would recommend to pick this up mainly because the next solasta coming out early '26 looks amazing. they are revamping the graphics, and making a slew of improvements. this one has minor issues like elevation is handled improperly, cover system is not great, crossbows are broken (in the players favor), graphics are meh, and few other minor things. all that aside i have put enough time in this one to endorse it, it'll do.
straight forward play along d&d lines. replicates a campaign quite nicely.

played bg3 and heard this was also based off d&d so decided to give it a try. i was surprisingly shocked by how much fun i'm having with the game. bought all the dlc and look forward to playing it after i finish the main campaign.
its really hard to enjoy this game with all the bugs from the first few hours of playing. developers need to do a better job and fix them

if you've finished playing baldur's gate 3 and are looking for a similar experience, whether single player or co-op, you are not going to find it here. the ui is very clunky, most classes/races are locked behind a paywall of dlcs. your characters miss basically every attack. ammo is required for bow/crossbow attacks. story seems very uninteresting. you become encumbered very quickly which can greatly affect how many spaces you can move. you can't move through characters, so corridors become a real problem when trying to move your team around. games seems pretty heavy on the crafting of potions and other materials. you have to stock up on food before you can travel between locations. fights take far too many turns to conclude. i was shocked to see this game is only 5 years old, because it plays and feels like something from 2010. honestly even if you've never played bg3, i would still probably avoid this game. hopefully solasta 2 will be significantly better than this.

very rough around the edges, for hardcore dnd fans only. i'm surprised that the positive review rating is so high. combat could start with other players so far away that it was pointless for them to even participate, attacks miss 50% of the time. feels like a game made in the mid 2000s.
everything besides the gameplay was just sad :(

i really wish there was a maybe option or something in between. i don't hate this game. i find the gameplay very fun, and the depth of mechanics that's just 5e srd mixed with some homebrew is fun. however, and big however, i cannot really get into the game. there's very limited choices in subclasses. the dialogue is a w f u l. what draws me even further away is there aren't really much options for character customization, and all characters look off. it's weirdly uncanny. would i recommend this game? if it was on sale, sure. if you're looking for a tabletop like experience, this is one of the few that will "somewhat" scratch that itch. there are better options. here's hoping the sequel is better.
the game looked good, and i wanted to play it. but it won't let me start the campaign, it freezes every time.
it's ok but rather boring and tedious. 6/10

i lost over 10 hours of gameplay because i didn't realize quick saves made during a dlc dungeon were going to overwrite quick saves from my main campaign. apparently, you have to manually save in order for it to store permanently. but at this point, i'm not going back. i'm done. i love the idea of this game. but it's jenk really shows.

writing is pretty bad, voice acting is atrocious, exploring is fine. the only fun part is the combat, because it's dnd 5e and they didnt make it themselves, yet somehow half of the classes and races they didnt create are behind a paywall after i pay full price. hard not recommend
*unoptimised *bland and soulless ui *insanely long travel time *terrible dialogues
scaling is way off, interactions are buggy, and co-op disconnects frequently.

it's bad. really bad. it was "campy" bad at first... dialog, story, graphics are all scraping bottom of the barrel. rules are inconsistent with dnd and even inconsistent with itself. some fire creatures are immune to fire, others are not, some are *sometimes* immune... highly inconsistent. most *base* classes and races are hidden by dlc. very scammy. there's a mod that helps with this, but it's not on steam, so it's a pita to get it installed. ***however*** once you install the mod, multiplayer is ruined. constant desync between host and client. there's a "decent" fix, by hard setting your gpu to 60 fps. which means, for wtf ever reason they connected network activity to the gpu. and it still desyncs, but not *every* fight. even worse, once you install the dlc and experience the desnc, you can't uninstall it... and after seeing all the classes/races left out by the orginal came in the mod, you can't enjoy going back. story is bad and get worse as you get to the end.
worst atempt to potray dnd i've ever seen... story 1/10. role play -5/10. gameplay 3/10. game design 1/10
the random encounters killing you before you can move ruin game.

why do they even have ironman mode anymore? i haven't been able to finish any game on ironman for years, maybe even a decade now, they all have bugs that need constant saving because,inevitably, it will crash or freeze or glitch out in some manner that requires a previous save to restore. every fuc king game i play in ironman s hits the bed at some point and leaves completion impossible. this game is no different. it's simply unplayable in ironman mode.

i wish i could recommend this game. there are decent levels and the level design can be good. there is some hilarious voice acting moments. the game feels like it is on the verge of potential. but most of the game is formulaic, and a lot of the interaction with the levels feels like busy work rather than playing a game, or solving puzzles, or getting over combat. the game trudges along until these pivotal moments that on the serve feel significant, but then it dawns on you: the writing is actually really, really bad, with many plot points undeveloped, unexplained, etc. there may be some great potential in this game with its dlcs and its sandbox components, but the main campaign (co-op took 35 hours with numerous crash bugs, in 2025) was lacking, to put it mildly.

lost will to play mid base campaign because of de-synchronization bug: - friend bought gear in a store, equipped it - other players couldn't see it in his inventory (he wasn't the host for the session) - game restart revealed that his character actually has no mentioned gear, yet money he spent are also not available anymore (so, he did spend it and got nothing) - we had to reload much older save and redo all the steps, all the dialogs and we did manage to buy everything the same and there was no issue that time ...and then it happened again further in a campaign there are a lot of minor inconveniences as well, but this de-synch issue is way to much...especially if you have to redo dialog all over the city because you realized there is an issue right when everyone were done with their preparations / quests and ready to depart from the town
temu version of baldurs gate...sooo janky! i wanted to like it though

dlc scum: $4 for the game, $20 for the fun. the basic version you get on a sale has only half races and classes available. in a d&d game! wanna play as a bard, monk, druid, warlock or barbarian? pay 5x of the price. that makes the game more expensive than baldur's gate 3! do you guys really think that your junk worth more than larian's masterpiece? even without sales, the full version of solasta is 50% more expensive than bg3. if you want full experience, without "blocked by dlc" icons all over the clunky ui, you'd have to pay as much as an aaa game. the game itself is just an indie with awful ui, boring story and clunky controls.

the general low budget vibe was fine. the bad graphics, the questionable ost, the hilariously bad dub, the basic plot, the generic ui that doesn't tell you much about your spells or enemies etc - all of this is literally ok, because having a coop dnd game with 3 other friends every weekend is great. but i draw the line at losing a coop campaign of multiple months to a bug that prevents main quest progression. unplayable, inacceptable and downright awful.
stupidly hard random encounters difficulty.
not only are common (player's manual) races locked behind dlc, but so too are common classes. i bought this on sale and am definitely getting a refund. i don't care how cheap it is, that's revolting.

the voice acting, close-up 3d model cutscenes and writing are all kinda atrocious. characters are ugly which would be fine if they weren't in close-up focus all the time, and 5 out of 12 classes are locked behind dlc (warlock, bard, monk, barbarian and druid). gameplay and exploration seemed okay, and the tutorials are helpful, but i was rather put off by the previous points and wasn't enjoying myself.

mechanics are decent as well as the armor and weapon models. the character models are bad and they could not be bothered to fix the visible gaps and seem in the shoulders. the dialogue is poor and the characters come off as bickering jerks to me. i also ran into a few annoying scenarios that threw my plan right out the window. trying to fight a vampire in the day time but when the battle starts it instantly switches to night time. or planning to ambush a group of enemies with a fireballs but the fireball does no damage because i pointless scripted event were the party talks and bickers a moment did not trigger. there are some good things here but a lot of this stuff is to much for me to really want to recommend it to anyone.
10/10 but i forgot to save and had to redo a bunch of sections. please save. totally improved my depression.

one of the fucking best games ever, i have played qutie a few games myself if may say so. i even beat dark souls so i am basically a videogame expert. this game is absolutely great, i heard so much great beforehand but it was even better than expected. so i really recommend buying it and also playing it to the end without spoilers. good luck my friend!

omori is my favourite game of all time, and i doubt this'll change. i found omori in 2022 before it was taken off of xbox, initially glancing over it at first, i decided to play it later on into the year. omori has easily been the most impactful piece of media to grace my life. the story is incredible, easily the meatiest part of this story is locked behind a huge spoiler wall, which i won't go into to allow people to really sink their teeth into something they equally should and shouldn't... omori's artstyle and soundtrack are both brilliant, both of which influencing my artwork and music tastes in their own beautiful ways. after getting a pc in july of 2025 i wanted to see this game again the most, and it was nowhere near as lacklustre. i'd argue it was better. the story doesn't erode, it grows on you and hits you really hard regardless of how many times you brush the dust off of it's cover. omori is, and likely always will be my favourite game of all time.

this game is incredible. it's so vibrant and pretty at times then it hits you with a stark contrast that is so bleak and so disturbing that you can't help but be sucked in. the combat was fun and the little secrets were really fun to explore. the story is incredible and it's paced to perfection. the music is top notch and helps manifest the imagery and world omocat is trying to create. i would 100% give this game a shot. 10/10

absolute cinema. best story i've seen in a video game. the combat is meh, if you liked the combat in undertale, this is a considerable downgrade. theres minimal grinding, you could honestly beat the entire game by ignoring every enemy besides bosses. and if you do get stuck theres usually a conveniently placed enemy that you can kill three times and level everyone up right beside the last save point. music is good, there were tracks that i could care less about but there were also themes that will probably give me ptsd if i hear them again. 10/10 would never play again.

this is now my favorite game of all time. however it is not perfect, it has many flaws it drags on for a bit longer than it should, the combat is ok not great, and sometimes my tears are so thick i cannot see what happens in some scenes. i also understand that this game is not for everybody if you cannot handle topics of depression and suicide i would strongly suggest not playing this game. although it may have many flaws i am willing to look past them because of the games great story, soundtrack, and art style. i haven't played any other game with a story as well executed as omori the story isn't afraid to explore some dark topics but it ends up paying off and creating one of the most beautiful bittersweet moments in any game. to sum it all up, if you are looking for a dark story-based rpg to play and are willing to look past the flaws i listed you will not find another game that will give you the same quality of experience as omori.

this game is just.. on a different level. a level in which everyone cries and understands these characters to the point where we think of them as our own friends. as us. that alone should be enough information to buy this game. this game is very story heavy with strong themes of depression and suicide. if you're struggling, i suggest thinking it over. this game has ups and really, really hard lows. that being said, it's those lows which pull the story together and make the player feel something. a connection. so, all in all, i'd rate this game an easy 10/10. i may be bias, but this game affected me in such a way i can't help it. amazing pixel art, story telling, fun gameplay, and so many npcs to interact with. if you plan on buying the game, don't spoil it for yourself. keep to the experience, it's worth it.

it's one of the best rpg maker games out there but i can't recommend this game, it would be one of those occasions where even if you want to play the game you have to separate the art from the artist in every aspect, i don't want to make a gigantic review about the issues that omori's creator has so if i can tell you something it's too research about omocat by yourself and take your own conclusions from there, the game itself is really good and i don't doubt it really helped people through some rough times and even made a lot of people feel the bitter sweet joy this game speaks about, but the people behind it... that ain't it bro... can't recommend this game with a straight face and unburdened heart...

everyone i knew was convinced that my play-through of omori would turn into a masochistic hate-play almost immediately. they were so sure of it that they made me record a voice memo promising i’d quit before the two-hour mark if i ended up hating it that much. when i finally launched the game, i wasn’t even allowed to do it alone. i had two people sitting beside me on the couch, ready to shut it down the moment i started complaining. honestly, i’m surprised i managed to stick with it as long as i did.

gameplay: fantastic, engaging loop that i found fun characters: 11/10 i love every single one of them they all have such unique personalities that fit seamlessly with the gameplay mechanics. the artstyle is so creatively directed and it brings such a charm to every single npc and enemy in the game. music: heat. it's banger after banger, many of the songs went into playlists after finishing the game. story (for 95% of the game): great, fantastic, engaging, heartwrenching, a story of loss, friendship, love, grief, pain, joy, and forgiveness. story (for the final 5% of playtime): makes me more annoyed/frustrated the more i think about it. i don't want to get too much into spoilers, but the writers made a creative decision that undercuts the entire pathos of the story, subverts the themes of depressive masking and emotional shutdowns in a completely negative way, and (in my opinion) completely ruins any and all attachment and emotional connection developed with three of the six main characters. the final like, hour of this game makes me never want to play it again and it makes it impossible for me to recommend someone play in good faith, i think if the "twist" in the story never happened, and instead the writers just played the story straight with what they already had going on, the game would've been so, so, so much better. as it is, i'm not going to recommend you complete this game, reader. it is such a creatively beautiful and heartwrenching game that shoots itself in the foot trying to include a "shocking twist" that completely ruins the story in retrospect right as its about to cross the finish line. that fact ruins it all the more for me. final score: dissapointment / 10
i wanted to like this game and i really liked a lot of it, but i had to drop it because the combat was just dreadfully boring. story is incredible though. don't get unless you really hate fun combat.
pretentious pdfs think this game is good

i genuinely cannot stand to finish this game. the actual story outside of the fantasy world seems pretty well done, and near the beginning it shows you that it can actually be engaging with its horror elements, but then the game just drip feeds the good parts to you over hours of boring cutesy gameplay that seems like its trying way too hard to be charming and memorable. i liked earthbound so i figured i'd like this too, but when the game shows it can be something much cooler (the horror scenes) and then just doesnt put the effort into making the rest of the game nearly as interesting, it just makes everything seem disappointing. maybe i just came into this with the wrong perspective thinking it would be much more horror based, but id definitely still be able to stand this game if the silly parts were actually fun. sorry omory
this game is harder than street fighter six and 4 but not xrd that ones hard :(
i loved the game, but not having steam cloud for game saves is ridiculous. lost about 18 hours of progress after reinstalling windows. i am not going to start all over again.
perfect game for the people who cut their own wrists

i feel like i am losing my mind. genuinely feeling crazy seeing how much praise this game received vs how genuienly bad it is. i loved the lisa games, undertale, yume nikki, etc, so its not like im just a hater for this kind of game. this is just bad. nigh unplayable, it has pokemon combat, including a completely pointless "emotion" rock paper scissors mechanic that mimics the way pokemon types work. it even has dozens upon dozens of random combat encounters, except this is not pokemon and you dont capture anything, so they're just filler meant to slow you down and force you to interface with a boring and poorly baked combat system that shouldnt be there in the first place. after my first attempt, i got so exhausted i stopped playing, and when i came back just to try to experience the plot, i enabled cheats, and still took 13h to complete this. you could also call all the headspace sections of the story pointless filler as well, since they take forever, are not particularly well written or endearing and do not progress the plot in any way. tho ig that is a blessing in disguise because the plot feels like its competing with itself to see what levels of edgy it can reach without following any coherent sort of thematic throughline. no idea flows into each other and the plot twist is so ridiculous that it makes me question my sanity. this game has deeply twisted ideas about what kinds of actions can be resolved and forgiven by just "overcoming internal guilt" and "talking to your friends". bizarre experience. cannot believe ppl speak abt this in the same light as the lisa games.

that ending makes the game go from a gentle, emotional dialogue on mental health and depression, to a hyper-specific tragedy that no one can relate to anymore. i lost my emotional connection the moment we had the reveal, and just completely checked out for the last hour or two of the game. which sucks, because i was holding the game in really high regard before the reveal, and then had a complete 180.
tbh not my cup of tea but besides that the game just felt like a walking simulator.
the ending is abominable, actually terrible horrid shit lol. most of the game is great, including most of the story/writing. the ending just wipes it's crusty, fettid rear end with the story though.

i want to like this game. it has a good art style, but i like battles and narrative to utilize all of my focus. however i find myself wanting to play other games while clicking the same button and waiting for animations over and over. i also don't enjoy having to grind in order to defeat bosses instead of improving my skill.
i dont know i havent played it

[b]don't get me wrong[/b], i kind of enjoyed the game, especially the story and [b]probably only the story.[/b] gameplay is just... [i]unpolished?[/i] i mean i see that developers had some idea behind and it is not totally awful, but all gameplay mechanics are kinda boring or get stale very quickly. the only thing that carried me through 21 hours of gameplay is the story. but to be honest, it also have some problems, especially when you start thinking about [b]the ending[/b] and some staff that were left over with [b]no proper explanation[/b]. i cannot go into details since i don't want to spoil the main twist, so i will point out a different problem - the way developers tell you a story is so [b]time-consuming[/b]. there are so many fillers with absolutely [b]zero value to the plot[/b], especially when you get closer to the end – devs just started making any excuses just so you will spend more time in it. i got the feeling and really believe that devs could just cut [b]almost half of the game[/b] and it would only [b]benefit the game.[/b] but despite that, i got emotional at the end and [b]teared up[/b], so i gotta give devs credit for that - [b]story definitely can get to you[/b]. overall, i just don't get why it is [b]so appraised[/b] since it's just an [i]okay game[/i], with a pretty much [b]fine story[/b], but [b]absolutely terrible gameplay.[/b]
i really want to recommend this game, but i just can't. it's a really impactful story, but told in such a... strange way.

i cant lie i couldnt get into this game. got it because of all the high praise and recommendations and honestly i can see why it would be loved but it just wasnt for me. i can appreciate the gamestyle and aesthetic but i couldnt really get into the gameplay or storyline at all. i didnt understand what i was doing or what i was supposed to do most of the time even with help from others. really wish i was able to get into it because i love story-rich games and psychological horror is my fav genre, but omori just wasnt for me unfortunately. maybe i'll run it back in the future but for now, it just wasnt fun or immersive for me at all.

oneshot- это опыт, который ломает четвертую стену, достает тебя за душу и остается с тобой даже после титров. выбор в конце -между нико и миром, был тяжелым. когда нико сказал прощай и лампа погасла, чувствуется пустота. если попробовать зайти снова, игра напомнит тебе о твоем выборе. одна из немногих игр, которая разговаривает лично с тобой. 10/10

i can't really understand why people like this so much. it's pretty atmospheric, and niko achieves the bare minimum of being a generally likable character. the fourth wall is also broken in a cute and fascinating way. but nothing else really drew me in. by the end of my playthrough, i didn't feel any strong emotional investment to the world or characters. after looking up some more info on the game, i learned that i have to go into my files and tweak some things in order to play through it again. but honestly, i don't feel any desire to. this game heavily relies on the player being invested enough to want to try to play through a second time. it's why they hammer it home so frequently that you only have one chance, and can only make one choice for the ending. but if the characters and world are dull and uninteresting, it's only natural to not want to bother. the game's "mission" was to make me care, and it only had one shot.
if your pc run on mac, you cannot finish the game. too bad for such a good game

i was really enjoying this game, but the linux port is broken and under proton-ge i hit a point where i couldn't progress any further. it's a shame, because there are so many great things to say about this game but i wasn't able to finish it. the game authors made poor technical choices that were all but guaranteed to cause problems down the line. worse, they are not really necessary from a narrative perspective and come across as a bit gimmicky. anyway, i don't want to hate on the game too much because it is really nice in so many ways but i have to leave a negative review to warn people about potential technical issues. i have seen reports of these occurring on windows as well. so just be aware.
love this game with all my heart. everything good about it you've heard is true. linux version just doesn't work. i paid for a broken product and i want to protest ._.

various hints are broken on linux and the initial ending is just an endless loop i can't get out of thanks to an executable file that doesn't work no matter what i try. game itself is fun - just play it on windows.

the game relies on having an emotional connection to the characters, and i'm one of 5 people who didn't really have an emotional connection with the playable character but was curious enough to complete the game's true ending. though it was more one part curiosity with the plot, two parts sense of obligation to finish the games i pay for. as for the game itself, it's an rpgmaker game with puzzles that break the 4th wall. there were a few neat ideas with the puzzles, but the point of the game is more the story. if the writing doesn't click for you early on, i wouldn't recommend sticking with it.
good game but not for me

to be honest this game is incredibly boring. i'm not really sure how to describe it, it seems like it was made with a lot of passion, but i sort of lamented playing it. the story is not nearly as deep as people make it seem, and i genuinely didn't care about the outcome of the ending

i don't know why this crunchy rpg maker game is overwhelmingly positive. its got crunchy rpg maker graphics, and they want you to play windowed and on a modern monitor with how low res the game is that means you will be squinting at a tiny piece of your screen straining your eyes so make sure you have eye insurance before playing. the first area is extremely dark but i think that was intentional so you can't see how garbage the game looks. the games whole gimik to try to counteract this mediocrity is to break the 4th wall like a dora episode. you move at the pace of a snail but at least there is fast travel so you only have to crawl through each garbage area a a single time. maybe the game gets better idk but i don't know how anyone made it through the start.
fix the linux version of this game

good game, but the document it asked me to view just didnt exist on my pc. i even checked my entire pc but couldnt find it. im pretty sure it is a problem with my os because everyone else online who also couldnt find it was either using a similar os or just ignorant. this game was obviously designed with windows in mind and even though i have used windows my whole life, the direction it is going in now scares me and id rather not be caught up in the middle of it.

i love this game i really do. but strongly go against buying this game if you are on linux. the game was built for windows operating systems in mind. you can brute force your way through half the game using wine and bottles to open .exe files that can't be accessed on linux but at some point those systems fail and you hit a brick wall that you can't bypass without changing the games code. this happened to me when i got to the tower and the game wanted me to open that clover file whilst playing the game, i ran the file through wine and it opened but the game didn't recognise that it was open so it just closed again. i don't blame anyone expect the developers for this over sight. they could have just added a skip button that bypassed those scripted scenes but alas the game is unplayable on linux.

i feel like the game relies on the player forming a connection to the protagonist but i honestly didn't care for it so my short experience with it felt really thin and twee. maybe i would've enjoyed it a lot more if i was still young, but i'd say it's not worth playing as an adult.

becomes cliche and annoying with its meta-ness to where i cant get engaged with the story or puzzles. some puzzles later in the game are excessively convoluted and annoying to figure out. title is a lie
graphics are nice, story is underwhelming, gameplay is repetitive and the characters are shallow.

base game is good, although very overrated. music and visuals are charming, and the game gimmick is fun. the 10 bucks steam version adds newgame+ content, featuring a different "route" with a new ending. this new content is hidden from players, and is mediocre at best. it is empty, with barely any new rooms and no puzzles. it's poorly written (with lengthy jumbled explanations all over the place), and the story it tells completely shatters the purpose of the original game and its ending. overall, this doesn't justify the price. just play the original game for free, unless you want to financially support the creators of course.

i didn't want to give it a negative review. the game is good, but it's very difficult to play on linux and the game calls me stupid for this! [spoiler]okay, i can find proper documents folder from ~40 of them which are contained in different wine prefixes. okay, i was able to check forum to understand that i was supposed to see changed desktop wallpaper (is this really normal behavior for a game?) and then get help with chatgpt to figure out which file i should read to get registry settings. and what about that film puzzle, okay, it worked good. but at the end i did not understand how to make it run. so i think i had to run both of those exes? from specific proton environment or i don't understand. anyway at the end the game became broken for unknown reason, it just doesn't launch.[/spoiler] maybe it'd be better to buy oneshot world machine if it's playable on linux, but i had to be told before. + i need to mention that i needed to run it from proton because it doesn't launch on linux because of unproper glibc symbol or something like this. so don't believe in system requirements like any distro is okay. it's not.
i didn't like this game because all of the cool puzzles are locked behind beating the game once. and after i beat the game once i was just bored

i originally was interested in this game as i heard many great things about it and after playing well... i don't think it holds up. the main issue i have is the gameplay. almost everything is region locked, ie you can only get certain achievements in certain areas and there is no way to go back. also there is so much moving around that it becomes quite tedious with puzzles. speaking of tedious lets talk about the endings. now i haven't done solstice yet however i don't plan to. the issue is going out of the game into your files for important info. also in order to restart at any time for a run you need to start from the very beginning, which is just mind numbing and a waste of time. and also, the tower was never explained (you have to exit the game and boot it up again) and if you need to look at a outside guide to beat a puzzle, then frankly it isn't inituive and not a good puzzle game. the final issue is the whole taking over your wallpaper and documents. wow a fourth wall break how quirky. oh look i hijacked your wallpaper, which can be invalidated by fullscreen or wallpaper engine forcing you to look up the puzzle, which isn't ideal for a puzzle game, they should be intuive. also having to dig through my files just to find a password gets annoying. so overall, i just found this game tedious and also for a game called oneshot you can actually play as much as you want, not even oneshot.

it states linux support, but it's very broken on linux, it doesn't even run without manually messing with the files if you are using linux, do not play this game unless you want to debug why it's not running other than that it's a pretty good game, however i didn't get to experience the ending because of the support issues listed above

the game and its idea are great, but it doesn't work on linux properly. unlike windows, linux environments can vary greatly. [spoiler]when it "cleverly" modifies files on your system, it should do so in a way that always works, for instance by using available system facilities.[/spoiler] on my machine, the ending, for instance, simply does not (cannot) work. [spoiler]i managed to find out what was supposed to happen in some cases that didn't work, and thus managed to arrive at the ending, but there, i'm stuck, b/c the program it tries to run fails with various errors. i fixed one of them (broken librt), but didn't bother with the remainder of the error messages.[/spoiler] also, [spoiler]some of the puzzles aren't thought out properly, so you can get stuck in some situations, where you don't have the necessary items anymore.[/spoiler] so, to me, the game is partially broken. don't play this on linux.
really not sure what all the hype is about....fell asleep multiple times playing, too much walking, a lot of pointless dialogue.

absolute masterpiece. the level of immersion is unbelievable. the story is emotionally brutal, it pulls deeper and deeper until you're forced to confront existential questions you never expected to ask in a video game. it's a shame that gems like this get overshadowed by endless, mediocre live-service sh*t.
this game makes you feel depressed, lonely, and have an existential crisis. 10/10

soma is the first horror game i played in a long while after around a 5 year hiatus from gaming in which the last horror game i played was alien isolation. i gotta say the theme & horrors of soma regarding existantialist dread was a breath of fresh air. this also happens to be my very first game from frictional so i had zero expectation or biases from amnesia. the monsters & feeling of isolation you get from playing this game is on a whole another level. some of the monsters were not that scary but some are definitely notable highlights such as ackers, the weeping lady, the dude who follows you around definitely sends shiver down the spine. 10/10 highly recommend to anyone looking for a good existantialist horror game

love how this game gets you to think about the way consciousness works, the value of life, and whether a situation is deemed to be better than death. spoilers for the themes and an integral twist in the game: [spoiler]"native americans used to think photographs would steal your soul." it's not a cut and paste, it's a copy and paste. would i create a copy of myself to live a better life? yes. would it really fucking suck to continue being the doomed version? very much so, but it would make me feel better that there's a version of me out there that's getting another chance. i've always been a big supporter of the idea of transferring one's consciousness to a mechanical or virtual form in order to evade death, i just usually think of it as a transfer rather than a copy. that might just be idealistic thinking though due to the disconnect between biology and what might be capable with technology.[/spoiler] love this game. top tier story, walking simulator gameplay (i turned off the ability to die but the horror scenes felt just as tense, just less annoying. hope this studio makes another game build on an idea with the same vibe as this, rather than another amnesia sequel. 8.5/10 art or cool rating: art

even after a whole decade, i'd say this has to be one of the best story-driven games i've ever played. just the way the game makes you feel, especially at the end, is too good not to mention. simply put, this game is a masterpiece that everyone should play at least once

its a very delightful game....the chase scenes are intense.....and early on scare is scary....tho, at least for me, i found probably somewhere in delta-->theta that you dont really need to crouch...you can kinda just dodge everything and speedrun teh game, its not a very scary game, the story is great though. but..... ....... ....... the puzzles..... the naviagation....... please for your sanity watch a speedrun while playing because i spent 30 minutes in upsilon just trying to find the dam chip thing then an hour in delta navigating the ocean, lambda is a bit better...theta.....i dont wanna talk about it.... i woudl buy if you like story and horror walking sim do not buy if you dont like wondering if the exit even exists

this game is so magnificent that even when speedrunning it still manages to be scary in many aspects: its atmosphere, art direction and story, and mikko tarmia's score is one of the best pieces of music i've ever heard in gaming and it fits soma perfectly. frictional games is known for amnesia games, but i believe soma is their best game to date. looking forward to their next sci-fi project.

one of the best horror walking sims whatever you call this genre. compared to the amnesia games its more story driven and fewer potential deadly encounters (except for a machine for pigs, which doesn't count as an amnesia game anyway and only has three enemies) but there are enough crucial moments where you need to quickly decide if you have to hide or run (or just immediately die so that you are not so skerred anymore) - but the story elements are wonderful especially since so much is just experienced through game play rather than only being delivered by text dumps (but there's plenty of that in there to fill in the backstory), the themes and such in the story (identity, survival, etc.) were more real and visceral than what you usually get in horror games. i played with a friend (via streaming) and our incessesant speculation about what was going on and what would happen next (almost entirely wrong) made it much more engaging. also we thought the ending was presented badly then we decided no it was good actually, so there's that.

best game ever, you won't regret it. i have anxiety when playing horror games when it's in first person, so i am so pleased to inform others there's a safe mode so you won't die by creatures making it a lot easier for me to play. i couldn't continue alien isolation because of my condition so i'm glad i was actually able to play through and enjoy the game. i wish there had been more direction, mostly like an objective in the corner because i could never remember what to do, otherwise this game was solid. if you love to be confused and enjoy a good story line, this is the game for you. i could never piece the game together fully until i got close to the end. it made me want to play all the more for a clear understanding. it was an amazing game and the details were awesome. the graphics and the story worked together wonderfully, making it more and more confusing, which was exciting for me. loved it, took me 3 days to complete it kept me guessing and on my toes. buy the game, it was worth every cent. worth replaying just for the atmosphere alone, and of course i loved the story.

game has settings that say it will allow 120fps but in order to do so, you need to dig around in documents\my games\soma\main and manually set frame limit to "false" but it doesn't matter because even though the game and whatever overlay you use will say it's running at 120, it still runs at 60. just a bunch of config nonsense like how god eater 3 has config settings the same way but they don't actually apply through the in game menus. i don't care how old this game is, there's not reason to not run at 120 if you specifically list it as an option.

an incredibly linear experience filled with enemies that are there to mildly inconvenience and slow you down rather than actually have you interact with the game or environment in an engaging way. story is decent if not a little too predictable. if you like sci-fi stories you can probably guess where this one is going after the first hour or so of gameplay. it made a few interesting points about its themes, but nothing super thought provoking. filters (that can luckily be turned off in game settings) caused me significant headaches during multiple play sessions. i can't be too hard on this one as it is nearing a decade old and i got it for a dollar. buy it when it's on sale if you're looking for a decent story, but i'd really recommend playing in safe mode. the enemies are more of a nuisance than anything else.
10 years later and i'm still mad at how bad this was so it's high time i give it a piece of my mind.

витратив на це 6 годин, тому що шукав гру на тему свідомості та ші, а отримав бродилку по коридорам де розробники вимушують мене ховатися від ворога, який завжди знає за якою стіною мене шукати. виглядає як тупа заскриптована гра, де навіть коли ви сховалися від монстра, він буде стояти і чекати вас за найближчим кутом, коли вам нікуди взагалі йти далі. виходить ви застрягаєте на одному місці без можливості пройти далі. нічого страшного в грі немає, окрім нудної системи де читерський бот завжди знає де ви. якщо вам потрібен справжній горрор - грайте в alien: isolation.

the game asks some deep questions, such as "what does it mean if we interrupt game flow with constant search-your-way-in-the dark sections while providing zero clues on where to go?". well actually the answer is pretty easy - it means you're ruining an interesting story with terrible level design.

im done, im fucking done with these fucking games... fucken go to room click, search, run around n read fucken everything and nothing to progress you, oh but you werent clicking it right, fuck off. i like puzzles n shit, but not when you make zero change or progress for an hour pisses me off. i was in that stupid room where the robot carl was, i turned on power to 2 things, went to click the 3rd, cant do it, ok go to power switch that shuts off eveything n lets that bad robot in, i go to terminal again but i still cant turn that final switch on, i fucken run around avoiding the bad robot, clicking everything nothing changes, i got back to terminal just in case, oh look at that i can turn it on now. im in the water section, the indication to climb didnt appear for fucken ages, i tried moving boxes to jump up, fuck it i reload game, oh look at that climb indication. now im outside that room n in underwater, what the fuck where do i go, what do i do? again, i clicked everything and went everywhere, that robot i saved isnt doin shit.

boring. i am writing this 10 years after the game came out, with no prior expectations. soma is a relic of its time; terrible writing, some sci fi themes that have been thoroughly explored in other media and severely lacking gameplay. there is no combat to speak off, and arguably worse no stealth tools. you can only really crouch or run to avoid enemies which just makes it supremely boring to play.

hot garbage with a mandatory 60fps lock that can't be changed. the game says it's at 165hz but it simply isn't. unacceptable, even for the time when the game came out. renders the game unplayable on modern systems in 2025 unless you like looking at blurry smeary shit.

this game is very much a mixed bag. i'd say the strengths of this game are the atmosphere and design, the weaknesses navigation and, possibly controversial, the story. i have seen people praising this game for its story and saying they can't stop thinking about it and its ending. well, for me, the idea is there but the story fell pretty flat and it didn't really impact me. maybe also because i didn't find simon enough of a convincing/interesting protagonist. for me the game was picking up once you get to theta and you encounter more enemies. but until then there was a lot of just walking around, not really knowing where to go and what to do and this was kind of frustrating and not very fun to play. i guess it fits the theme of simon waking up and being a bit lost but i almost quit the game because of it. that being said it is mainly a walking simulator with having to get random items and sections of hiding/running from/sneaking around monsters. one thing i liked about that is that you had to approach each monster with a different tactic. regarding the ending: [spoiler] i wish there was an option not to launch the ark, just shut down the wau and that's it because i'm not convinced it was the right decision. sure, "humanity" lives on but actually you are just brain scans on a harddrive floating in space. i wouldn't call that living. i wish there was an option that if you stop the wau and everything just shuts down. roll the end credits [/spoiler]

⭐ devour – the best co-op horror experience out there ⭐ rating: ★★★★★ (5/5) devour is easily one of the best co-op horror games i’ve played. the tension, atmosphere, and unpredictable gameplay keep you on edge from start to finish. every map feels unique, every run feels different, and the jump scares never get old — even when you think you’re ready. the game rewards teamwork, communication, and strategy. when things go wrong (and they will), the chaos is actually the fun part. whether you’re running from demons, collecting objectives, or reviving teammates in panic, the adrenaline rush is unmatched. the developers keep the game fresh with updates, new maps, and challenges, making it a title you can return to again and again. smooth performance, creepy sound design, and smart difficulty scaling make devour stand out from other indie horror games. if you enjoy horror, teamwork, and intense moments that make your heart race, devour is absolutely the best co-op horror game to pick up. highly recommended.
over the years i had many fun and exciting moments playing this game with friends, we're still getting together whenever a new map releases. certainly recommend it if you have someone to play with.

solid multiplayer game. firstly, this game isn't the smoothest. interact prompts can be weird, the map balance is off, and some animations are pretty cheesy and rigid. however i am surprised at the variety in this game. you look at this game and think, "so i do this one thing over and over with new coats of paint?" well, no. weirdly enough while the goal and basic, find x and use on specific spot 10 times never changes, but the "how to" changes and it can get pretty enjoyable. the maps are really fun and different. the maps shift from open to tight hallways really well. there is also really fun spots to jump railings and evade the monster. the maps are also really well designed and i like how not one map looks or feels like another. solid multiplayer game, play it with your friends for a fun time.

devour is the perfect mix of panic, teamwork, and “why did i agree to this?” it’s a surprisingly intense co-op horror game where every round feels like a frantic scramble between collecting items and getting jump-scared. the maps are creepy, the progression of the demon keeps the pressure high, and playing with friends is chaotic fun. it’s simple, replayable, and absolutely terrifying in the best way. if you enjoy shouting at your friends while running for your life, this one’s a must-try.

one of the best and most fun co-op horror games you can get. definitely best in this genre. right now this game has 7 maps, hopefully more to come, with 4 difficulties ranging from easy to nightmare. so there is something for everyone. each map has similar gameplay which is burn/sacrifice 10 specific items but different enough for each map so the gameplay isn't stale or boring. also it has a bunch of achievements to grind after you completed all of the maps if you're into that. i've seen some people complaining about jumpscare sound being too loud and i wish there is an option to lower just that sound a bit but you can also turn it off completely if it's bothering you. it's best to play with friends since people come and go on this game with most players coming back to play the game again around new map release. sometimes it's hard to find public lobbies, their official discord is decent place to find people to play with but not the best. overall 10/10 game. definitely would recommend it to all co-op horror fans.

devour tries to present itself as a horror game, but in reality, it feels much more like a task-based challenge than a genuinely scary experience. the premise is intriguing: a group of players trying to stop a demonic cult while being hunted by a possessed entity, but the supposed horror quickly fades once you realize most of the game revolves around completing objectives and managing resources efficiently. for the majority of the time, you’re not scared: you’re busy collecting items, burning or purifying objects, and coordinating with teammates. the gameplay focuses heavily on timing, organization, and communication rather than actual fear or atmosphere. jump scares do happen, but they quickly lose impact once you understand that everything follows a predictable pattern. after a few rounds, the game’s formula becomes painfully repetitive. the entity stops being terrifying and instead turns into an annoying obstacle disrupting your checklist. devour might offer brief moments of tension or adrenaline, but it’s far from what you’d expect from a true horror experience. in the end, it’s a game that demands tryharding more than courage, and once the illusion of fear fades, what remains is a repetitive, mechanical loop with little to no genuine terror.

genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, Strategy, Free To Play
review_text: after sinking over 450 hours into paladins, i can confidently say this is one of the most enjoyable hero shooters you can get—especially for free. is paladins perfect? no. the matchmaking can be hit-or-miss, and balance patches sometimes feel like they were decided by throwing darts at a board. but when the gameplay clicks it’s genuinely some of the most fun i’ve had in a shooter. for anyone wondering if paladins is worth trying or returning to: yes. absolutely. it’s chaotic, stylish, surprisingly strategic, and still manages to be addictive after hundreds of hours. if you’re willing to embrace its quirks, you’ll find a game with a ton of depth and replayability. 450 hours later, and i’m still not done.

review_text: been years since i last played. apparently it's now winding down in activity. seems like i never made a review for this. better late than never. all in all, i liked the gameplay. but disliked the "free-to-play" monetization. every new character (non-free) they introduced was always op, until they introduced a new character (again op) and "re-balanced" the earlier one. you could usually pay for them with an exorbitant amount of in-game currency, or a fairly small sum of real-life money. so "free-to-play" became "pay-to-win". i especially liked the character skill/attribute customization options, where you could build your character to your own play-style. there might not be overly many players online, anymore, but i would recommend trying this. skye ftw!

genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, Strategy, Free To Play
review_text: a 5v5 team-based shooter like paladins looked very promising on paper. it had a good variety of maps, a large roster of unique champions with different abilities, and even a shop system where you could buy extra perks to improve your stats. the gameplay felt fast and dynamic - fights were happening all the time, yet it never felt overwhelming or chaotic. the balance and anti-cheat existed, though not always in their best shape. still, for a while, the game managed to stay alive, build its own community, and even have an esports scene. but as time went on, it stopped evolving. players began complaining that the only updates were new skins, while major improvements were nowhere to be seen. the game had squeezed out everything it could from its audience - and decline followed. it's not a bad game by any means, but today it's simply not worth your attention anymore. ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ ☆ ☆ ☆ ☆ ☆ (5/10)

genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, Strategy, Free To Play
review_text: as a longtime paladins player, the matchmaking and balance issues have really ruined the ranked experience for me lately. way too often, my team gets paired against players who are obviously way more skilled or ranked much higher, turning matches into totally one sided stomps. it’s super demotivating when you realize that winning or losing feels out of your hands not because of how well you or your team plays, but simply because the matchmaking threw together teams of wildly different levels. frankly, i want my effort and skill to matter, not just luck or who got stacked on my team. recent matchmaking changes have only made things worse. matches feel even less fair than before, with the system regularly putting beginners against top-tier veterans, or grouping talent in ways that just don’t make sense. sometimes i feel like the queue cares more about filling spots quickly than about actually creating competitive, fun games. all this randomness means i rarely enjoy ranked anymore, since i don’t get consistent, challenging matches with players on my level. honestly, unless the developers address the core of these matchmaking and balance problems pairing teams based on actual performance and skill rather than random chance i just don’t see myself having fun in ranked mode anymore. competitive play needs to be fair, and right now, it’s just not

review_text: played til i was level 14 and was flamed last 10 games for who i picked and not doing good enough... community is more toxic than league of legends so much so i can't even stay long enough to properly learn the game... even in the "rookie" mode for newcomers i couldnt find a match without waiting 5-10 minutes a match....in game it felt bad dying and not rewarding killing. the item "auto buy" felt sloppy cause i couldnt set it how i wanted it to auto buy, or if you can- its not streamlined enough to be obvious in game. the "frontline" champs were the only people i could play without getting murdered and i really didnt find any champ that felt "good" to play. the "good" champs are 30k each, and after saving 20+ games winnings i finally bought the guy i was looking at. turns out, he sucks! so now, after that, i gotta do it again..save another 30k. why are the champs costing coins? feels just.. so bad for a new player.. no single player mode to even test a champ out before you buy it?? last 5 champs i bought i research, watch, fought against, then when i went to buy them i realized just how bad they are in an actual game. game felt stale in about 3 days. frustrating, toxic, and stale. i'll be finding something else.

review_text: from someone that has played this game a ton over the year i unfortunately cannot recommend this game. i am finally uninstalling after years of frustration. the game itself it wonderful and enjoyable if you can get into a match with 9 other actual players. more than 50% of the games result in someone leaving after dying 1 time and with a hero fighter like this that means the match is already over. you can not win a 4vs5 match in this game and reporting people does absolutely nothing. so you will basically have fun maybe 25% of the time because either your team leaves or the other team leaves and you are just playing against bots. you either steam roll them or get killed because of the bots on your team. if this game was actually popular and the developers took it seriously it would be one of my favorite games. after about 9 years of playing i am finally giving up on this game having any hope.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Free To Play
review_text: path of exile completely changed the way i look at arpgs. what started as a casual curiosity turned into one of the most immersive gaming experiences i’ve ever had. the depth of its skill system, the freedom to build your character in countless unique ways, and the constant introduction of new leagues make the game feel endlessly fresh. what truly stands out is how rewarding it feels to grow your character. every upgrade, every crafted item, every perfected build comes from your own effort and creativity. it’s a game that challenges you, but it also inspires you to think, experiment, and push your limits. path of exile didn’t just raise my standards for arpgs. it completely redefined them. if you love meaningful progression, complex systems, and worlds that pull you in and don’t let go, this game is a must-play.

review_text: the game is extremely poorly optimized. the skills are all boring and because any character can use any skill gem, there is no atmosphere or aura to any character played. it's basically a game for chair gremlins who want to grind resources to make up for a small pp, which is what is confirmed when you look at these twitch streamers they throw their moneybags at. the worst offense is how utterly bloated this game is with 'content'. poe when i first played it was a crappy but interesting arpg you could put a week or two into every few years and zone out on some maps and areas. now, there are 15 different events that pop up on every single area. yeah, you can ignore these 'pop ups', but now you are missing out on currency and possibly upgrades. these 'pop ups' basically ruin the game for anyone who is an adult and not some twitch chair gremlin micropener. the game loses any atmosphere it had and just feels clunky, cheap, and fomo'ey. but we live with this new generation of buffoons who can't go 1.2 seconds without a dopamine hit, so there needs to be special chests and events popping up literally every 5 seconds of speedfarming. it's horrible. even diablo 4 trashes this game. stick to older arpgs that aren't super bloated with boring currency mechanics designed to keep the user enslaved to the game.

"the "memory game" in path of exile has not been removed because it is a core part of the maven's boss fight, intended to be a unique skill check that tests a player's reaction and memory, not just damage output. while many players dislike the mechanic and may seek to minimize its impact by overpowering the fight with high damage, removing it would fundamentally change the intended design of the encounter." i n t e n d e d haha look at this retard can't remember no fun for you!

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Free To Play
review_text: it just isn't fun. poe was the diablo 3 people wanted back in the day: it was a passion project that filled the "no, we want more d2" gap left by blizzard. and so for that, it was good. but as it continued, the complexity and customization only increased. and now the world has moved on. loot games have evolved. and this game is unapologetically complex because it believes that is what you should want. i'm sure it gets amazing once you get deep into its systems, but last epoch is right there, folks. and even diablo 4, lost ark, and a million others - including poe 2. if you want unlimited customization which is only possible with unlimited complexity, then this game may do it for you. but otherwise, you can do better.

this game has a surprising amount of depth despite seeming like a simple rpg on the surface. the game's balance is impeccable, every new area and boss is challenging but not overwhelming and you are always rewarded for your curiosity and exploration. the post-launch support has been among the best that i've seen in any game, with mod support and even a built-in randomizer that makes the game insanely replayable. absolute hidden gem!
this game is the best i've ever played.

ok this one was kind of cheating because i did finish most of it and then just went and learned the speedrun, so i technically didn't "beat" it casually, but whatever this is just your standard turn-based rpg combat-wise, nothing too fancy here. you go around the world touching crystals, which unlock new classes, and then eventually beat the final boss, with all of your accumulated crystal knowledge. the special sauce it has is the entire world is open to movement, and if you're good at jumping or spotting the patterns you can get places waaaaaaaay before you're intended to. this game is very interesting! it's plot-light, there are npc interactions you can find as you go around the world, but the main draw of this game is its heavy focus on builds. you can mix and match classes easily, and not only that, you can mix and match stat growths from classes. this doesn't affect tooooo much if you're just playing casually, but if you want to minmax this is absolutely the game for you. it felt like a slog for me a few times, but once i understood where to put my focus everything crystallized fairly well. the movement in this game is very satisfying. there's a sprint mount, a swim mount, and a fly mount, among others, and all of them feel really good to use.
great gameplay. can't wait for crystal project 2
there is a lot of exploring and very little story. imo this is a positive because story usually gets in the way of freely exploring.

very fun game! if you like to explore and find hidden secrets, this game really scratches that itch. the battle and class system is really good too. there is a very generous demo available as well which you can transfer your progress over to the full game. definitely recommended!

crystal project has an amazing sense of adventure! easily one of the top 10 games of the decade for me. its open world feels on par with titles like breath of the wild and elden ring, offering true freedom and discovery at every turn. the class system is brilliantly designed, allowing for countless creative strategies and builds. the itemization is deep and rewarding, making exploration and experimentation feel meaningful. on top of that, the game is packed with thoughtful quality-of-life features that make the whole experience smooth and enjoyable. easly 10/10

this game is heavily inspired by old school jrpgs—to include punishing battles, grinding, and a complete lack of hand-holding. the game eschews traditional puzzle solving in favor of platforming and exploration, metroidvania-style. the story is minimal, and the cinematics are non-existent. if that doesn't appeal to you, then don't buy the game because you won't like it. if that does appeal to you, then buy the game, because it does all of those things at a really high level. the two complaints i have are somewhat minor: 1. the difficulty settings are easy, normal, and hard when they really should be normal, hard, and "i hate myself". under the description for normal, there is an explanation that there won't be much grinding. that's not even close to true. the game is still quite punishing on normal, and one of the most common complaints i've seen is that the difficulty spikes are ridiculous. if the developer had just renamed easy to normal and so on (sparing a lot of people's pride, myself included), they could have avoided this entirely. 2. the map system sucks. it should just track the area the player has explored. instead, the game gate-keeps this function needlessly. this is easily the worst part of the game, and the other biggest complaint i've seen. without looking things up online, you'll spend a lot of time wandering. again though, if this is the kind of game you'd normally like, then you'll love this. for a cheap game made by a single developer, it's an absolute gem.
great game if you love rpgs.

hell of a beast! ❤️ kudos to andrew. **warning bit of spoiler** while normally i'm a bit of a sucker for a story in my jrpg's., this one has none present, short, albeit funny dialogues here and there. the gameplay of platforming and metroidvania as well as the jrpg with different classes / sub classes / wpns / gear / acc's / archive entry etc got me hooked! quintar breeding was a pain, but oh so worth for sequoia tree, got pretty close to the top with owl & salmon but wanted to die x.x, never again. do not suggest unless you're into pain and rage, masochistic style. currently bulking for the 4 superboss in the depths, 1 down 3 to go. there are assist options if you feel you need a bit of a break on certain aspects of the game. imo the 3 homepoints are a must. others at your leisure, i find most stuff balanced as is. the music is superb, really immersive. the world is fun to uncover, and i know some of you, like me, will reach out for every corner of the map possible. 😁 mini games are harsh at first, but becomes easier as it goes. quintar breeding is money and time consuming. there are ways to break and fast forward the games progression, as this is non-linear game. speedruns are out there on every crystals. workshop supported and lots of guides and videos online. def recommend, two thumbs & two big toes up. 👍🏻👍🏻🦶🏻🦶🏻

i'm surprised i haven't heard almost anyone talk about this game given how good it is. excellent freeform exploration ripe with stuff to find and shortcuts that allow multiple ways of accessing almost every location, solid combat system (i disagree with some balancing decisions, but overall it keeps things appropriately difficult the whole game), very-very light on story. it's more or less exactly the game i wanted after finishing octopath traveler ii
pixels, rpg, exploration, classes, skils.... perfect
amazing game. doing what most jrpgs don't do anymore: having great gameplay

dont feel like writing a long review. tldr one of the best game worlds i have ever played trough, the design of the map itself gives the game so much character it is not comparable. the game was obiviously heavily play tested and it shows. its 10 bucks, trying it wont hurt. and if you dont like the current job balance (i dont lol) there are rework mods that change that.

it's a great blend of the job system from ff5, a minecraft parkour map, and a metroidvania. if you like all of those, then this is a fantastic game, but you really have to be into all of them for the game to truly shine. the combat is good, lots of different class combinations and interesting setups you can make. the game is very difficult by normal jrpg standards, but there are a plenty of ways to break the system. the game even has a preset system that lets you save specific setups so you can swap them easily. the exploration is good, very open-ended and tons of little secrets to find. it can be a bit tedious to get around, as even with all of the teleport stones it can take a couple of minutes to get to where you need to go. none of the areas really stand out in terms of level design, but there are tons of skips and tricky jumps you can make to completely break the intended order of progression. the platforming is, in my opinion, the weakest aspect. it's fine, for the most part, but there are way too many areas where one missed jump can set you back upwards of five minutes to get back and try again. areas with platforms over spikes or water were the best, since there if you miss a jump at least it puts you back where fell from. nothing stings worse than missing the final jump in a section and falling all the way back to the bottom. definitely worth it if you like all three of the genres it's blending. if any of those are a turn off for you, it's probably best to just skip this one.
owlbear is just fking stupid
a very well-made passion project. super fun exploration, good combat, good progression, amazing class system (including multiclassing). 9/10
great gameplay, great environments, great music, great class system. would highly recommend to any rpg fan.

perfect rpg for an rpg hater like myself. specifically: * i'm not interested in story or dialogue. the game has minimal both. * i want combat to be interesting and not a grind. here, it's similar to slay the spire in that it's almost a puzzle: the enemies broadcast their upcoming actions and you need to both plan and react accordingly, rather than just apply a broad strategy. (sometimes the normal enemy encounters can feel a bit repetitive) * traversing the world is actually interesting, and only restricted by your movement/inventory rather than plot triggers. * skill trees and character customization are deep enough to be interesting, but simple enough to not warrant analysis paralysis. * effectively no decision is irreversible, and no missables. if you ever want to pivot to a different strategy it's always an option, and just requires light time and resources. and there's no sense of "don't miss stealing an item from this boss" * you feel you can liberally use items. there's no sense of "save all your megalixers!" i can't imagine an rpg that's more in line with what i want out of an rpg. (fully completed on switch)

100% recommended, i'm enjoying this game a lot. kind of like a mashup of old school final fantasy and elden ring huge world and the exploration is awesome, nice music, some challenge but not too difficult and was this made by 1 person?? crazy edit: i took a break and came back to finish the game. i will say that the level cap is unfortunate, because some of the end game bosses will still be quite difficult even when you've reached max level. you can lower the difficulty, but it can't be increased after it has been lowered. makes no sense to me and i'm stuck on easy now normal difficulty was fine for most of the game, but some of the later bosses feel pretty unfair the worst part of the whole game, though, has to be the quintar racing/breeding. not only because the racing is difficult and not very fun, but also because you need to breed a golden quintar to access at least 2 areas in game. and for that, you will need to win a lot of races and spend a shit-ton of gold to feed your quintars which get hungry every 2 seconds. so then you might actually need to grind to get gold to feed your quintars, which is the absolute opposite of fun summary: very fun overall, huge game world with much to explore, but the end of the main game and the post game are disappointing for sure
good recent ffv job system combined with 2.5d platforming.
just finished my first playthrough and got all achievements at just under 50 hours of playtime. incredible game for the price.

what an absolute journey, this game really embodies the essence of adventures. with an expansive world to explore and plenty treasure chests rewarding the curious. not to mention the many wonderful songs playing as you go (if i could, i'd buy it to listen to). the combat offers a deceptively interesting system, with a handful of classes to play around with. this game offers a challenge, a journey and a story you make yourself - since there really isn't a deep one other than the overall theme. i can highly recommend this to any rpg lovers
if you like minecraft parkour or final fantasy 1 you will love this game.
a game so good i've bought it on multiple platforms.
