one of my fav games. play it!!!!!!!

it's just fun. if you want a game with lots of freedom and deep combat that feels like the fever dream of a ff3/ff5 fan, then this is a game i think you'll love. if you want a deep story...it doesn't really have that, but there's a little something here that pops up from time to time. really this game is about the exploration, the fights, tinkering with your party's builds, and even some solid laughs. sometimes a game just clicks for you, and for me this is one of those games. plus it's super inexpensive and has mod support! it's great!

one of the best classic turn-based rpg i have ever played. simple graphics, very fun to explore world with a variety of enemies, bosses and biomes. you mix and match abilities from different classes to create your party of 4, lots of combos to optimize for different bosses. you can choose to customize the difficulty perfect for you, i cranked it to the max and had fun creating builds for the hardest endgame bosses and their gimmicks. multiple times i was surprised at finding out many new areas when i was expecting to be at the end of the game, also you need to actively chase down and defeat summons before they become available as skills for the summoner so 10/10
amazing game, i enjoyed every aspect of it!
i love it so far. it makes me feel honestly really nice to be playing it. although i do get confused at some points of the game.

i'm a huge fan of final fantasy 5, and crystal project scratches that itch for me better than any other game. tons of classes to play around with, and they all have their own skill trees so you can prioritize the order they learn abilities. (i only have 12 minutes in the game because i played through it on console. however, since it is such a great game i look forward to playing through it again on steam.)
amazing game, long and difficult. if you want good jrpg, pick this one up. worth the 14 dollars for sure.

deceptively deep combat system and great exploration mechanics and rewards. some of the endgame stuff has a bit more friction than i'd like (like the golden quintar process), but that didn't stop me from thoroughly enjoying this game.
underrated gem. open world rpg with amazing depth

this game spits in the face of modern jrpg qol. everywhere is cumbersome to get to, there is no fast travel, you can't speed up or skip common battles, you can't even use items in battle, you can't even run from battles. there are very few inns and getting back to them is a pain. currency is scarce. every single battle is a challenge - which at first is kinda cool, but after manual trudge back into zone x and having to fight every single common enemy that you don't literally outrun... it gets old fast. especially when you don't have a ton of time to sink into games. even the most common enemies are extremely op and getting one-shotted is all too common (and annoying). they introduce taunt which seems great in premise but, you have to taunt each enemy individually so your healer will get smacked. any game that copy/pastes ff5's job system gets major kudos from me, but it turned out to just be too much of a slog, especially when compared to its contemporaries. ultimately, crystal project introduces unique gameplay mechanics, but fails to even get the basics right.

i'm sad to give this game a negative review because it has so much promise in the beginning. exploring is fun, finding secrets or hard to reach treasures that give you an advantage feels rewarding, and the variety of classes hints at some fun mix and match experimentation ala ff5 or fft. unfortunately, a lot of this falls apart as early as the mid game. basic enemies can frequently kill party members in one or two hits, the jumps used for progress start to get ridiculous, areas are hidden behind terrain that you can't see, and bosses require specific setups rather than allowing for any party comps. the class you're playing when you level up affects your stat gains, but you can pay to reallocate the gains, which means grinding for money against enemies that can easily kill your party, or using specific attack patterns to make the fights trivial, but also a slough. the point of making generic enemies this difficult is to avoid the problem of "mash attack" that pops up in a lot of jrpgs, but instead becomes "cycle through menus for the same attack pattern," which is basically the same thing with extra steps. add into that the expensive mp cost for abilities and relatively low mp pool of your characters, and everything becomes a tedious, plodding chore. i want to like this game. there's so much potential, but i just can't force myself to play anymore.

there are some parts of this game i like, but overall i can't recommend it as it copies too many of the bad parts of final fantasy too. i really like the exploration, which reminds me of crosscode, and it is very similar with the influences from final fantasy too. however, unlike crosscode, the slow battles make the grindy combat very tedious, especially when most fights require no tactics whatsoever, just repeatedly bonking the enemies until they die. it reminds me of the bad parts of final fantasy: mystic quest - which is a shame as the exploration part is done very well.

the game is unnecessarily hardcore with mechanics which just don't bring any pleasure. like unlocking classes, which apparently you need to change while playing... you can't develop love towards your character at this pace. the mine-craft block style map was something unusual for me to see, but in the end it's just depressing because the majority of secrets are hidden in between these blocks, with crazy jumping mechanics of 'press longer to jump a bit higher'... i did my best to really make myself play the game and at least understand what a hell i am actaully doing it. until... you get a message on the message board that the only sense of all what i am doing is ... looking for crystals... which depresses me, because... crystals unlock classes... (which i would never transform into during playing because i created the characters as per my own understanding...) ... and serve as requirements to go further in game... to sum up - it's exceptionally boring, with great soundtracks, drugged monster sprites (which i liked), mana troubles and too much complication. also, there is not a single thing about jrpg in it. apart from final fantasy hero sprites... wish i could refund these 6 hours back to my life.

hardcore grindfest with minimal mechanics or fun strategies, barely any depth outside of it having a great open world design. if you want a casual rpg look elsewhere. this one on the "no grinding" normal mode has unbearable amounts of grinding due to horrid game balance the soundtracks, and artwork are nice but it has no story and there are hundreds of amazing rpgs you should play instead. this is a last resort one if you want to torture yourself with dull gameplay.
expected 95% jrpg with 5% platforming, got 95% platforming with 5% jrpg

honestly, i do like this game, it's a unique spin on an rpg. but it is completely ridiculous, certain enemies can just completely mop your party without any warning, and the leveling curve is absurd. not to mention all the awkward platforming to get to certain places. honestly, it's a good game, but it really needs some polishing.

there's some parts of this game that make me want to tear my hair out. the racing mechanics, the grinding, strange difficulty curves later in game, how vague the game progression/direction is. it has a lot to like, but at the end of the day it's a frustrating experience that i can't recommend.

unfortunately the platforming aspect of this game is awful and just gets worse and worse as you play it. the shoju ninja village is just oppressively awful as every missed jump is a minute plus walk back and you can't move the camera more than like 15 degrees in each direction to get a clear picture on the jumping. add to that a character that slides around and having to use multiple different types of mounts to make different jumps and it just completely falls apart. too bad as ffv like jobs system and combat and gear is overall pretty good. better gear than ffv and tactics, but worse class combos (.... er.... what class combos really....). don't bother if you just wanted more ffv, ffvi or fft. there are better games out there for this fix!

this game was pretty fun, right up until i realized that there is literally nothing to it to keep you coming back, unless you want to install mods. without mods, this game is a shell of an rpg. more to the point, if you want to have any kind of actual "fun" in game, you basically have to learn to use crystal edit to improve the game and classes yourself, otherwise you'll always feel under-powered, under-leveled, and ill-equipped. i shouldn't need to go into the game files and make the game what i want myself. i hate that i paid money for this. don't buy this game. seriously. i play the game still, but only because i changed it to be what i wanted it to be, not because it was fun already.

i loved this game, but i don't know a single person i like that i would recomend it to. this game is a hard jrpg but a brutal platformer with some sadistic minigames. there are platform challenges that can take several minutes to re-attempt if you fall to a place that doesn't kill you and are frame/pixel perfect. this game doesn't respect you or your time.

a decent game absolutely ruined by the creator's sadistic and unnecessary approach to platforming. massive sections where a single mistake will reset 10-15 minutes of progress await you in the end-game. find another rpg with classes and play it instead.

i'm disappointed i didn't manage to get into this game, seeing how positively it is generally regarded. you really, really have to love platforming not to find the exploration part frustrating. it's just an endless series of jumping puzzles with little direction and plenty of nasty punishments if you mess up (long backtrack, unwelcome fights etc.). the combat is good and the character building is a nice riff on the old ff system. but it's mainly the boss fights that are great. the regular fights feel a little overtuned. they're doable of course, but tax your attention and resources (potions to refill mana mainly) and the combat isn't quite interesting enough to make me want to do 10 semi-risky trash fights just to traverse some zone. you can avoid lots of fights, but that relies heavily on being good at the platforming parts.

cons: [b]#1.[/b] no mouse support (which makes overworld movement obtuse and menu navigation even more obtuse). [b]#2.[/b] huge lack of information provided to the player, like when creating your party at the start of the game, or when selecting the difficulty setting, there's almost no information provided. [b]#3.[/b] no reliable fast travel to previously visited locations / towns. [b]#4.[/b] a gigantic amount of platforming. [b]#5.[/b] if you save at a savepoint, and load that save, you're taken back to your single 'home point' instead of spawning at the location where you saved. this makes no sense. if a reliable form of fast travelling was implemented, then perhaps i could bring myself to shifting my overall opinion to slightly positive, but honestly, the lack of fast travel is going to waste hours and hours of your life in the game, and that's something i can't abide by (i'm not talking about the 11shrines in the game, those don't even take you to 10% of the places you'd want to go, like nan's place or the fishing place, etc.)... i simply value my time too much to spend it backtracking for hours. i'd honestly rather replay earthlock or ff9 than play this game anymore. i'll check back in a year or so to see if #1 & #3 was fixed atleast, perhaps then i'll give it another go for more reviews, visit my curator page: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/7851637/ for my full recommended list of games: https://steamcommunity.com/id/lfpg/recommended/

ok... i really want to like the game, and find the openness very interesting... but (in my short time playing) literally 70% of all my time is just spent on jumping puzzles. it's cute having a couple secrets be tough to jump to, but literally progressing all my quests and areas is based on jumping puzzles (with a map that doesnt rotate). i just spent 45 minutes trying to get a final dog bone that i can see, but never figured out how to jump to it.
it had some clever ideas but ultimately it felt more and more like a slog to get through.

i like everything about this game except for the overworld. there's a job system! there are unlockable classes! there are no random encounters! unfortunately, none of that matters when you're lost: you're just going to spend hours wandering around on an empty map. i don't have the patience for that. at least give us a hint of where to go, please. 2025-03-09 - i love almost everything about this game, so much so that i struggled through the parts that annoy me, or that i strongly dislike: the huge, empty world with no direction is tedious, but you can at least keep a guide open in another window. the platforming challenges are awful, especially when you can't see the xyz coordinates of where you're supposed to be jumping, so you just have to guess, die, and try again; but at least the auto jump option helps in some instances. but what i hate is how, at the very end of the game, in the final dungeon, there's an unskippable platforming/ice block challenge which is longer and more difficult than just about any other obstacle in the game. if you start this game, you might not be able to finish it, but you won't know until you've wasted dozens of hours.

a fast, tactile vr fps that channels a counter-strike-like energy: tight rounds, bomb plants/defuses, and clutch moments, translated into full-body presence. manual mag handling, bolt pulls, and sight alignment make every reload and peek feel earned. gameplay & mechanics — 8/10 snappy gunfeel with satisfying manual reloading and clear hit feedback. movement options cover stick locomotion and smooth turning; room-scale peeking around corners is a genuine edge. occasional jank and the learning curve on weapon handling can spike early deaths, but mastery is rewarding. modes & content — 8/10 classic search & destroy sits alongside a grab bag of community favorites (ttt, zombies, ww2, gun game). the workshop/custom servers are the secret sauce - maps and modes keep the playlist fresh, though quality varies server to server. presentation & audio — 8/10 clean visuals for quick reads under headset constraints; positional audio and proximity voice chat add tension (and hilarious chaos). not a visual showpiece, but it prioritizes clarity where it counts. comfort & accessibility — 7/10 smooth locomotion can challenge vr newcomers; comfort tweaks help, but motion-sickness-prone players may need shorter sessions. weapon manipulation is immersive but demands practice and decent controller tracking. conclusion pavlov vr is a fun, counter-strike-like arena shooter made better by vr’s hands-on gunplay and a thriving custom scene. it’s not the most polished or guided experience, but if you want competitive rounds with real-world reloading and endless community variety, it delivers. score: 82/100

breaks my heart to not recommend this game, but it's just simply dead at this point. the game thrived on mods with players making crazy custom modes and maps. you could easily lose yourself for hours in the variety. the devs made the decision to move everything to ue 5, and in the process essentially nullified all existing mods. the issue with doing that to a game that's been out for a while is that a lot of the modders aren't actively keeping things up to date, so we lost all the cod zombie maps and have only gotten 1 or two back a while later after some dedicated modders revived them. so in short, the devs attempt to shore up the game is the very thing that ended up breaking everything good about it, which has led to an exodus of the playerbase. at this point, its maybe one or two populated servers, and then a ton of private lobbies and empty lobbies. and sadly, i can't blame them. keep in mind, this game made the move to ue 5 in summer of 2023. plenty of time to fix it up for the modding community, so this is not just a matter of impatience but an active decision to stall / not consider it. since the update, i've installed the game twice in the last year to see where it's at, and sadly it seems mostly everything has stopped dead in feb. no new mods really, no new dev updates, no new mod kit expansions to allow for the people still playing to save it. save your money and just accept that you missed out on this title when it was king, and if you pick it up now it will be a shell of it's former self.

if you bought a vr headset to play on pc and are considering pavlov as your first vr fps, here’s my honest review. the game itself is very well-made, offering solid mechanics and immersive gunplay, but the experience you’ll actually have depends heavily on who you’re playing with and that’s where things start to fall apart. first off, most of the pc servers are practically dead. the player base is much smaller compared to the pavlov shack version on quest, which means finding active and populated lobbies can be a struggle. even when you do find one, pavlov isn’t beginner-friendly at all. the community tends to be impatient and impulsive in modes like ttt, players will often kill you for no reason, with little to no cooperation or understanding for newcomers. if you’re new, you’ll likely find it frustrating trying to compete against experienced players who play daily and have the right equipment. it’s hard to have fun when the learning curve feels more punishing than engaging. because of that, i’d only recommend pavlov if you plan to play with a group of your own friends. playing with randoms from the community is rarely a pleasant or viable option. the game has great potential and craftsmanship, but without a stable, welcoming player base, it ends up feeling more isolating than enjoyable.

disappointing performance and accessibility issues i was really looking forward to trying pavlov vr, but unfortunately the performance issues made it hard to enjoy. even with an rtx 3070 and a ryzen 9 3950x, the game runs very poorly — with frequent stutters and inconsistent frame rates. it feels heavily unoptimized for what it offers. the tutorial does an okay job at teaching the basics like movement and shooting, but it doesn’t go much deeper. i also struggled to find a way back to the main menu — after several minutes of searching, the only solution i found was to close and restart the game. because of these problems, i didn’t even make it to the multiplayer part, which was the main reason i bought the game. hopefully future updates will improve the performance and usability, because it seems like there’s potential underneath all the technical issues.

used to love this game. it had loads of fun modes like pavz, tons of mods, and always full servers. since the move to unreal engine 5, all the mods are gone and so are the players. now it’s just the same 25–30 sweatlords playing the same three maps, spawn killing everyone else. all the fun stuff that made the game worth playing is dead. you’ll be lucky to find a full server anymore. it’s a real shame because the gunplay and maps are still great, but without the community and mod support, there’s nothing left. unless you’ve got a big group of friends to play with, don’t bother buying it.

i purchased the game in 2020 and post scriptum quickly became one of my favorite games of all time. superior to the laughable arcade mess that hell let loose became near the end of its early access and beyond. unfortunately, i really can't recommend the game in its current state. the new devs have made some irritating changes, especially to logistics, that killed the game for many players. the changes led to an exodus from what was once a great ww2 milsim. many days, you'll be lucky to see 1 full server running. it had a great run, but the devs seem determined to kill off the last few of us who were dedicated to the niche. i suppose a thumbs up for the great times over the years, but i cannot recommend this game to anyone unless the devs pull a 180 which is unlikely. the last of the community is hanging by a thread.

squad 44 is a tactical ww2 shooter. as an avid enjoyer of first person shooters, this is really fun once you get into combat situations. its not a spectacle like call of duty or battlefield. instead, its much closer to hell let loose. unfortunately, new players like me who are not experienced with realistic shooters struggle to properly engage in these battles. another issue is that there aren't enough servers in asia which makes it hard for me to play the game at a smooth performance because of the high ping. the game's file size is also clearly large. still, i find that the gameplay is very engaging. guns are responsive and close quarters combat is intense. the game also has a wide selection of weapons and vehicles to choose from, so the game is great for you if you're into tanks. the game doesn't look that good compared to modern aaa titles but it holds itself well. buy this game when it discounts by 50% or more if you are into realistic shooters.

i mainly play this game for the tank simulation. infantry is all right. but same with battlefield when i initially played it i was terrible with infantry. so i just used tanks. idk if the same thing will happen to me here. but i just played the tanks. i wish they added air support that you can actually fly. but idk it may never happen maybe it will. but regardless i just play for the tanking. its kinda boring game. even when your in the tank. feels like you don't see things for hours. and then some games you just get completely wrecked depending how big the map is or your in a more urban environment. but that's just judging from tank gameplay. i feel like the tanking before was better before that huge major update they made that's why i kinda stop playing it. not being able to move all the periscopes from each section of the tank was a big bummer. its like if it was like that irl why not have made the game like that to beging with.... but do i recommend this game? yes and no.

it's a great game with best ww2 maps i've ever seen. it's just dumb to point at hll and immedietly claim it's better, simply put, if you like a more 'arcade' experience that is less realistic and more casual then you're going to like hll better for sure. but if you want a more simulation experience with more realistic details and larger maps then you're going to like squad 44 more. also everyone complaining about performace issues must have no idea how to change their video settings because it always runs at a stable 60fps on my 3060. tldr: hll is the 'rising storm' of ww2 milsim while squad 44 is like a hardcore version of regular squad with better maps more realistic details and it takes place in ww2. both are good games but hll is more arcadey and sacrifices realism for console friendly gameplay

squad 44 is an outstanding world war ii tactical shooter that captures the chaos and camaraderie of large-scale warfare like few games can. every match feels like stepping onto a living battlefield, with massive 50v50 fights where teamwork isn’t optional—it’s survival. the authenticity is incredible: weapons have weight, vehicles require coordination, and communication through proximity and squad chat pulls you right into the action. it’s not just about shooting; it’s about building defenses, holding lines, and pushing objectives as a unit. playing with a well-organized squad is unforgettable—you feel the tension of storming trenches, the relief of repelling assaults, and the adrenaline of clutching a point in the last seconds. the sound design is chillingly real, from artillery barrages to the crack of rifles whizzing past. squad 44 isn’t an arcade shooter; it’s immersive, tactical, and demands cooperation. for anyone who craves authenticity, teamwork, and large-scale ww2 combat, it’s absolutely amazing.

actually a pretty good game, and the coop works without issues (atleast for 2 player) so far for me (8 hours) yes the game lacks some features etc, but considering the next patch that is in experimental at the time of writing (taming) it seeems to just be a perfect rendition of rimworlds early days, but with a sweet integrated coop. the coop: each player starts with their own colony, but on the same map. you can play solo or as allies, or you can semi integrate your colonies and share resources with trades. (you can not control each others colonies / use each others resources etc.) i really like this coop integration.

acolony is a good colony sim. base defense, research, trading, meeting colonists needs, resource gathering, base building, etc., is all here and it runs well. a good 3d colony sim is hard to come by and even though it's in early access, this may be the best one on the market. the level of polish and attention to detail shows that this developer truly understands what makes the genre fun and engaging. but the name.... it's not doing this game any favors. a very basic lore primer and a name that shows even a bit of effort goes a very long way toward garnering attention in this genre. the developer is "zerotris". off the top of my head "zero colony" or "colony zero" would be an insanely better name than "a colony". the name makes it sound like a side project or a project that's only made to generate some quick cash before being abandoned. okay, i'm done ranting about the terrible name slapped onto a very good game. i have no opinion about co-op because i have no desire to play a colony sim in multiplayer after realizing it detracts from the experience for me after trying it in other games. i want to build my colony and play my way without someone interfering in my plans. as a single player experience, this game is polished for its current state and fun.
as the dude in the horse mask would say.. "i love it" cant wait for future updates.. and yes the game gets updated alot with new stuff. almost every week

it's got everything i want in a game. 3d colony sim with modern tech. it takes a little to figure out. just make sure you meet your settlers needs. i haven't been addicted to a game like this in a long time! i can't wait to see where they go with this game! i hope they allow modding. like rimworld on steroids.

this game takes time and effort. me and my friend have been grinding since the release of the demo and bought it the next day. the game itself is super relaxing yet stressful in times. getting raided by 9-11 hostile people and scrambling to get in a defensive. the farming and crafting is a grind yet fast if you keep the same people on task to level up their traits. accepting the right colonist to your group is ideal as well. the dev is very responsive in his discord and super helpful and willing to implement qol changes to the game based of the community.

edit: i am again nominating this game for labor of love 2025! howdy! - i am nominating this game for labor of love 2024 this game is well worth the time and money, and presents a very unique playing experience for those that enjoy colony management games such as rimworld with friends. the developer zerotris does a fantastic job keeping new updates coming as the game approaches the 1.0 release. this is a game that i constantly get into when i want to relax and play anything in the colony management space. acolony has a bright future ahead of it, and a very solid developer and community supporting it.

interesting game wich takes a bit of getting used to (for me at least). reminds me of "the kindred" which was never finished, with graphics similar to minecraft. i am playing single-player, trying to build a nice settlement. so far, despite early access, i have not encountered any bugs. i am finding some of the concepts interesting; i especially like the rising demand regarding living quarters depending on the amount of colonists. its also challenging sometimes to deal with your stuff, as everything rots if it is not in storage and/or in a confined room. if you like this kind of game give it a try - it plays nicely.

re7 is an incredible survival horror game. of all of the resident evil games that i have played, it contains the least action, but is better for it, as it really shines best when exploring its dark, twisted setting. the best section of the game involves going through the large baker house - a dilapidated estate in louisiana bayou. it's a truly inspired setting, and capcom nailed the southern horror vibe incredibly well - it's extremely authentic and believable. the attention to detail is amazing, and it's the most memorable haunted house/house of horrors setting in any media that i've been exposed to. the story is excellent, and very intriguing, as you piece together why ethan is there, what's really going on, and what happened to the baker family. they're extremely memorable villains and very menacing as well. also, even nearly 9 years after release, at the time of writing, the game looks incredible. up close, some of the character models are showing age, but in the moment-to-moment, the visual fidelity is awesome and the performance is incredible. i also enjoyed the 1st person setting much more than i thought i would - i think it's absolutely necessary for the kind of game they crafted, and it is more immersive than the 3rd person re games, by necessity, as that's really what you're getting here - a very engaging and immersive horror experience.

after almost 140h pretty much, since i also played it on console, i can honestly recommend re7 with my whole chest; it’s one of those games that somehow manages to be creepy as hell but still kinda.. soothing? like you’re walking around this disgusting mold-infested nightmare house, but your brain’s just locked into that “ok let me solve this entire building like it’s one giant nerd puzzle” mode. the pacing hits that perfect spot too: chaos one minute, then you’re standing there staring at a weird shadow puzzle feeling like einstein because you rotated a plastic bird correctly. the whole game turns into this satisfying loop of “survive, explore, uh oh, puzzle time,” and it scratches that exact itch of horror mixed with logic. idk, it’s just one of those games where even when you’re stressed, you’re vibing, like a cozy panic. and if you’re a puzzle/atmosphere nerd like me, it’s honestly peak

graphics are great. the controls are minimal. death is only semi-frequent; very far from the pointlessness of the dark souls games. also, the ambience in this thing is amazing. very horror-centric. it's made up for whatever the heck re 6 was supposed to be, and wasn't.

i've been a long time resident evil fan and have played basically all of them except for some of the more obscure ones. with that in mind, i honestly think that 7 was a fine addition to the franchise and made for a unique and enjoyable experience. scuffed chris redfield notwithstanding of course. i just recently played through this game again and enjoyed it just as much as i initially did. when the game was first announced, i was admittedly skeptical that the game's formula wouldn't translate well to a first person perspective, but i was pleasantly surprised that it worked well. of course, it doesn't play like your average call of battlefield ce fps so don't expect slide canceling and drop shotting. what you'll get is a good first person horror experience that is a fun ride in a unique setting. i give this game 7 chris redfield boulder punches out of 7.

resident evil 7 completely blew me away. coming from playing the older re games and being amazed at their action and scale, stepping into re7 felt like entering a whole new era of resident evil — and i loved every second of it. the story is insane in the best way possible. the mystery of the baker family, the creepy atmosphere, the plot twists, and finding out the truth behind eveline… bro, i was hooked the entire time. every reveal just made me go “no way, so she was behind all this!?” the gameplay is tight and genuinely scary. the first-person perspective hits different — it puts you right in ethan’s shoes. exploring the baker house felt like being inside a horror movie. the tension, the footsteps, the doors slowly opening… damn. peak horror. i also loved how the characters operate in this game. jack chasing you down the hallway like he owns the place, marguerite with her creepy insect powers, lucas being a psycho genius… and ethan? that dude is him. the man takes more damage than any human should and still keeps going just to save mia. respect. and bro — the guns feel amazing. the shotgun slaps, the pistol feels crisp, and every upgrade hits hard. when you finally get fully geared? you feel like a badass walking through hell to end everything. overall, resident evil 7 reminded me why this franchise is goated. it’s terrifying, emotional, intense, and unforgettable. if you love horror, story, and pure resident evil vibes, this is a masterpiece. 10/10 — eveline tried to control me but she can’t control my love for this game.

been playing through a bunch resident evil games lately and this one really captivated me. the game play is fun, the story is interesting, and by far the art direction is fantastic. i can only describe as a blend of disgusting imagery and beautiful area design (mostly disgusting though since it takes place in louisiana). while shorter than other resident evil games i think even without dlc this game would be worth buying.

edit: after trying the game again, i'm pretty furious. the game is so buggy. first i got the recreational room book glitch that needs you to restart the entire game to get around, now the game crashes every time i try to cross this bridge to save my progress. i literally can't do anything about that. al the fear i was supposed to feel was replaced with frustration. this game seems kind of cool, but i definitely enjoyed 2, 3, and 4 far more. nothing is really too scary, it just seems like jumpscares. i don't mind puzzle solving, but fighting seems so clunky. guard doesn't seem to work when i need it to, i get grabbed at at stupid distances, and shooting the enemy to stagger them for a second doesn't really work as well as you think it would. i especially don't like how the game doesn't stop when i open my map or inventory (which sounds better for the fear factor, you're never safe, but it really just causes annoyances when i'm trying to do something and get attacked from behind). i can see the effort in this game so i'm sure it's a very good game as everyone is saying, but for me personally i just can't play for more than 30 minutes without getting a legitimate headache.

this is the first time i've actually been softlocked in a resident evil game, and it's due to an inventory/key item glitch. i'm pretty sure it glitched because i tried to pick up one of two key items (blue keycard), but my inventory was full. on the way back to the storage box, i decided to get the other key item (red keycard) since it was closer, intending to go back for the other one later. the second key item triggered progression in the story, and now i can't interact with the original key item. some of the other resident evil games have some quirks and bugs, but this is the only one i've experienced in my playthroughs that resulted in a permanently broken save. other than that, games scary and has a spooky atmosphere but the first person makes it lose some character compared to other re games.

there are two types of design philosophies i absolutely despise in games, corridor shooter that require a substantial amount of backtracking to progress( with mandatory puzzles), and shooters that throw a ton of enemies at you with very little resources at your disposal. tack on bad pathing, tedious level design, and a story that seems interesting on the surface, but is about as deep as a puddle, and you get resident evil 7. that is not to mention the absolutely atrocious inventory systems as well, or insanely limited resources. the worst thing about all of this, is that the game is a slog to playthrough. there is some cool ambience that is served up, but other then that- i'm not compelled to finish the rest of the game. seven hours was enough for me to want to uninstall this game. final rating: 2/10- buy on sale or just watch the cutscenes on youtube.

risk of rain 2 doesn’t feel satisfying to play: it becomes repetitive, build development is uninteresting, and progression feels slow. there’s no real sense of danger or urgency. some thoughts: the teleport event seems pointless—its only function is to move you to another biome, but there’s no meaningful reset or shift in pacing. boss fights are significantly harder than regular encounters, yet the reward is the same single item, so defeating a boss doesn’t feel genuinely rewarding. opinion: as a roguelike, the game has potential, but it needs substantial rebalancing and a deeper rethink of how builds and progression develop.

i've had a blast with this game. when it wants to work (keep that sentiment in mind), messing around with it is incredibly fun, and it can be fascinating to see how broken you can get. so why is this a "not recommended" review? the answer's quite simple: gearbox and take-two have their grubby mitts on this game. between their predatory eulas and other scummy business practices, not to mention how they've handled the game itself since taking over, hopoo's legacy and the hard, honest work of those who have worked on alloyed collective have effectively been spat on repeatedly. they want control over everything in the ip, and that includes information on those who play it. you're more than welcome to keep going on it if you trust gearbox and take-two with the stuff on your computer and trust them with every fibre of your being (although why you would want to do that is beyond me). because, per their eula, if what they cause via those methods ruins something, you can't hold them liable. probably the biggest red flag is that multiplayer itself is completely dysfunctional half of the time. and by "dysfunctional", i mean "it will straight up not load at all, no game for you". considering that multiplayer is a pretty major pull for a roguelike such as this one, that's just such a big no-no. and as a result of our [i]dear publishers[/i], i don't know - or care - if those problems will be fixed. risk of rain 2, i love you. i love the way you play and i would have loved to sift through everything alloyed collective offers. but i think it's officially time to file for a divorce and head to roguelikes that will actually respect the person playing it.

after finishing the full release, i have to say i’m disappointed. i supported this in early access but after all this time the game just doesn’t pull me in like the first one did. the tone, writing, and presentation constantly break immersion instead of building it. the story and dialogue never clicked for me. in hades 1, conversations felt clever and fitting for mythic figures. here, it’s casual and repetitive, and the characters rarely grow or respond meaningfully to your progress. the plot never gave me the same drive or emotional hook that made zagreus’ journey compelling. the characters feel weaker, and melinoë never really develops, even after dozens of victories. the cast lacks the charm and spark of the first game, and the serious tone never lands because there’s no wit or emotional payoff. the redesigns of many characters feel wrong, they clearly weren’t meant to immerse you in the world or tell the story, but to do something else entirely. that takes me out of the game more than anything else. gameplay is solid at its core, but the magic of the first game isn’t there. weapons feel too similar, combat is slower, and builds rarely feel impactful. progression is bloated with too many materials and grindy systems that make runs feel like chores. on top of that, screen clutter from attacks and effects often makes fights frustrating because you can’t see what’s happening. overall, the game lost the personality, charm, and tight design that made hades 1 special. supporting it early felt exciting, but the final result just didn’t deliver, and if this is the direction supergiant sticks with, i won’t be backing their next project.

same formula as the first, but nearly as tight. they added more systems, but a lot of it is frustrating rather than intriguing. super builds aren't nearly as common which adds to the frustration. all-in-all a more poorly paced game that has issues with the story and the presentation.
it sucks cuz its on steam
i truly enjoy this game but every time i launch it forces me to verify the game files. i cant recommend it until they fix this.

(hades2 is the "the new colossus" to hades1's "the new order") tldr: game's great, but feels subpar to supergiant's ridiculously high standards, so hades1 - for coherent storytelling and consistency, hades2 - for more diverse gameplay. .. to elaborate: - true & epilogue ending both are mediocre at best (the patch only made it a smidge better) - just time-travel in general messing up the whole premise and post-game justifications - some npc arcs falling flat (chronos, hypnos) - subplots going nowhere or lacking a satisfying resolution. hades1 sisyphus stayed for boldy, hades2 npcs stay because of the "npc in a rogue-like" reason - they can have it better, but none take the opportunity or, in some cases, even move (tartatus couple). .. the rest are nitpicks - outlandish style choices (suited chaos; dionysus's attire; the oceanus boss - albeit entertaining but still too whimsical), tame weapon aspects (save for a few), flat god portraits (poses, not animations), boring +5% upgrades (moon tree), ubiquitous status curses with similar effects. mechanically hades2 is super fun, the surface climb is awesome, the music\songs are beautiful, some characters do leave an impression, not to mention the overall level of polish and attention to details - this is still supergiant! .. but i enjoyed hades1 more..

the core of what made hades a great game is there, but the game has a frustrating habit of suddenly dumping damage on you with cheap shots. in one end game area i died to a falling object with no tell. one boss has a pattern memorization attack that basically wipes or halves one life (if you were pumping max health) if you make a single error. if it had front loaded more of it's cheap stuff early i would have honestly refunded it.

[progressioin spolers ahead} i beat typhon and chronos both 3 times. i beat polyphemus like 50 times. and you still do not give me a normal ending after all that,.....that's not ok. i just lost interest in trying to beat this game. in fact i already did, multiple times, but you rigged it and designed it in such a way that forces your players to keep coming back over and over again. very scummy and i didn't enjoy this. [game lore] also i think it's very obvious you guys wrote yourself into a corner and then pretended like everything is okay. if you played the 1st game, it doesn't make sense that zagreus would like his father. i can't accept that in hades ii you tried to make this an reality. that's just wrong. i would understand melinoe loves hades and respects him but that's only because she has never met him when he was a ruler. hades treated his son zagreus horribly and there is no way zagreus or his mother do not remember/do not vocalize that! you guys desperately try to cover this simple truth throughout the entirety of this game!!! thi s*** too woke. i'm out. honestly bought this game and gave it an honest try but you disappointed me. give players who beat typhon a proper ending. stop treating us likes tyour slaves, likeyour lab rats, that's disgustying what you tried to pull.

can't stand how this is even more meta-progression focused and decides to split the fucking game into 2 paths (lol and multiple gods are locked behind this too.. wth) instead of adding actual room and encounter variety which this game lacks in even more than the 1st game as well. enemy design is safe and lacking. everything just feels safe as hell. nothing wowed me even close to the last 2 areas and boss encounters of the 1st game. the fact that the rat miniboss in oceanus is something you can encounter past the 1st time you see it too.. wow, peak fun. peak game design having to read an instantly dashing tiny ass rat you can barely see on your screen while you're bombarded from all sides. who the hell designed this? game is good overall, but i'd prefer to be critical considering how overblown this game's praise is.

how is it possible? i mean... how? the first hades game was great all around: great combat great pacing great story great characters great music great endings (both of them) on the other hand, this one still have a good combat, but it's very hit and miss, glacial pacing, terrible story, boring characters, ok music (except for the sirens, they are great) e abysmal endings (especially the epilogue)... add the total lack of respect for greek mythology acurracy and you have hades 2... such a shame...

a bit of a different experience from the original hades, some things are better some aren't. story wise it has its ups and downs. melinoe is everything that zagreus isn't (which is very good honestly, doesn't make it better or worse, though). what we fell in love in the original is there, but also the steven universation... the old story of old dude can do all terrible things and get a pass. there are better ways to solve a conflict, talk no jutsu is one of the worse.

it doesnt click as the first one, hades 1 is perfect and this one tries to be similar but different at the same time. the characters are less charismatic copies of the first game. for example, nemesis and oddyseus feel like aliexpress versions of meg and achilles. the new gods are bland, and the returning ones come off like actors worn down after six seasons of playing the same part. personally i didn't enjoy any of the weapons and i'm not having fun with the magic system. any weapon in hades 1 is more fun than the witch staff. also, i'm color blinded and i didn't have problem seeing things in hades 1 but after 60 minutes playing this one my eyes were exhausted.

after completing it and getting to the epilogue i'm realizing only after the fact that... it's just not as good in terms of writing as hades 2. it's nonsensical and unfulfilling in a lot places, with either unearned or hanging plot threads and characters all over the place. this is one of those times i wish i could give a neutral recommendation, but forced to pick yes or no? it's no. make no mistake, what's here is an improvement gameplay-wise on hades, but hades 1 was a complete package and that's why it was good: writing and mechanics actually interlocked in such a great way to keep you playing well past the ending. that isn't present here. they really dropped the ball with the development of the narrative overall here, it's all weird and disjointed when you stop to think about it, all the way from simple bonds you have with characters, to how things 'resolve'. and that just isn't good enough when you're only standing on your mechanics, and being compared to a much better complete experience like hades 1.

i loved hades 1 and was so, so excited for this game. and i really enjoyed it for 60 hours! and then i reached the ending and ate the greatest dissatisfying nothingburger 0 character development of all time. the game and characters had so much potential and none of that is ever addressed. melinoe isn't particularly likeable and she never gets character development throughout the entire game, she isn't even a satisfying protagonist which sours the otherwise great gameplay. the art style change was just disappointing, considering how hades 1 had an incredibly unique, dynamic style

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG
review_text: rust is less a video game and more an ontological crucible—a ruthless simulation of human fragility in which players are unceremoniously thrust, naked and bewildered, into a violently indifferent world. armed initially with nothing but a rock, one becomes acutely aware that this primitive tool is not merely a means of gathering resources, but a symbol of humanity’s eternal struggle against entropy. the island itself operates as a living ecosystem of paranoia, where each footstep behind you triggers a sudden philosophical inquiry into mortality. what truly distinguishes rust is its uniquely volatile social dynamic. alliances form and dissolve with the same instability as subatomic particles, and the concept of trust becomes a rare and precious hallucination. the player must navigate a landscape saturated with machiavellian scheming, economic desperation, and a level of unpredictable human behavior that borders on the anthropological. a single encounter with another player can unravel hours of effort, transforming personal progress into an existential tragedy worthy of greek theatre. the emotional turbulence rust generates is unparalleled. triumph feels mythic—your first fortified base stands not merely as a structure, but as a monument to defiance against an uncaring universe. conversely, being raided at 3 a.m. by a clan of sleep-deprived marauders is a humbling reminder of the cosmos’s disdain for your ambitions. this perpetual oscillation between empowerment and devastation makes rust an experience not of simple entertainment, but of psychological endurance. in conclusion, rust is a hyper-chaotic meditation on survival, cruelty, and the volatile nature of human interaction. it is exhausting, awe-inspiring, and occasionally soul-crushing, but it is unquestionably one of the most brutally honest reflections of human behavior ever disguised as a game.

superhot is the most innovative shooter i’ve played in years!

while i typically avoid fps games, superhot caught my eye because of its presentation. it's a bullet time game where time only moves when you do, and even with this huge advantage you're constantly having to think on your feet in close ranged combat. a part of why this works so well is that the game is a puzzle as much as it is a fps. every level places you in a difficult situation that they need to figure out with moment to moment reactions. you also die very easily, so it's about trial and error until a working strategy prevails. i feel that this initially had the potential to be one of the best games i've played, even for something outside of my typical preferred genres. however, the way the story presents itself is a bit flawed, as it's far too intrusive to the actual gameplay from the getgo. i know some people will argue that's the point, but i don't want to ever replay the game exactly because of this. i feel there are better ways that the story could have been executed without sacrificing too much of the gameplay itself. if the message is supposed to be that the gameplay is addictive, then let me experience that! i still like superhot, the gameplay itself is intuitive. a minimalist style and mechanics to focus purely on the bullet time aspect makes for a memorable, albeit not perfect, experience. i'd suggest just getting this on sale due to the shorter playtime, although the franchise as a whole is probably not worth checking out unless if you [i]really[/i] find the core gameplay to look interesting.

i like this game alot. it’s very fun and addicting, with tons of challenges and quick action that keeps you on your toes. i played the vr version (13 hours), and i loved that game. although this game is flawless with no complaints, i must say that in my opinion the concept of superhot: where time moves when you move. is better executed in vr. i had so much more fun in the vr version because superhot’s gameplay is smoother and better done in vr than in the original. also, with how short these games are, i don’t find real value in the $25 price tag for each of them. the vr version is by far worth its price, while the original feels lacking because its gameplay and difficulty is just stale in comparison. now, i do want to make this clear: superhot is not bad. it is wonderful and a joy to play through, and i can see some people justifying the $25 price tag. i just think that when you compare it to superhot vr, its price isn’t worth it to me personally. i bought this for about $8, and i’m happy with it, but i would not pay the full $25 price. if you can buy this game on sale, then i’d say it’s worth your time and money. however, i believe that superhot vr is the definitive and better version to play.

i’ve only played superhot for about an hour, but even that short time was enough for me to say this game is amazing. i picked it up on sale without expecting much, even though i had heard some good things. but honestly, it completely blew me away. the game feels so fresh and unique. the graphics are super clean, and the fact that it came out in 2016 is mind-blowing. the maps kind of remind me of tabs, and the whole experience makes you feel like you’ve been dropped into another world. i was literally sitting on the edge of my seat the whole time, waiting for something wild to happen. the “super... hot” voice is so cool and really sticks with you. the way time moves only when you move makes everything feel intense and tactical, like you’re actually dodging bullets in slow motion. the only thing that bugs me is how accurate the bots get when you’re not slowing time. it almost feels like they have aimbot. even with that, i’d still say to not get this game. i’ve heard it’s short and it gets way too repetitive. the lore is boring as hell and i have no free will. "they" keep telling me to leave.. so i did and i never played it again. it is a fun and unique play, but it costs way too much. $30.00 cad for me.

mechanically a good game ruined by tedious processes. the levels are the fun part. the text based "story" is not. who even cares about the story? it's the same stuff over and over and over and over again. oh no you're not in control, oh wait yes you are, just kidding no you aren't. go visit yourself and see your own body in the real world, wait your trapped, hurt yourself, obey disobey, obey, disobey, rinse repeat. ohhh metanarrative, how compelling, how daring. annoying is more like it. incredibly annoying and ruins all the pacing the game builds upon during the action levels. imagine watching an action packed movie, and after every fight, there's a 2 minute long uninterruptable ad that you have to interact with in order to progress. the flame fizzles as soon as the story garbage begins.
neat i guess but way overpriced for a handful of neat levels and a plot the devs admitted was completely worthless.

this game is really bad, this game is not difficult it's just annoying. hitboxes of everything are messed up, especially walls, you can throw an object around a corner and it will explode after hitting nothing because the wall hitbox extended there. you aren't told how many bullets you have left but the game will gladly make time go fast while it shames you about how you don't have bullets it's a cool time mechanic but the shooting mechanics suck it's a game you can complete in under 2 hours and refund tho, just expect it to be tedious and annoying with very little worthwhile challenge

that game reminds me of precision platformers but here, its precision shooter and im not a fan of precision platformers, they are too sweaty to my liking. while the gameplay is cool i quickly got frustrated with each reset i initiated. we got couple of stuff at our disposal, depending on the level, be it weapons or objects and later on an ability to switch bodies, so there are couple of ways we can clear the level. game quickly became a puzzle instead of a shooter. with each reset, i knew more possibilities of approaching threats but it wasn't for a better. five tries here, switching approach, another two tries there, switch, different tactic, here i couldn't make it, there i was not quick enough. that's not for me to have an multiverse gameplay in my world, maybe its my brain that im capable of seeing all the possibilities and none at the same time so im stuck 5 times in one confrontation before i switch to different threat or progress further. i feel like that gameplay was melting my brain and on top of that, the lore, the progression of said simulation became irritating. so, in the end, i got a decent mix of frustrating triggers. im only glad i got it while it was -70% so im not so bitter about it. i would recommend this but game too quickly fried my brain splitting it into multiversuperhot super hot super hot super hot super hot

cool concept but way too short of a game for what it is asking. the main mode can be beaten in an hour or so. once you get beyond the time slowing down mechanic it's just a simple shooter with a few melee weapons.
the story mode is short and sweet, but i have little desire to complete all the endgame challenges. the main mechanic—time only moves as you do—gets old after spending 2 hours in the story mode.

this is a great and highly innovate fps, but it has some problematic design choices that weigh it down. these problems mostly come in the delivery of information. mind swap charged, full screen flash. story beat, full screen flash. run out of ammo, full screen flash. anytime the game wants to tell you something, it gives you a flash-bang effect. it gave me a headache pretty quickly and i had to turn down the brightness of my monitor or look away whenever it got aggressive. i get how the flashes tie into the story, but that doesn't make them magically not obnoxious. it also doesn't help that the story is charitably described as a low quality copy pasta. 2 hours isn't enough time to develop much, so at least keep the story elements from degrading the feeling of the game. the challenges and endless mode get this flash-bang effect the worst, which is a shame since that's where you will experiment the most and discover how deep the combat can be.

"time moves only when you move" this is a great concept that would have been much better if implemented in a game that has other things going for it. but as it stands, it's the only game mechanic, and there isn't much of a story either. you shoot some red guys then the game is over. at the end of each level, they spam you with a loud voice repeating the game title. perhaps to make sure you remember it. it's very annoying. the game knows not to overstay its welcome, but the gameplay grows old faster still. (it took me 2 hours to beat, then i left it open to get trading cards)

it’s okay — it’s actually great for, let’s say, modern yu-gi-oh. the game itself is probably much better than previous titles. updates are frequent, new cards arrive about five months after they’re released in the tcg, duels are found almost instantly, and there are often events with changed limits or forbidden cards. but for me, the game would be much better if you could switch the game mode to formats like goat, edison, etc., and find opponents who play the same format as you. of course, you can create custom games and play that way with your friends — which i do — but why should i only play with my friends when i could play against you? overall, the game is good. i’ve made all the decks i own in real life, and it’s a great option to experiment with different strategies and to learn new decks much faster.

the most accessible way to play yu-gi-oh! online. cards trail behind the tcg/ocg by about 6 months. gems for cards are earned at a decent rate. perhaps the least gacha gacha game on the market. unlike duel links, cards can be crafted/dismantled for dust, similar to hearthstone at about a 3:1 ratio of dismantle to craft. this means even unplayable duds of the same rarity contribute towards cards you actually want. no need to scrape the bottom of the packs looking for must haves like duel links. events are held roughly twice a month for some variety and include loaner decks to experience the latest decks, albeit not their meta versions. ban list is wildly different to the tcg, for better and for worse. while it doesn't make paper play obsolete, it is a fine alternative if you are just looking to play yu-gi-oh!

i recently got into the yu-gi-oh for the first time and was overall pleasantly surprised, but master duel has some really bad stuff. first of all, if a game has this many "must have" generic staples, they should be easy to get, and not be f****** urs, are you kidding me? and ur drops are so rare that by the time i time i collect enough dust for the playset of all of the must-play handtraps i already lost interest. unlike in hearthstone, each rarity uses separate dust, which means you need to actually pull urs to craft urs. around 25% of your deck is either generic handtraps everyone plays or counters to these handtraps, so it's not even like these expensive cards you're crafting are resulting in building cooler decks. they also don't give you more fun play experience either. it's like a nuclear race: both sides are forced to stockpile their decks with the most powerful weapons to keep up with the other side, even though the end result sucks for both of them. on the plus side, the visuals and ost are fantastic. solo mode is a good way to introduce archetypes, and the special tournaments are fun too - and often give rental decks, which bypasses the awful ur grind. if konami uses experience from these they might improve ranked. alternatively they could ban maxx "c", that works too.

pros: - yu-gi-oh card simulation seems smooth. - music is good. - highlights relevant card text for various effects. - some event duels create new metas outside the traditional ranked. cons: - story mode content is basically a nice looking power point. - in app account management between devices is a dumpster fire. (do not play on any device before linking up your account. there is no simple log out button.) - once event duels end, there is no meaningful way in game to engage with casual play. - game locks packs of various archetypes, and you can only purchase these various types of packs by generating a card from that 'set' or using gems (earnable, but still a paid currency.) to hopefully pull an sr from the set. which then allows you to spend gems on the set you are actually aiming for. it's a yu-gi-oh! tcg simulator. as an official product that generates revenue, i would say it doesn't meet expectations. if you like yu-gi-oh! - you will enjoy yu-gi-oh! in the app. that's as far as it goes.

i could not get the game to respect my settings and not use hands free calling for my wireless headset. for those who don't know this results in horrible audio quality since bluethooth is not capable of handling high quality in and output at the same time. just imaginge putting your phone in a tin can and put the volume to max. then you know how this sounds. this is not an issue in any other game i own. every game respects not using the headset mic how its set up in windows. deactivation all other devices besides my usb mic and headphones did not work. changing gamebar and xbox settings to use the headphones for just output and the usb mic for input did not work. deactiviating hands free mode via windows resulted in no audio at all. the game always forced the hdeadphones to be used in hands free mode resulting in horrible audio quality for the whole system. after trying everything i could find online about fixing it and nothing working i just gave up and refunded without playing a single second. i wasted over an hour researching and messing with settings without success. sad that a mircrosoft related company can not get their product to work properly with their own operating system.

honestly any game that has to have its files verified and the game basically redownloaded due to their anti-cheat engine breaking isnt worth much as far as playing. at least half my playtime is running the game for it to crash, not sign me in at all, or sitting in the menu trying to get the games audio to even come close to working. beautiful game on the eyes and whatever optimization they did recently is great for the framerate and overall smoothness of the game itself, but between the horrid player base (weve all been chased down for a few cannonballs and bananas, havent we?) and the game itself not really working half the time, its not worth the price tag it comes with and its most certainly not worth the price tag of the trinkets and knicknacks and season passes. if you can get this game for 5 bucks thats great, but youll be pretty pissed once you keep having to take the time to verify, download, and install its game data 3 hours a month as well. id say "have fun" but before the toxic player base makes you bitter the crashes will piss you off first.

it is a solid game with awesome graphics as you would expect from fromsoft. however, it is a console game they overlaid pc keyboard play ability on too. i'm a pc gamer and don't have a game console. the game's sword parry, deflection, and dodge mechanics require being far too good with heavy penalties for dying and very little resources for healing. you may have to plan on restarting with a new game several times unless you are a natural speedster. also, if you die, you have to do the entire area over. you don't get to pick where your save points are.

hard to recommend this. e.g. - the game is designed in a way to make it very difficult to learn. you have to get good at parrying, and weirdly it offers you very little opportunity to really do that. - far too much bs, and far too many situations encouraging cheese. - op consumables that trivialise fights, but extremely rare to find so tough shit if you didn't kill the boss the time you used snap seeds. - punishes the dying and learning cycle with dragonrot mechanic. i did get to a point where i enjoyed the game, but fromsoft really did make it as difficult as they could to get to that point. i'd recommend lies of p or khazan over it any day.

the combat system is neat. its enjoyable for a bit but gets really repetitive and drawn out on some encounters. a lot of bosses have really cheap tricks that they throw at you that feels like it breaks the flow of the combat and i don't find the cheapness fair or interesting. most of the bosses and mini bosses can kill you in just one or two hits, which makes learning them a painful chore, but of course you need to get about 50 in so that their posture bar doesn't deplete so fast in order to kill them. player dropoff is almost 50% by the first major boss. for the rest, a lot of players resort to cheese tactics to beat a lot of the encounters, which i think goes against the intent of the game. i get being tough, but i find this game doesn't always play by its own rules. despite picking it up a few separate times to give it a fresh approach, each time i find i just hate it.

usually challenging games make it fun to develop the skills needed to play it. fromsoft games seem to take the opposite approach: make the player miserable until they can rise above the challenge, and punish the player for needing to learn. sekiro is no different. i haven't encountered a boss in a couple of hours because i'm stuck exploring this vast area with lots of dangerous enemies and no checkpoints. sneak past them? sure, maybe a couple. but when i need to enter a cavern guarded by 5 enemies, or when the way forward is guarded by monks with spears that do half my health bar with one hit, it's just not fun. this game doesn't make me want to get better at it, it makes me want to quit. the realization that dragonrot also punishes you for dying by denying you the ability to do side quests? yeah, i'm done with this.

great game so far but i have issues with launching the game a lot of the times. for example, if i connect my controller after launching the game, the game will be screen-locked and i'd be forced to restart my pc because i can't tab out or even close the game. sometimes, the only thing i can do is alt+f4 and restart the game when this bug occurs. oftentimes, the game will get stuck on a black screen and i'd get a message prompt saying that the application isn't responding which also forces me to restart my pc in order to play. another bug is sometimes when i'm in game, i can't tab out from the screen or even use any keyboard buttons such as print screen to take screenshots. while i am enjoying the game and find myself constantly thinking about wanting to play it on the weekends, i can't recommend it in its current state unless you're okay with possibly being forced to put up with all these bugs.

sekiro is a great game that suffers from the syndrome known as being apart of the soulsborne legacy. that is to say, everything that sekiro does right feels like an evolution of the darksouls formula, but fails to let go of aspects that makes it miserable. the game play is excellent- when you already know exactly what to do. the map is well designed - when you know exactly where to go. the game is fun to play - after you've already mastered it. if that sounds nice too you, get it, but i can't recommend a game like that in good faith. pros (which there are a lot of) - fast and interesting evolution of souls-borne combat - excellent boss-gated leveling system - amazing atmosphere - interesting bosses cons - weird tacked on souls-mechanics that detract from the experience (abhorrent camera, weird hitboxes, souls-esk stumbling and uncharacteristic clumsiness, occasionally inconsistent rules) - lack of proper tutorialization/introduction to mechanics (lightning attacks, shielded enemies, archaic actions required for certain areas of progression.) - very forgettable story with mediocre characters - beginner unfriendly, not encouraged to experiment (very low heath at game start, potential to be soft-locked out of using an xp mechanic due to death mechanic, items made to ease difficulty implemented frustratingly poorly.) i'd say this game is a time sink, where if you spend the time, you will enjoy it, but after 40-some hours, i know for me this is not something i'd recommend to others, nor is something i'd complete without a guide in hand, cheesing every boss i had the mispleasure of facing for the first time.

not well designed and incredibly overrated. the good things include the visuals, the story, and the one on one combat is amazing. however, they do their very best to avoid that. nearly every miniboss is some sort of duo fight, completely ruining the combat and making it severely unfun. the open areas are passable but overall mediocre. in summary, you have to wade through hours of slop until reaching a handful of amazing bosses, which just isn't worth it. there are too many good games out there to waste 30 hours on this. i would suggest nine sols as a similar game that just was miles better for me. sekiro has potential to be amazing if it leaned into one on one combat and reworked a couple of the areas, but it feels like it does its best to avoid this, so overall not worth the time or money.

insanely overrated game. boring, tedious, and repetitive. it boggles the mind to think that quick-time-events are unanimously hated in the gaming community (and rightfully so), but this game is universally praised as a masterpiece. essentially, every fight is a punishing, lopsided qte simulator that requires quick reflexes and enemy attack pattern memorization. block/parry most attacks, dodge/jump when it's something like a charge, sweep, grapple, etc. succeed and you get a brief window to chip away at the enemy, maybe 3-4% of their health. fail and you get hit for 50-75% of your own health. it's guitar hero, but with ninjas. f*ck off.

a well calculated game... nba 2k20 continues the franchise’s tradition of delivering a highly realistic basketball simulation, with stellar visuals, tight gameplay, and robust content. however, it’s not without its flaws. pros: gameplay mechanics: smooth and responsive controls make dribbling, passing, and shooting feel intuitive. ai improvements enhance realism in both offense and defense. graphics and presentation: stunning visuals and lifelike player animations capture the essence of the nba, while dynamic commentary keeps the experience immersive. mycareer mode: a compelling storyline with celebrity involvement adds depth, alongside satisfying customization options for your player. variety of modes: from myteam to myleague, there’s plenty of content to keep players engaged, whether you prefer competitive online play or managing a franchise. cons: microtransactions: heavy reliance on in-game purchases in modes like myteam and mycareer detracts from the enjoyment, especially for casual players. repetitiveness: despite small updates, gameplay can feel overly familiar for long-time fans. server issues: online connectivity remains inconsistent, which can be frustrating for multiplayer enthusiasts. verdict: nba 2k20 shines in gameplay and presentation but stumbles with aggressive monetization and recurring technical hiccups. it’s an excellent choice for basketball fans who can overlook its shortcomings. rating: 7.5/10.

[h3] basket is my least favorite american sport. [/h3] [h3] i asked the community which nba game on steam to play. [/h3] [h3] 2020 and 2015 are apparently the least bad. [/h3] [h1] gameplay: [/h1] i can't compare with other nba 2k's because i haven't played since allen iverson's 03. but i enjoy playing this one, the game is smooth and stable, the difficulty is easily adaptable to your level. progression through the game is fast, and the gameplay can be adapted according to ability. dribbling is much more complex than i remember, where i used to dribble all over the place with the sg. gameplay can be adapted to make the game very arcade-like, big dunk, stealing, fast pass, alley oops and i love it. the mycareer mode is very bad, we need a very low level to progress, better than jordan but ridiculous all the same. i probably don't understand the concept of this mode, even though it's one i'm very fond of in any other sports. the ambiance is very immersive, though, and you really feel like an nba player. the other “online” modes are inactive, and the game can be considered dead if you don't play against the ai. [h3] the game is dead, but i still enjoy the occasional match, so i can only recommend it if you don't want to play online. [/h3] [h1] if you like sports games, come and discover what's available on steam. [/h1] https://store.steampowered.com/curator/45180919-senigaming-sports/

nba 2k20 has received overwhelmingly negative reviews, becoming the 5th lowest-rated game on steam. bugs and technical issues there are numerous bugs and technical problems that hamper the gaming experience. there are tons of graphical performance issues, with some users noting that the game looks less crisp and polished compared to its console counterparts. performance problems and lag have also been mentioned, affecting gameplay smoothness and responsiveness. one of the most prevalent complaints is the rampant cheating in online modes. only the pc version is plagued by hackers, significantly diminishing the enjoyment of multiplayer gameplay. the lack of effective anti-cheating measures has led to a toxic online environment, with many users exploiting the game's vulnerabilities. 2k games has been criticized for their insufficient efforts to combat cheating. the absence of robust anti-cheat systems has allowed hackers to run rampant, particularly in online modes. this issue has persisted across multiple iterations of the game, leading to frustration among legitimate players seeking fair competition. the combination of bugs, cheaters, and lack of anti-cheat measures has severely impacted the overall gaming experience. while some players find enjoyment in single-player modes like mycareer and myleague, the online component of nba 2k20 on pc is frustrating and unbalanced due to the prevalence of cheaters. in conclusion, nba 2k20 for pc has been marred by technical issues, rampant cheating, and inadequate developer response to these problems. while the game may offer some enjoyment in its offline modes, the online experience falls short of expectations due to the lack of effective anti-cheating measures and the resulting toxic environment.

this game is good, but there are some pretty annoying aspects inherit to its genre. like, because you are reliant on rng especially early on getting enough defensive cards to avoid damage, its often completely unavoidable to take damage no matter what you do, which can cascade into players dying with no counterplay.

9/10 game easily my favorite rogue like ever. its characters are charming both playable and npcs, its cards are very intuitive never once have i been like "what does this do?". the only reason this isn't a 10/10 for me is the challenge is just too difficult once you get later on in ascension levels which, yes its a rogue like that's what's going to happen. i knew this walking in however looking at this from a casual player perspective they will almost never go past ascension 10 so if they do that on all 4 characters that's still 1 hundred maybe 2 hundred hours just to experience half the game. and once you hit higher ascensions you are forced to choosing 1 of like 3 decks on every character if you want to win consistently. i would still recommend this to anyone in a heartbeat (pun intended) fantastic game with a fun modding community and great devs

i'm only not recommending because of the price. it's good, but only worth it if it's on sale. i got it for 700jpy ($5 us), and i'd say it's worth it for up to $10, maybe 15 if i'm being generous. if i compare similar and similarly priced games like hades, this doesn't even come close. very basic. i feel like once you've played it for about an hour or 2, you're not really going to run into anything new with the gameplay or progression. it seems there's only 3 levels to clear, which will take you around 90~120mins, and you just do that over and over again, while not really getting much stronger per run aside from the new cards you unlock on level up (which only happens once every 2~3 attempts, and then you have to find those cards in a run. your starting deck doesn't change, so it's hard to feel good about starting a new run when you never get any stronger. story and characters are non-existent, so the game has to stand entirely on it's gameplay and while it's fun enough if you take it for what it is (a single player card game) and don't compare it to more fleshed out card games like mtg, again, i'd say i wouldn't pay full price for it. i certainly don't understand the glazing that it gets.
