a bit more than a month after finishing this game, i've come to the conclusion that i need to make a review about it. this game is one of those experiences that i can't really imagine leaving you after you go through it. i absolutely recommend it. the music is beautiful, the characters are memorable, the gameplay is fun, and the story is genuinely amazing, with some of the best writing and execution i've seen. there are a few people who think the endings get a bit irritating to do over again and again for all the endings, which they aren't wrong in, but i enjoyed seeing that all again personally. with the sole exception of the junk heap. that place sucks. nice music though. this is a game you want to go into blind. don't look up stuff before or while playing or it won't feel as impactful (this goes for most games tbh). unless its about getting through the junk heap... i am very much looking forward to playing nier automata. once again i heavily recommend anyone who sees this review plays the game.

absolute cinema — one of my favorites. but the completionist experience was a nightmare. the required items had such low drop rates that it drove me insane; i lost around 15–20 hours of farming, and it really ruined the experience. the speedrun boss achievement was also frustrating — you can’t unlock it unless you skip the cutscenes, even though the beauty of this game lies in its cutscenes and storytelling. very disappointing. i had to replay the entire story just for a speedrun achievement, and it was tedious... but discovering the game for its story alone is amazing. i really, really recommend this game.

nier replicant ver.1.22474487139 is an action rpg that builds on the cult classic nier. the updated version improves visual fidelity and gameplay flow while keeping the original structure. the world design presents a bleak tone that pushes the player to question the value of progress. strong art direction supports this. combat uses light and heavy attacks mixed with magic abilities. animation timing feels responsive. enemy variety grows at a steady pace. boss encounters stand out through scale and pattern recognition. the combat system is not complex but remains engaging across the runtime. the narrative focuses on a journey to save a loved one. it presents moral ambiguity without pointing to a single correct answer. dialogue reveals layered character motivations. themes involve identity and the cost of survival. emotional impact builds as the story advances. multiple endings encourage repetition. new routes add narrative context rather than simple alternates. later runs change perspective and reframe earlier events. this structure rewards patient players who want deeper lore. it also increases the total playtime without feeling padded. the soundtrack is notable. vocal tracks rise during key story beats. ambient music maintains tension in quieter moments. sound design fits both exploration and combat. audio feedback supports player awareness in fights. visual upgrades include refined textures and improved lighting. character models feel more detailed. environments show stronger depth. performance remains stable on modern hardware. load times are short. nier replicant ver.1.22474487139 succeeds as a refreshed version of a niche title. it preserves the unusual tone and narrative risk while modernizing weak points of the original. it appeals to players who value story driven structure more than mechanical complexity.

i played nier replicant for about 15 hours, and honestly, i found the experience disappointing. a large chunk of my playtime was spent running back and forth on the same roads just to reach different villages or cities, which quickly became repetitive. enemy variety felt low, and the boss fights didn’t really stand out — they were more underwhelming than exciting. the story was interesting on the surface, but it never really dug deep or elaborated enough to keep me fully engaged. compared to the first nier game, this felt like a step backwards. for me, it ended up being more of a waste of time than a memorable experience.

this game is a junky mess. i'll rate this game as a 2021 game (meaning i expect it to meet 2021 game standards), not a 2010 one. the story is acceptable enough that it kept me playing and forced me to play and get the abcde endings. and the story is the only positive thing about this game; everything else is mediocre/horrible. - gameplay - junky, slow. everything you do in the game should be done faster: every dialogue, interaction, collecting anything, just everything. - combat - junky, tedious, repetitive. sometimes i just ran past enemies because i didn't feel like fighting them. - side-quests - absolutely horrible, boring, snooze-fest. most of them are fetch-quests that add nothing to the game. - fast travel system - should be much better, not this crap with boats where you have four places to travel and usually it's faster to get somewhere else by just running there - bosses - most of them were tragic, boring, and too long. lots of gimmick bosses, multiple phases. the culmination of the bosses' tragedy was a boar that had to be killed 15 times (i counted) in many places to progress. - the structure of this game is poor. the gameplay should be structured so that you play once and discover everything in that single playthrough, instead of everything being divided up so that in route a you get almost nothing, in route b you get a few more cutscenes, and in route c you get a few more dialogue lines. and you play for hours just to get one more line of dialogue. all of this should be in one playthrough, not forcing the player to repeat everything multiple times to get the "context" of what we've done.

i really wanted to enjoy nier replicant, but the pc version is plagued with technical issues that make it hard to justify the price, or the time investment. 🛠️ [b]technical problems galore[/b] from inconsistent frame pacing to poor mouse and keyboard support, the game feels like a barebones port. crashes, stuttering, and resolution scaling issues are common, and even basic features like borderless window mode are missing or broken. it’s baffling that the game was released in this state. 🚫 [b]developer neglect[/b] what’s most frustrating is the lack of meaningful updates or communication from the developers. these issues have been widely reported since launch, yet there’s been little to no effort to patch or optimize the game for pc players. it feels abandoned. 💸 [b]refunded and relieved[/b] i ended up getting a refund, and honestly, i wouldn’t recommend anyone spend more than 10€ on this unless the technical problems are fixed. as it stands, it’s not worth the hassle. 🎮 [b]final verdict[/b] if you’re curious about the story, maybe watch a playthrough or pick it up on console. but for pc? save your money and your patience.

i do not get it. i couldn't finish it and had to put it down. the voice of the book is so grating. constant exhalation, way more than necessary. switched to japanese and then had trouble reading the tiny subtitles in the middle of combat. the constant backtracking is mind numbing. you spend more time running from a to b then doing anything. the side quests are the absolute worst form of mmo garbage. this is totally unacceptable. half of them require you to either grind a bunch bullshit, or just buy arbitrary quantities of things. story moments frequently lock you out of interacting with npc's critical to services and side quests. music is great but there is only like 4 songs. combat sucks. no gap closer, wonky camera when locked on, getting stuck in a 5 second combo facing the wrong direction, basically all magic except dark blast is pointless and a waste of time, and every trash mob has a steel foundry worth of armor you need to bash off before doing damage. characters are unlikable. main character might be the best, fashion sense aside. the story of the endlessly sick sister that everyone wants to have her just lay in bed "resting" until she dies drives me up the wall. bitches days are numbered, let her have fun. emil is cloying and melodramatic. kaine is some kind of futa fetish fantasy constantly talking shit. the desert mask people are supposed to be cute? they are annoying, the desert i have to constantly cross to get to them is annoying. the forest text dungeon was waaaaaay too long. i just skipped through all of that crap. after heading back to the starting area for the bajillionth time i just couldn't take it anymore. this game sucks.

at 17.9 hours and bought for $9.99 short answer: yes its worth buying, bethesda wont stop breaking fallout 4, and when they get around to releasing fallout 5 in 2200, we all know it going to be horrible anyway. dont buy over $20 wait for a sale they come around too often. longer answer: honestly screw bethesda they need to shut their doors for good and sell the ip to someone who cares. this game is entirely made up of extremes. if somethings good, then its really good. if somethings bad, then its really bad. iv watched this game from afar since before the release waiting for the right time if there would ever be one to buy. its nowhere close to the miserable state of crap i expected buying it, and im actively enjoying myself. if you`re thinking about buying it, its likely because fallout 4 is just unplayable with bethesda trying to appease their hallucinated new audience of people suddenly interested in fallout because season 2 of the show is around the corner and they will break every mod and destroy everyone`s saves to do so. don`t be afraid, the waters actually fine. there is for sure a player base here and active, and im strictly solo so no ones helping or assisting me in anyway outside of chance encounters with people out in the world.

it's more complicated than a yes or a no; even as i am writing this, i'm currently playing it, and i've put 94 hours in in the past two weeks, apparently. fallout 76 was one i initially picked up on ps4 when it dropped; i've been through a lot of the highs and lows, and so my recommendation is: if you can find your own fun in things with friends or alone, you might like this game. however, that said- there is absolutely no reason this game should be as buggy as it is, 7 years out, over some of the most basic of things. it's a real shame that bethesda doesn't give this so much more technical support, too, as it could really be a good game- but it's ultimately stunted by some design choices, by lack of bug fixes, and a healthy dose of corporate greed for microtransactions. again- overall, i personally really enjoy my time with the game, but i can't in good conscience suggest it to others at full price. wait for a sale. there's a ton of fomo marketing at play with it, too, which frankly sucks.

this game will earn a thumbs up from me when they remove all 'pay to reduce the grind' products from their microtransaction shop & when they allow us to play in private worlds.... without continually paying for it. like all the previous titles. it's a real shame because they've got a fantastic game here. the experience of wandering the wasteland is beyond any other game... but they had to go smear a bunch of marketing crap over it which really sullies the experience. i would happily pay 5$ per month for a stipend of atoms. i will not ever pay 13$ a month to be allowed to use a storage box, or just not play online. start there, bethesda, fix your game!

qol is pretty bad. basic items not included (think fo4), you have to use the atom shop. server stability is not good, random disconnects with "server is not responding" pretty much kills emersion. basic graphics settings are not available (contrast/brightness, etc...) instead you have to monkey around with custom ini files hoping you can make the game playable. visuals are not ideal. shadows at mid-day render, while in them, a pitch black area where enemies are hidden. there are so many i don't have time to list them all. basically all of these little problems add up to make the game more annoying than fun. the only reason i am still playing is i wanted to give the game a fair chance so i told myself, "self, i will play to level 100 and then see". well i'm at level 68 but with the random server disconnects i may not make it.

tl;dr: nothing more and nothing less than a scam. you buy fallout 76 because you just like wasting your money… that’s fine! but that’s only where the fun begins! because guess what? you can throw even more of your precious tinky-pinky shitey whackey cash at it! fallout 76 for only €40. (base game… and by “base” i mean the bare minimum.) sooner or later, you’ll probably want a subscription - you know, for a bit more “comfort.” people without taste will call it “basics". and to top it all off: if you like collecting things and decorating your base a little, you can unlock a few items in-game. don’t get me wrong, they look cheap or terrible at best. the good stuff? that’s where you could get rid off of your totally worthless money. *takes a deep breath* ...what a lovely ingame-shop! wonderful, isn’t it? if you feel scammed, don’t worry - that’s on purpose. and whenever the game feels dull and worthless, that’s because it is dull and worthless. let’s go even further… ever feel somewhat empty and alone while playing fo76? welcome to fallout 76 - you’re a whale, gently drifting through a dark, cold, and empty ocean. avoid being scammed, check sources and read critical reviews. /peace

overall: ★★★★★ – who knew being a tiny cat in a big cyberpunk city could feel so emotional? 🐾💖 gameplay: ★★★★★ – jumping, climbing, sneaking… so smooth and fun! 😸 story: ★★★★☆ – short but really touching, loved the little mysteries 🕵️‍♂️✨ visuals: ★★★★★ – neon streets, tiny details everywhere, just wow 🌃😍 music & sound: ★★★★★ – super immersive, perfectly sets the mood 🎶💫 atmosphere: ★★★★★ – lonely but magical, i got completely lost in it 🌌🐾 fun factor: ★★★★★ – honestly, just being a cat exploring this world is pure joy 😹 ✅ recommended for: cat lovers 🐱, explorers 🌍, indie fans 🎮, or anyone who wants a short emotional journey 💖

phew.. this really hurts me but i think overall i wouldn't really recommend it. soft spoilers in the review (mostly just settings) the first level is amazing, exploring the town, meeting robots and learning about how they function is great. you can explore with great verticality to either walk on the streets or over the rooftops. but unfortunately it falls off pretty hard after that, the sewers are intense and i liked the vibe but the gameplay was stale and very linear. the town in the sewers is also just a path to go further up untill we reach midtown. midtown was the most disapointing aspect for me because while it is pretty big there is just so much less in it. you can't really climb up anywhere to explore and outside of the main quest you can ignore everyone in it unless you really want to see what their one line of dialoge will be. the game is nice, i think a lot of people can have fun playing this but for me personally once the charm of "awe cute cat" has worn off i really felt that most of the developers love and attention was put into the first area.

i have to say no as i think £23.99 is a quite frankly extortionate amount of money for the game. on sale at 50% off its worth it but i wouldn't pay more. while exploring as a cat does have a lot of charm to it, the ending was the most infuriating. spoilers ahead. you get to the top, you unseal the city, but i get to see almost nothing of what happened to my friends i made along the way. i spent so much time in the low area, was shopping with them, bartering, and all i see is one robot happy. just feels a bit, of a shame. my companion b-12 kills himself at the end for the greater good. bit of a boring plot device that i kind of saw coming. once we get back to the outside, what other purpose would he serve, all the humans are dead. again his whole demise felt a bit, rushed. the whole final level felt rushed and just a bit, boring. it was underwhelming and sad. i really liked my cat player and i think its a good game at half the price. but i finished it in 6h30m didn't focus on collectibles but tried to explore everywhere. there was a lot of room with the world they had created to expand upon it with the characters and allow me to revisit or, see people rise up against the peacekeepers and the sentinels, things like that. i don't know why they felt a need to cut the game so short. i hope stray 2 is a longer game that feels more polished in how it looks after its characters. it felt like certain decisions were made simply because they didn't want to have to animate or do x thing.

i only play this game for the warhammer 40k mod, which i will add works amazingly. i cannot recommend this game enough if you want to play 40k online, or even just to make different armys and practice them, the possibilities are quite endless and the best part it doesnt cost you money to try things out. its really useful for trying expensive models in gameplay before you commit to buying them in real life. its very fun game and has so many quality of life features that make playing 40k a lot quicker and easier but definitly shouldnt be used to substitute the real game. its also very easy to make your own custom mods for the game like datacards or codexes, or any kind of text or data document you want really, you literally just need a pdf image and you can upload it to a custom template then save it, posting social media is probably harder! the amount of different map packs the community has made is unreal, it would cost you a lot of money to play on some of the map designs i have seen in the game. the whole experience is basically your warhammer 40k dream with no financial constraints, you're free to make the biggest most expensive army you can and play it for free. if you like 40k this game is a no brainer like why do you not own it already?

genres: Action, Casual, Indie, Strategy, Free To Play
review_text: bloons td battles 2 is what happens when someone at ninja kiwi said: “what if tower defense… but also ranked anxiety?” you boot it up thinking “haha monkeys vs balloons,” and suddenly you’re sweating over **optimal eco curves** while some guy named “xxblo0ngodxx” sends fortified zomgs on round 28. --- ### pros: * same adorable bloons, now in glorious hd ruining your entire evening. * heroes add “personality” which is nice, because you definitely need quincy saying “i never miss” after you absolutely do. * meta constantly shifting so you can never, ever be happy or comfortable. * every match feels like a job interview for “war criminal, bloon division.” --- ### cons: * you: “i’ll try a fun off-meta strategy.” matchmaking: *puts you against a guy with 4k hours and a spreadsheet open.* * one mis-timed rush and your entire economy folds like a dollar store lawn chair. * “rubber to gold” is also the name of what this game does to your free time. * ranked = climb 100 trophies in 2 hours, lose them all in 10 minutes, go lie down on the floor. --- ### peak battles 2 experience: * both players quietly farming, building defenses, playing it safe. then round 18 hits and suddenly it’s **wwiii with purple and zebra bloons.** * you send a giant, carefully calculated all-in rush. opponent defends with 3 abilities and an emote. you sit there, broke, watching the defeat screen in 4k. * “gg” typed with tears in your eyes and 3 fps left. --- 10/10 turned strategy, math, and psychological warfare into one colorful package. would say “no rush, just chilling” and then full-send fortified bads again.

review_text: this game fun occasionally, maybe a game or two a day, but its not the sort of game i could see myself playing for hours on end. would still recommend it to any bloons fans (play btd6 first). overall the game is less of a test of skill, and more of a knowledge check, at least until you get to the top .1% of players. early laddering is basically looking at the opponents board and seeing what they forgot to account for and exploiting it. this works for most ranks, and can be fun if you like stomping newbies. there are a lot of newbies. note that this game looks like microtransaction hell at first glance, and while the game is easily ftp, i could see a more impressionable person throwing money into the in game marketplace.

genres: Action, Casual, Indie, Strategy, Free To Play
review_text: игра 'bloons td battles 2' – это приятное продолжение популярной tower defense серии. графика стала более яркой и современной, а игровой процесс, хотя и знакомый, предлагает достаточно новых элементов и стратегий. pvp сражения напряженные и требуют быстрого мышления и адаптации к тактике противника. разнообразие башен и героев позволяет экспериментировать с разными билдами и стратегиями. однако, присутствует некоторая проблема с балансом, некоторые башни и герои явно сильнее других. также, процесс улучшения прогресса кажется немного медленным, особенно для бесплатных игроков. реклама ненавязчива, но может встретиться несколько раз в день. в целом, игра увлекательная и предоставляет часы стратегического геймплея, хотя и требует некоторого терпения для достижения более высоких уровней.

review_text: bloons td battles 2 delivers a solid and engaging multiplayer tower defence game: it has the mechanics, players, and polish you’d want. for players who are committed and understand what they’re getting into, it’s well worth playing. however, the game is not without caveats: the progression system, perceived pay-to-win elements, and pacing may hinder the experience for some. final call: if you’re into strategic duels, enjoy tower defence and are okay with some investment (time or money), go for it. if you prefer anything more casual or loathe grind/unlock systems, you might want to wait or approach cautiously.

review_text: the battles where you use tickets are full of bots. you can clearly see the difference between how real players play and how bots that surgically calculate and send balloons behave. in these battles, it’s shocking that all the players (bots) play in exactly the same style. they give you three free tickets, use bots to beat you, and then make you pay to buy more tickets to keep playing. in the free battles (where you don’t need tickets), i didn’t feel there were any bots. it’s sad how great games are becoming so stupid in the hands of sneaky business people. there are tools (like auto balloon senders, banana farmers, etc.), and nobody understands why you have to pay for them. they intentionally make parts of the game annoying (like collecting bananas or manually sending balloons) just so they can sell you those tools to remove the annoyance. i really hope governments and lawmakers do something about this micro-transaction nonsense. it’s like they give you free heroin to get you addicted, then sell you the heroin or the rehab for money. just sell the damn game, and if you want more money make an expansion packs etc!!!

when decision-based, cinematic games first started taking off, twd came out of nowhere and set the bar pretty high. the plot and decisions presented to the player are top-notch offerings, with each episode being full of memorable encounters and exiting (or depressing) moments. it had somewhat of an advantage of being the first "big" telltale-style game, but make no mistake: the hype for this one is pretty real. there's some age on it at this point and the game's engine in particular was never that great, but it's still an easy [b]5 out of 5 game[/b]. other attempts in this genre may come and go, but lee and clementine are forever.

«the walking dead» by robert kirkman was originally not a story about those who rose from the dead in the mould of our beloved george a. romero, but about those who remained in this world to enforce laws according to their own, often twisted moral compass. in turn, the phrase «the walking dead» refers to the unconverted people who have ceased to be human. in the first and most heart‑wrenching part, playing as lee everett, we have to do quite a lot to ultimately achieve true catharsis.

classical telltale interactive story. the story is interesting, the dialogue is (mostly) well written and the characters are believable. i dislike this game purely from a gameplay perspective. the gameplay (between the story and dialogue choices) is quite clunky together with bad camera placement. it is annoying when people get mad or sad that you did not talk to them but the camera angle also did not show where they were. also the automatic save points are sometimes quite far apart. so when you want or have to stop playing and come back you might have to replay larger portions of a chapter. together with unskippable cutscenes, this gets annoying very quickly. let me skip cutscenes i have already seen! i do not need a "what happened before" when i just finished the previous chapter and i do not need a "what happens next" at the end of a chapter that spoils part of the story!

telltale’s the walking dead: season 2 is a strong continuation of clementine’s emotional journey, pushing her into even tougher situations and forcing players to see the world through her eyes. the story remains gripping, with meaningful character moments and some heartbreaking twists. there are noticeably more qtes and player choices this time around, adding tension and a stronger sense of agency. while not every choice leads to drastically different outcomes, the weight of each decision still feels impactful.

if the walking dead’s first season was about finding hope through connection, season two is about the cost of keeping it. telltale games shifts perspective in a daring move; you now play as clementine, no longer the protected but the protector, and that single change reframes everything. what was once a story of guidance becomes one of survival, loneliness and premature adulthood. the emotional tone is bleaker, the choices harsher. there’s no lee to steady your hand this time, no moral anchor. instead, you’re forced to navigate shifting alliances and impossible decisions while the world collapses around you. telltale doubles down on moral ambiguity, asking questions that rarely have clean answers: how much of your humanity can you sacrifice and still call yourself human? technically, the creaky engine and qte remain, but they fade into the background thanks to powerful writing and performances. melissa hutchison’s portrayal of clementine is remarkable: restrained, vulnerable and quietly fierce. the supporting cast, while inconsistent, delivers some of the series’ most haunting moments, particularly in its later episodes. visually, the comic book aesthetic continues to serve the material well, and the score - subdued yet piercing - underscores the emotional exhaustion that defines the journey. season two doesn’t quite match the original’s freshness or emotional gut punch, but it’s every bit as courageous. it’s a story about growing up too fast in a world that’s forgotten kindness, where survival often feels like defeat. by the time the credits roll, you realize telltale hasn’t just made you play clementine... they’ve made you become her!

so unapologetically weird and so fun to unravel for it. finding the underlying logic, both mechanically and narratively, in this mess of seemingly senseless esoteric rambling is an immensely satisfying experience. there's a great roguelike underneath this game's meaty exterior.

golden light is a strange, creepy, and very unique roguelike. the game hooks you with its absurd atmosphere: fleshy hallways, living objects, bizarre monsters, and the constant feeling that everything around you is alive and watching. levels are procedurally generated, so every run feels unpredictable — sometimes funny, sometimes genuinely scary. what i really liked is that the game doesn’t hold your hand: you discover the rules yourself and learn how to use the environment and weapons in creative ways. even glitches here somehow feel like part of the style. the soundtrack fits perfectly with the madness on screen. that said, it’s not a game for everyone. it can feel chaotic, a bit clunky at times, and if you’re not into surreal “meatcore” aesthetics, this will probably be too much. overall, it’s a great horror roguelike for players looking for something unconventional that isn’t afraid to break the rules.

[h2] briefly [/h2] this is a dynamic horror roguelike with an unusual plot. [table] [tr] [th]+[/th] [th]-[/th] [/tr] [tr] [td]visual[/td] [td]long transitions[/td] [/tr] [tr] [td]storyline[/td] [td]-[/td] [/tr] [tr] [td]gameplay dynamics[/td] [td]-[/td] [/tr] [/table] total 8/10 [h2] full review [/h2] this is a very unusual game that combines the horror and roguelike genres. every item in the game has hidden properties that you discover by eating it. all items can be eaten, including ordinary consumables and weapons. many notes are scattered around the locations, some of which reveal the properties of items or plot details. the lobby is also highly interactive. you can find items in it that will help you navigate the locations. fans of both genres will enjoy this game. i recommend checking it out!

you get over the weirdness in five minutes. every level is exactly the same. spawn in, wander tiny cramped dark halls looking for randomly spawned keys, leave. each level starts with an unskippable "stand there doing nothing" section. each level contains unavoidable traps and gas, randomly spawned around you in such density as to be unavoidable, all serving just to pluck away at your health and money while you wander the pitch blackness looking for keys. each enemy respawns infinitely and acts the same, walking up to you and hitting you. fighting them is pointless and there are hardly any weapons, all of which break in two swings. guns too, despite being weaker to the point of uselessness and also requiring randomly spawned bullets to be found to even use them. once you get past how hard this game is trying to be weird you find it's gameplay loop is tedious, terrible, and lasts the entire game.

if you get motion sick from first person games, this game will do it to you and it will not let you increase your fov base, instead it's an unlockable option. typically i don't get this type of harm from fps games but the way movement feels and the game plays really made me feel like vomiting after a bit of playing. i can't really go for a refund, just not who i am, but i felt like putting this out there for anyone who gets motion sick from games: skip this one, it's really not worth battling your stomach for.

partial controller support indeed. unless you plan on spending a long time fighting steam input and the half baked controller support, don't bother. shame, the game looks cool and i was excited to finally try it when it went free for a bit, but core mechanics are simply not accessible on controller. this has apparently been an issue for two years now and no improvement, so i encourage the dev to disable native controller support entirely or actually make it functional out of the box. it really sucks when an interesting game advertises that it could be accessible (as most 'partial support' games just have a few instances of text input that cause that, such as naming a save file) only to completely shit the bed about it. if this had been a good experience, i may have been tempted to purchase the dev's other work, but it's wasn't so i'll be sure to forget about this game by tomorrow.

might be the best coop game i've played, scratches that itch for me of requiring teamwork and being highly cooperative. have yet to find a game like it, the sequel does not do it for me. if you have friends to play with its a ton of fun, if you don't, i'd recommend making some. gameplay is chaotic and full of very funny moments. long and relatively fleshed out progression system and good degrees of difficulty to match, quite grindy though but gives you things to work towards for a long time. playerbase nowadays is quite small however. 3 factions with plenty of enemy variety and good build options to adapt to them. there's a high degree of skill expression but its still goofy and casual which is perfect for me. still wishing for an iteration on this type of twin stick shooter in love with melee dodging... hmu if you wanna play :)

back in december i didn't want to buy helldivers 2 yet and helldivers 1 was available for about $5. i bought it but it was a top down game and i just messed with it awhile and forgot about it. when i started playing it for real a few weeks ago because i loved helldivers 2 and wanted some perspective on the first war-- i was stunned to realize how well designed and good this game actually was! all of the strategems and weapons of the helldivers 2 game originated here and there is a reason why there was a sequel. this game is addictive especially since if you and your friends lose a battle the front line will creep toward super earth and you could lose the war. after 10 years it still has a vibrant online community. i say if it goes on sale on liberation day october 26th or around that time, check it out! its really an amazing little game. its not for everyone and it is not a 3rd person shooter like helldivers 2 but if you like the helldivers humor and universe, you will enjoy it.

basically alien swarm but not as frustrating and a cool wargame mechanic. that's pretty much all i can say. should you play it? yes. is it anything like the second game? no. it's a completely different game all together. will you like it if you played hd2? maybe. depends on what you played for. like i said, it plays a lot like alien swarm, utilizing similar mechanics from hd2 as obviously hd2's mechanics came from this game so... yeah. everything is radically different, including weapon customization. you get a few upgrades and can use research points to buy them. each upgrade varies in price. you get rp by leveling up and collecting samples. armor doesn't have passives, instead it's purely cosmetic, and all the armors look pretty good. the liberator has a bayonet upgrade. all in all a solid top-down shooter with fun gunplay and strategems to use. also actually in a playable state unlike hd2 so if you need that itch scratched but cannot stand the state of the second game definitely give this one a shot. it's also a great way to get acquanted with the upcoming units that are being brought over from this game to the sequel, even tho they will play differently than in hd1 it's still a neat sneak peak into what's coming next. 9/10, solid game, great soundtrack just like hd2, fun mechanics, and can actually run smoothly on any platform lmao.

while not the worst twinstick shooter ever made, helldivers 1 does [i]not[/i] hold up well to modern standards. the atmosphere (especially voice acting) is underwhelming, the combat is clunkier than its successor, and the game as a whole lacks the polish that is present in its successor. the atmosphere, in particular, is worth singling out above all other flaws present in hd1; while the core gameplay is passable, the atmosphere simply [i]is not there[/i] compared to hd2. comparing the intro cinematics between the two games is enough to summarize the difference, especially as that difference in quality persists long after the intro ends. only try this if you can live with a much more underwhelming atmosphere and gameplay is the only trait you're looking for.

to our american friends, if you see this message, please consider acquiring this ridiculous game company. love from eos. this should have been a historic moment in gaming — players from all over the world united for a last stand, a glorious comeback. but arrow turned its back on everyone who believed in them. all our efforts were in vain. we poured countless hours into this, and all of it was for nothing.

disable steam cookies @ [url]https://store.steampowered.com/account/cookiepreferences[/url] steam support are [b]content[/b] [i](their words)[/i] with the current refund policy that allows devs to update games months/years after "purchase" where they can then remove [b][u]advertised features[/u][/b] that you paid for aka [b]bait & switch[/b] with no recourse [i](14day2hr - only exceptions are big backlashes).[/i] [b]we really have [i]no control[/i] over our own [i]steam libraries[/i][/b] and its only a matter of time before it happens to a game [i]you care[/i] about as this becomes more prevalent with more and more games adding launchers years later, requiring 3rd party accounts (to collect and sell our data), updating [i]our[/i] 8+yr old games just to add advertisements for their new games or worse adding kernel-level spyware [i]"anti-cheat"[/i] and as mentioned removing advertised features like os support, cross-play, or anything else they feel like removing because they can so long as it doesn't result in a big backlash and mass negative reviews - although even that they are already making negative reviews less impactful. [h3][b]we get no offline installers, no (official) way to stop an update or revert it - not even to the version at time of [i]"purchase".[/i] most games are now requiring an always online connection (even for single player) and have no lan or dedicated server to host our own servers. we have [b]no control over our libraries.[/b] they want us to own nothing [strike]and be happy.[/strike][/b] [i]"buy"[/i] only at [b]high discounts[/b] or [b]drm free[/b] with [b]lan/dedicated servers.[/b][/h3]

great game ruined by ridiculous camera being bound across all 4 players. even when playing with only 2 players and staying close together we can hardly see a few meters in front of us and the patrols are always detecting us off screen and triggering the alarm. even when we are all playing on separate computers the camera stays centered on all players ensuring that we can never see the enemies off screen while they can see us perfectly. trying to stay close together only helps us to see a tiny bit further and ensures we will friendly fire and 1 shot each other.

this game just feels like such an asshole. which makes me say the devs are total assholes. why do friendly inbound reinforcement have to aim for my head every freaking time. i just want to kick the devs in the nutsack for all the obnoxious brutality piled on top of what is already 'hell diving'. if there was a rating system i would probably say 2.5. lots of points for actually being fun but many demotes for "asshole design". all the best features are in the dlc which is just stupid. just sell a game or dont, quit screwing around with the best gear in dlc, that's just annoying and i'm already annoyed at friendlies dropping on my head every other second like it's literally trying to kill you with ally drop pods. then you've got the fact that any enemy can spawn anywhere anytime. gtfo. a tank can just plop right next to you or your esquort mission and kill everything in a split second. speaking of split seconds the freaking light walls are messed up. if you can't see the thing that makes the walls the visual que is so fast it's impossible for the human brain to react in time. the camera is another jackass in itself. the game insists on everyone sharing the same screen even with online players so you can't actually see what's coming you just have 0 visibility half the time. the controls for the mechs get all wonky and go the wrong way unless you vigilantly hold the joystick in the perfect position to maintain your aim. i like this game but there's too much in it that pisses me off to recommend it.

putting aside many design choices like aliens spawning at the very same inch you are, instantly killing you; lack of high contrast crosshair and further customizations; a better, cleaner and more clarifying ui; and the fact the game is pretty much dead but still relying on community progress to unlock stuff, it's still a blast. unfortunately, [b]i can only recommend if you gather some friends for a casual fun[/b]. in case you decide to go solo, things like aliens spawning right where you are completely kill your experience - and i wonder how tf they never did something about it. gladly i have no intention of playing helldivers 2, awyways. better stick to deep rock if you want a game with continous, long term fun and solid progression.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text: tower unite is a brilliantly laid back game. with several minigames from the casual and fun minigolf, to the arcade horde shooter of zombie massacre. this game has plenty for people to see and do, with a player base which may be small yet is highly active and devoted to this game, you should see the workshop content this game has! however, the best thing about this game has to be the development team who are active in the game and listen to player feedback as well as hosting plenty of events throughout the year to keep players interested, if you want a laid back party game you can enjoy, i highly suggest you give tower unite a go!

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text: this is a social game and is an amazing value for the money. i bought it long ago when most of the games and cosmetics that are here now were not, and it was still worth it back then. for $20 (or less) this has it all: mini-golf with a dozen or more courses, ball racing, go kart racing, minigames in the plaza, a casino, bowling, trivia, an arcade with dozens of games to earn tickets and redeem for prizes, a shooting gallery, a roller coaster, fishing spots with various bait and tackle, tons of fish, condos you can decorate and buy items for (and invite others to hang out in!), movie theaters (and you can watch youtube movies/videos with friends there or your condo!)...it's an absolutely incredible value for the money and tons of fun. and no microtransactions!! everything you buy in the game, you earn in the game, by playing games in the arcade or the main games. 10/10, if you like even 10% of what's there.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text: started playing tower unite way back in 2013, when i didn't even have the counter strike games yet. i was looking at a big pink chessboard and i still loved everything it had to offer. macdguy was even available to chat to on skype. great times. when the game became standalone, i held off for years - because i felt i wouldn't enjoy it as much anymore. but once i got it; boy, was i wrong. i love everything about this game and it's a shame that it doesn't get played as much as it did back on gmod. i would love to see this game skyrocket in the future!

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text: tower unite is everything i loved about the old gmod community experience, modernized and expanded into its own vibrant world. as someone with several hours in gmod, i truly appreciate the culture this game has built on and evolved. it captures that same sense of creativity, fun, and community but with its own unique personality. the variety of mini-games is a blast, and there’s always something new to jump into. whether you’re competing, exploring, or just hanging out, there’s a strong social aspect that brings players together in a way few games manage these days. i enjoy all the activities tower unite offers, and it’s clear the game has plenty of room to grow. the dedicated dev team is constantly improving things and seems genuinely passionate about the project. it’s refreshing to see developers so involved and committed. overall, tower unite is an awesome experience with tons of potential. i’m excited to keep playing and can’t wait to see where the devs take it next.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text: i love this game. i was a long time player of gmod tower, tower unite's predecessor, and when i first heard about this game, i was worried. i backed the indiegogo campaign, and as soon as i got access, i was playing. i've been off and on again, as other games catch my interest, but i've kept an eye on tower, and often return. honestly, it has issues at times, but i feel that most of the issues are peanuts in comparison to the lack of content in other social games. many social games feel like glorified chat rooms, and if tower unite was a chat room, it'd be a bbs in december of 1993. i've bought this game for multiple people, who have all enjoyed it, including my sister (who otherwise just plays sims 4 and minecraft), my fiance, and my best friend (who otherwise plays age of empires 2 and counter-strike: source). despite it's flaws, the game has something for everyone, and even at the slowest of times, you can find people online to hang out with. i love this game, and as long as it's online, i'll be playing it.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text: tower unite is one of those games that's perfect for a friend group who struggles to decide on what to play. it may not be something i reach for every day, but it's something i'm always confident i'll come back to. there's plenty of fun, curated experiences and activities that the developers provide alongside a plethora of self-expression and ways to create your own fun: custom player models, a level editor for various activities, and even a robust player housing system. just when my friends and i think we've seen it all, we find some guy who turned his condo into an entire 80s vaporwave sci-fi retro-futuristic city to explore. i would highly recommend it for often-ambivalent friend groups, people who are looking for a chill social experience, or people with a strong creative spark who enjoy expressing themselves in the games they play.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text: this game is soulless. the magic of "gmod tower" is gone and dead; nonetheless, a soulless shell persists on its grave. and that game is tower unite. throughout the years, the game has been slowly dying and losing interest to those who had hoped it would be a golden frontier for gmod tower. but sadly, they failed to deliver. with the slow updates and repetitive gameplay, most players succumbed to boredom and deleted the game right after. the updates don't include a lot of material for players to work with. being forced to be stuck with a limited gameplay loop of: a. a very small player base that plays mini-games, which may consist of 3 to 5 players, or, if unlucky, none of the mini-games have any active player base. b. oversimplified mini-games. because of how simple the game is, it becomes boring very fast due to its very repetitive nature. of course, i can go for hours talking about the flaws and issues with the game. but that wouldn't solve anything, nor be necessary. i'm overall disappointed with how this game turned out. sure, there's gambling and great detail with all these games and how they look and function. it doesn't feel rewarding after a certain point. it feels bland. of course, this is my opinion and feeling about the game, and others feel different, but overall, this is what i've noticed.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text: unfortunately even after 1.0 release this game is so laggy, both in terms of performance and networking, that the experience of even something as basic as walking around in the lobby is deeply unpleasant, let alone playing a minigame. i really wish i could recommend this game but it's so hard to look past the fact that, despite some interesting and fun aspects, the core gameplay experience is still disorientingly laggy and unstable despite years of updates. if i wasn't always rubber banding around the lobby and experiencing big frame hitches just walking around, i'd probably give the game more consideration, but unfortunately the game feels *very* janky and uncomfortable to play.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text: it's a good game. there's a lot to do. and this review would normally be positive, but: it is incredibly buggy. alone in half a week of playing again, there have not just been simple overlookable bugs but outright game-breaking ones, including full hard crashes. and in addition to that, the servers themselves also have massive lagspikes spanning 15 seconds, if not longer. this was sort of excusable in early access, but the game has been released since then. from a gamedev perspective there have also been really odd choices regarding ui/ux among other things. i want to reiterate that it is a ton of fun with all the things you can do, but i cannot recommend it currently due to the above issues at the asked price at all.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text: this review is about the ability to play/host this game privately with a couple of friends rather than the game mechanics itself. see to other reviews if you don’t care about this. short version: you cannot host a private plaza dedicated server like you used to, neither can you have a private session with your friends anymore. (you can however set your private condo to friends-only if you host from the game client from what i’ve understood) longer version: as someone who used to play this game every day (not on this account) many years ago i was so excited to pick this up again seeing how much it had evolved over time only to find they’ve removed the ability to host a private plaza and have essentially forced most of the interactions into the public sphere. their reasoning for doing this makes sense but it sounds more like an excuse rather than a justified reason because they could have made it so people who wishes to host a private game were simply forbidden from using these private characters and any asset on public servers. i understand this requires more work but having come from the time this game allowed this made it really disheartening to discover after my excitement. ☹ maybe someday the developers will again grace us introverts with the ability to host our fully private version away from the public hoi polloi of business. until then i cannot recommend this game for people like me. thanks for reading!

after fixing the issue this game is great for those who are crashing during loading if you have sufficent hardware heres what you do: go to c:\users\yourusernamehere\appdata\roaming\microsoft flight simulator and in your usercfg.opt find the line that says "preferd3d12 0" and change it to "preferd3d12 1"

playtime: <15hr os: lm 22.2 cin cpu: r7 2700x gpu: rx6800xt mem: 16x2 ddr4 3.2k hdd install i dont think theres been a single instance where ive launched this game and not had a hairpulling experience. reinstalling always makes me remember why it was uninstalled to begin with. id rather not play when every single peripheral keybind is dumped out of nowhere. id rather not play when the core ui itself, from main menu to cockpit interaction requires you to spam click and hope one click works but not twice because then youre back on step one. id rather not play when i finally rebind all those controls that emptied themselves just to hit f11 to save and apply them for the game to crash, saving none of my changes after waiting for the five minute boot time. theres also something to be said about this title being marketed and sold as microsofts flagship "forever" flight sim that would be updated on and not succeeded for at least a decade, just to sell v1.1 four years later for 70usd as a base game. can you at least copilot multiplayer in that one? lmao waste of 500gb.

for a shooter that is supposed to be all about the ssstyle most enemies sure don´t react in any meaningful way to the majority of your shots. this means that the "player expression" is more of a facade than anything else as it pushes you to vary up your weapons for variety's sake and little else. the ranking is mostly superfluous aside from it helping with your hp regeneration, but even then the stylish part itself is not that engaging, at least in dmc, when you style on something you get to combo and lock down said enemies in the air as a result of your skills, but without significant stagger it loses much of its appeal. arena and boss design is similarly vapid due to this rigidity. with so little crowd control aside from the techniques to maximize dps, most enemy rooms turn into clusterfucks of projectiles where you spam the blood regen to tank the shots, and the bosses are mostly simplistic pattern memorization fights, where not even parries stops their onslaught, which makes such manoeuvres feel flaccid despite offering a lot of benefits in regenerating your health and dealing damage. while not totally devoid of cool ideas as seen by the coin ricochets and some cool weapons, it is a game that has ridden more on its hype rather than the substance of its mechanics. the mark of amateurish design is to be seen everywhere, like how, for example, the game has secret collectables for you to pick up, but also simultaneously punishes you in your ranking for taking too long to explore the level. it is this lack of attention to detail and messy design that makes ultrakill a gimmick rather than a true stepping stone for boomer shooters.

genres: Adventure, Casual, Massively Multiplayer, Simulation, Sports, Free To Play, Early Access
review_text: vrchat is a platform of many extremes, and that is something that has to be accepted when playing, especially in public lobbies. i've personally had some of the most enjoyable times, enlightening conversations, and the closest connections i could've ever imagined. i've also seen some of the most vial, gross and downright reprehensible content spread here. it's a polarizing tugging of both ends of the spectrum. vile language and frequent inappropriate content are frequent in public lobbies due to the lack of moderation. a good strategy is to get some close friends or a tightknit community to hang out with in private lobbies, and avoid public lobbies aside from most games. you should be fine then, but be prepared if something else should arise. the block button is a wonderful feature, and you should not be afraid to use it if someone is being offensive or reprehensible. if you're a parent looking at reviews to get a gauge on if this game is okay for your kids, wait until they turn 18 for their own sake. if you're a child thinking you're mature enough, you are not. wait until your 18 for your own safety, and thank me later. if you're over 18, you're an adult. go in with an open mind, and you'll be surprised at some of the pleasant folk that wander some of the quieter corners of the community.

review_text: i can't say for playing with strangers, but i always have fun playing this with my friends and partners, and i love that there's always new worlds to explore, there's so many different worlds that even playing by myself is fun and how i often play, i have no experience with uploading worlds, but i've had decent luck uploading avatars using vroid, blender, unity, and vrchat's offical helper add-on/ app (i can't remember what it's called but it's on their website) though i definitely recommend watching some youtube videos for guides and extra help, all in all, i think vrchat is fun, i know many people have bad experiences playing online with strangers, unfortunately, in a lot of cases, you have to do your own moderating and make sure you block, and if necessary, report, people that are causing issues or harassing you or others, vrchat is a huge platform with countless players and the moderators can only keep up so well if people aren't actually using the in game reporting system

review_text: vrchat is a social platform for everyone, provided "everyone" is a subset of people who own a full-body tracking suit and have decided their spirit animal is a neon-blue fox. the ratio is approximately 80% fluff to 20% existential crisis. if you stand still for too long, you will be adopted by a pack of digitally enhanced canine avatars. it's less a game and more an accidental, full-scale ecosystem designed to test the limits of your pc's shader capacity and your own tolerance for ear-splitting squeals. if you are looking for a reminder that society is actively degrading and that technology merely provides us with new, more efficient ways to be miserable together, vrchat is perfect. it is a necessary, awful, and deeply honest reflection of who we are when there are no consequences.

review_text: a good concept, but.... i ended up giving up. you have nothing to do there unless you're already with your private friends. people are asocial, it just doesn't make me wanting to return there. struggling to develop my review as all of my experiences have been bad there since the first time i tried, so i guess i will just give pros and cons. [h3]pros[/h3] • be what you want as long as you have your model to import. • if you don't have your own model, many are available to get in game. • playable on pc and vr. • various worlds with many purposes, such as games, exploration, or a simple home to relax in. • customization is almost limitless, but... [h3]cons[/h3] • ... extremely complexe to create and to setup, especially compared to competitors • community is very closed. don't join hoping meeting people. join with your own friends. • steamlink terribly unstable depending on setups. • subscription options too much highlighted. it almost jumps to your eyes on the menu, and happens to appear on loading screens. [h3]subjective points[/h3] • none comes in mind, feels like experience is black or white (but mostly black) [h3]final note[/h3] since it's free, you can always give it a try and potentially spend time with your friends in there, but that's it.

back in 2022 vampire survivors did not invent its genre but it did give it a major boost in popularity, now there are numerous survivor-likes everywhere. but back thern its content was pretty damn anemic. a big part of the major content that has been introduced since then can be found in the dlcs, but there were also plenty of updates to the base game. the result of this is that there is at least something to do in this game unlike many lesser titles. there is a sizable number of unlocks, a clear progression path of what to do and unlock next, many different stages with some unique gimmicks and plenty of hidden secrets. if you go for full completion you will be busy for a while and even if you arent then the variety can be entertaining for a while. that said, this is still the game that survivor-likes come from and therefor does not innovate upon the genre. for the most part it really is just the same eternal loop of pickung up a few weapons and upgrading them until the entire screen explodes and the game becomes hard to look at. you can do this with many different characters and weapons now but the result and gameplay will always be the same. but there is a reason this genre got popular and its 5 bucks without a sale, just give it a try, you will at least get a few hours out of it.

poncle, i love your game, i bought it for 3 of my friends and we have all your dlc. while we all understand the new online mode is exactly what it is; new. there are many a problem we face. opening chests during late games will cause all of us in the game to be hung up and nobody can open the chest forcing one or all of us to altf4 and reboot the game. this has been an ongoing thing for the past 4 days as i post this comment so it's not a one time thing to complain about. three times just on the night i am sending this, our game has frozen during online play and while all our survivors could move. we could not interact with floor drops, pause or see the other players move at all, all while being immune to damage and dealing none to the enemies. once again, i love your game and understand that the function is new so i can't bitch too much, i just want to inform you and others reading that this is a problem we are facing at the moment. thank you very much for readin

i wanted to like this. i can't play more than a few matches in a row because it feels very unrewarding and... i dunno, unfun. it sucks the joy of playing video games out of me as i try to play it. i have no idea what i'm supposed to do to progress. knowing who to use or what stage to complete for the next unlock you need to continue in the game itself is completely unclear. you can unlock stages well before you have the upgrades to beat them. exclamation points draw you to stages that have seemingly no objective left to complete. and worst of all, every match either feels too easy or is frustratingly impossible. you can either walk the map with impunity, as if there were no mobs spawning around you, or you're being hopelessly overwhelmed and were doomed from the start, regardless of choice and skill. i had such high hopes for this, but i've been sorely disappointed.

my only praise for this game is it really is something you can idly play without having to put any brain power into it. my many complains for this game are the forced black bars at the sides which serve 0 purpose, the lengthy grindy approach the game takes to the roguelite genre, the severe lack of difficulty in any of the game's content, a lack of originality in any of the basegame content, all of it mostly being elements stolen from castlevania and the free collab dlc maps being very lazily made, simply being a png compressed and slapped on as a background. i will continue to play this game solely due to how easy it is to idle, but i'd rather actively play games that copied this and did the formula better in every way, such as picayune dreams or bloodshed.

i adore this game and have spent a great deal of time playing this on multiple systems. this new online implementation is vastly inferior to the local co-op, so i will leave a negative review until these issues are adressed. first off the is inability to pause in online co-op, which is something you can do in local. and the fact that unlocks are per player and not for the whole. example. i played gennaro to unlock the heart passive for the crew, but only i got it and not the other players n the lobby who would each have to take turns playing gennaro. bad design imo.

after the latest update, the max item slots in couch coop were reduced from 4 to 2 per player. this completely breaks the balance and progression for duo play. how are we even supposed to reach the grim reaper (30-minute mark) with only 2 upgrades? some weapons (like peachone and ebony wings) are already useless early on without evolving, and now evolution is basically impossible because you can’t hold both needed weapons. (maybe with exdash but do i need cheatcodes to progress?) i started playing this game with another person, and we wanted to unlock everything only by playing duos. we put around 10 hours in - having fun, progressing steadily - then suddenly there’s an update, and this massive change hits without any mention in the patch notes. no explanation, no reasoning. our progress didn’t just slow down - it pretty much died. i’m not interested in using cheat codes or having one player sit out just so the other can unlock things. why even make coop mode if you’re going to cripple it like this? i saw people saying online that you can “unlock party mode” from the west wood map by gambling with someone \ but what even is west wood? where do you unlock it? can i even reach that point playing duo with only 2 item slots each? also a bit separate matter but the wiki is zero help with anything regarding couch coop. to make it worse, the game now crashes around the 25-minute mark since this same update. what even changed in the base game if the update was only supposed to add online coop? all in all, this update feels rushed, untested, and uncommunicated. vampire survivors used to be a so fun in couch coop but now it's just unplayable.

the new online update sucks. you can't help each other unlock stuff; you are essentially just a helper in battle. if you want to unlock a weapon or character, you essentially have to do it twice for both of you, but on couch co-op it works like it's supposed to. when i did that, i could unlock multiple things at once and only needed to do it one time.

i think it's official -- i like this more than slay the spire. there's a little more depth in terms of clear synergy strategies, and that becomes fun to think about. i also like the clarity of knowing what kinds of boss challenges are ahead to inform a deck build.

shiny shoe delivers again. if you enjoyed monster train or any other roguelike deckbuilders, you are going to enjoy this one too. the soundtrack in particular is quite an improvement! apart from that, most of the initial problems (e.g. old clans not having room and equipment cards) have been adressed and the game is actively improved by free updates. looking forward to any dlcs! however, if you are looking for real difficult challanges comparable to sts a20 heartruns or similar, you will be dissapointed. the game lacks a bit for the real brainians that like to spend hours on a run. with some experience, most runs will feel solved after the first couple of rings. there are some "cursed seeds" that challenge you more, but you have to join some discord groups to find them.

similar to slay the spire, the gameplay is well constructed and fun, with different reasons you might replay it time and again if you enjoy the card battles. that said, once i beat both this and slay the spire multiple times with different starter decks/mechanics, there really isn't much left in the way of new things to do. the lack of any really interesting story also makes it feel a tad hollow. get on a deep sale for a decent distraction.
nice game. had an issue during one fight where i lost all but 1 ember during several turns, and i couldn't find the reason. fun game and this was the only issue i found so far.
addictive, tons of replay value, strategies to approach each run, cards and much more to unlock after runs, etc. super great, super fun, highly recommend.
fun for the first 10 hours, but quite repetitive afterwards... same boss over and over

well i did not know that i enjoyed deck building games. perhaps you have not played one? it (the enjoyment above) started with many friends saying that i should check out slay the spire (ss from now on) and that game hooked me in. then i decided to check out some twitch streamers of ss and gravitated towards one of them. this streamer then was playing monster train (mt) and i asked him what his opinion of it was. he said "he enjoys it more than ss and thinks it is the better game". i pretty much wholeheartedly agree with him on this sentiment. gobs of replayability due to the two faction team choices and then the three champion choices within the main faction. 100 hours later and it is one of the few games (less than ten) that i have bought on mobile. lots of love have gone in to this game and i would recommend it to anyone!
banger game. slay the spire but way better.

the gameplay is unique, first time playing a roguelike deckbuilder that plays around different floors (thronebreaker doesn't count) so, thumbs up for creativity. also, it is not as hard as slay the spire so try this is you are new to the genre.
super fun and addicting - like slay-the-spire meets darkest-dungeon or something. for me it's great for playing while working out: fight, lift, repeat...

good game, but for me struggles with roguelike syndrome after a while, where either the difficulty gets ridiculous or things can start to feel the same. the daily challenge is really fun, but otherwise am probably done with the game. solid pick for the price, and if you really love roguelike deckbuilders then this one's a keeper.
one of the best card games i've ever played.

i was getting destroyed trying to build a balanced deck like i would in some other card games, but then it clicked: the goal is to break the game. figure out how to overpower your deck and crush. once you combine a unit with slay with multistike its like, ok bxtch, lets go. then you figure how to win battles with just spells because your multistrike glass cannon and tank got destroyed by some effect you didnt prepare for. there is so much strat going on and also there is a workshop and a sequel. wot

great game, especially for that small price. keeps you interested through lots of achievements and unlockable decks and cards. also great that every run starts with random cards, so every run is different and you gotta adapt to your cards.
great slay the spire alternative.

[b]score: 8/10[/b] [list] [*][b]art style:[/b] the art direction is solid and cohesive, with detailed card designs and distinctive unit visuals. while the overall aesthetic might not appeal to everyone, it fits the game’s theme effectively and maintains visual clarity even during the most hectic battles. [*][b]music:[/b] the soundtrack is quite good. there are memorable and entertaining themes that enhance the experience, even if they don’t all stand out individually for extended listening. [*][b]story:[/b] very basic story. the narrative serves as a light framing device rather than a deep or meaningful journey. [*][b]gameplay:[/b] strong variety of characters (clans) and deck-building options. the core idea is original and fun. that said, some combinations aren’t very well balanced, which can affect fairness and replayability. [/list]

i love this game and have spent many thousands of hours one both 1 and 2. if you are trying to decide between the first game or the second because money is tight, just go ahead and get the 2nd. i promise you wont miss too much.
really fun roquelike & deckbuilder, runs are fast and very awesome :d only downside - there is a boss or 2 that are waaaaaaay unfair, but that could be just me

just got monster train on sale in 2025 and immediately hooked the steam deck up to the giant tv to hyper-size and slightly blur the graphics. i don't think this has quite the complexity or difficulty of slay the spire, but there are enough unlockables and new clans to play as that it kept me playing for quite a while. if you haven't played this yet and are looking for a deck-builder that's quick to pick up and hard to put down, this is a good option.

being a roguelite deckbuilder, it is very similar to slay the spire in gameplay. but unlike sts where several less than perfect choices can easily ruin your run, monster train focuses on forging yourself into an unstoppable powerhouse. the interesting concept of mixing two clans creates multitudes of unique synergies. game-breaking combinations exist in droves and it is up to you to experiment and discover them. this game is not as tightly balanced than sts, with many runs highly dependent on luck. there is always randomness to games like this, but it sometimes feels nigh impossible to optimize your choices to find a way to win. nonetheless, for a casual player like me, successfully amassing exodia in my deck and steamrolling all foes is still exhilarating as ever.
fun and interesting take on the genre!
fun game with a few interesting game mechanics and lots of perks to keep you playing
a very addictive and fun game!
a slightly more chill slay the spire with a cool twist.
slay the spire but faster and with more classes, pretty good, 8/10 would recommend.

a worse version of slay the spire. this game will appeal to those who enjoy instant gratification, the ability to achieve victory at ease is baked into the game but the pay off is always weaker. not my cup of tea, there are many better deck builders out there and this one doesn't do anything new or better than slay the spire. don't understand the hype for this one, oh wait i do - it's the ease of hitting the deck you want and the mild difficulty. so that might entice you.

this game is a mess. if you're thinking about getting it as it's 'similar' to slay the spire then don't. it's a visual mess with far more going on than slay the spire and no learning campaign or tutorial. sts works because it is simple, both visually and in game play terms. each time i boot up monster train to give it a yet another go, i am overwhelmed by the ui and the totally unintuative gameplay. i don't want to trawl through youtube to learn how to play a game.

not recommended even on a discount. the balance for champions is really bad. the first champion introduced with "slay" and "revenge" is too powerful, making the rest of the playthrough with other champions not fun at all. you are just trying to mimic your playthroughs with the first champion to obtain similar power level but never get there.

this game is middling. i did enjoy my time with it initially, however its too simplistic in its design space. the factions are cool from a first impression, but all the 'depth' that is so beloved is just number stacking and praying. there is very little variance in how you go about winning, and if you don't follow those limited routes, you will lose no matter what. all of these things though, would be forgivable, were it not for how the developers abandoned this game after making a cash grab dlc, and then decided to make a new game with new factions, still in the same bland art style, instead of continuing to support this one. they could have continued to rebalance this game with the money from the dlc, but instead they just left it to rot, and i refuse to support any company that doesn't even bother to try and fix their game. it sets a precedent for how they will treat the next entry, and i refuse to be part of that problem. they left this game to rot, so let the developer rot in return.

the first around 3-4 hours are really fun learning the game, once you know what to look out for the game plays itself most of the times. even after trying out other gimmicks, clans and whole different ways to make my deck, i realized the game is way to easy. each time you win, the games makes it a little bit "harder" for you to win, however every addition is so minor even after those add up you can counteract them pretty easily as well. for example when starting a run at higher "difficulty" a lot of trash cards get added to your deck, the simplest way it to mark the unwanted cards with freeze, or simply remove them, there are such solutions for most things in the game like this, knowing what abilites the bosses have before facing them makes this more strategic but also yet again easier.

in the moment of writing slay the spire has 97/100 and this has 96/100, in that one percent there is a lot of quality. monster train plays (and looks) like a generic mobile game. monster train is one of the easier card games and is probably great if you have little or no experience with this kind of game but it will offer a veteran player nothing but dull disappointment.

played this for a while on game pass and i'll probably play it a bit more having picked it up on a deep discount on steam recently but all in all, it's not the best card game of this nature, not by a long shot. when you think of trains, you think carriages, yet every battle takes place on a single one with 3 tiers and you protect the pyre at the top. i honestly don't know why the game wasn't built around having a long train and you had to protect the engine with battles in each carriage instead? would be a much better and appropriate format imo. the ui is cluttered for what it is, the balance is either too easy or too difficult, and visually the game feels cheap and generic. also it just lacks the fluidity of comparable deck builders and this comes from the strange battle design and convoluted interface. thankfully you know very early on when a run is going to be an early bust. i can still see myself getting 10 or so more hours out of it and it's a great price if you want to take a punt, but don't expect slay the spire on a train because this is nowhere near that in quality and design terms.

i find myself unenthused by the design philosophies of monster train. i've played 4 runs, all with different faction combinations; won 3 with minimal resistance, always playing on the maximum difficulty the game would allow. all runs seem to revolve around creating a "perpetual motion machine" with your deck, i.e. a set of cards you can rapid fire with little thought while watching numbers balloon to absurd and broken heights, and then as each stage draws to a close, hope the numbers have increased sufficiently to survive the end boss. if they haven't, there's next to nothing you can do anyway, but that rarely even comes close to happening. maybe i've been spoiled by the culdcept series, but the variety of cards and the breadth of possible strategies seems severely lacking, and while there's some enjoyment to be had picking and choosing options for the deck, actually playing it is pretty dull. each run goes for about 4 hours, and i feel it should have been 1/4 that much. the game expects you to do a lot of grinding. it "unlocks" new features with a glass dropper, and the new features do little to spark interest anyway. that somber, melancholic world theme clashes really heavily with the cartoonish/goofy/mobile shovelware art style of the game, and just the thought of having to listen to that song again makes me not want to play.
it is short the endgame is stupid. the rng is balanced in the beginning but by the end the tolerances are just too narrow for the sheer amount of variance. good effort, bad results.

[h1]it has less agency during fights than sts[/h1] once you play a unit on a certain floor, that's it, you can't play the unit again this fight (except if you upgrade that card with a special rune) and you can't move the unit to other floors (except with spells). the only other choices you get regarding that unit is whether you play other units in front or behind and whether you play spells on it. after all the units have been played, you're cycling through the cheap spells, waiting for the better spells to draw. [h1]waiting out bossfights is wasting the your time[/h1] when all waves are cleared and the boss enters the first floor, units will repeatedly take turns hitting each other, until either your units are dead or the boss is dead. there is nothing you can do, besides watch. this is so stupidly boring, that the game teaches you to use the fast forward button during the tutorial. there's no point in watching, since you can't influence it in any way. these two designpoints render everything else the game does well, irrelevant. music is good, boss gimmicks are neat, challenges are good, menu animations are quick, gameplay mechanics are reasonably readable. but i don't recommend it.
